undefined

Welcome to Bonfire Character Creation! You'll notice that there's a lot of steps and, if you're familiar with other TTRPGs, that it's a bit longer and a bit more complicated than other games. Why is that?

The first is that it gives you, the player, more choice. Do you want to build a cunning fighter than actually using their brains instead of their brawns to defeat others? Do you want to play a sly diplomat that crushes her opponents' morale without even lifting a finger? Or perhaps you want to play a power wizard that concocts his spells on the fly, building the perfect one for each scenario?

More importantly, do you want those different characters to actually feel different when you play them? So that convincing some actually feels different than just beating them to death?

This is the first thing that Bonfire offers you.

The second thing is that it allows you to be surprised during creation: through your choices and rolls, you'll get a more fully formed character than in other systems. You'll get what you want with extra twists that help add interest and depth to your character that you wouldn't get in other systems.

And not only that, but you'll also have those choices, twists, and depth mean something in play. Is your character brash? You'll be rewarded for playing that way in the game.

So, what are you waiting for? Let's get started!

Step 1: Roll Stats

Your character has 6 attributes that define your character physically and mentally. These are Strength (Str), Dexterity (Dex), Constitution (Con), Intellect (Int), Willpower (Will), and Pre (Presence).

Roll 3d6 for each of these Abilities to generate that score.

This should result in something similar to this:

Str

13

Dex

7

Con

10

Int

14

Will

11

Pre

6

Strength

Strength (Str) represents your character’s pure brawn. How much can she lift and carry? How strong are her punches?

It governs the base damage you do, how much you can carry, and strength-based skills.

Dexterity

Dexterity (Dex) is a measure of how agile your character is. Can she dodge arrows, or can she execute a graceful pirouette? Dexterity is crucial for avoiding blows in combat or traps in a hallway.

It covers how accurate you are, how well you can dodge, how quickly you get up in moving in situations, and dexterity-based skills.

Constitution

Constitution (Con) represents your character’s overall health and toughness. Can he shrug off the Dancing Death or does he succumb to a head cold? Can she take a solid blow in combat and not even blink? These are the things Constitution oversees.

It controls your base Vitality, the amount of minimum Vitality at every other level up, and how much damage you can suck down without going comatose, and constitution-based skills.

Intellect

Intellect (Int) measures your character’s raw knowledge: how much data can he remember? Can she do mathematical calculations or remember who the Elector of Stanitz is? Intellect doesn’t help in applying that knowledge, but it does give you knowledge to draw on.

It governs how accurate you are, how many CrP you get on level up, and intellect-based skills (which are a lot of them).

Willpower

Willpower (Will) is applied knowledge. Does she process information quicker and learn from other’s mistakes? Does he understand life is more than just a set of numbers of probabilities? Can she see other’s viewpoints? How well can she overcome adversity or keep her ground?

It controls your starting Stress Threshold, how likely you are to get hit, how quickly you get up and moving in situations, and willpower-based skills.

Presence

Presence (Pre) represents force of personality. Does he bend others to his will? Is she the focus of any room she enters? Do people look up to them or what to be him? Presence is not looks or even likeability: it represents this animal magnetism that people follow.

Presence covers how much bonus Favor you get when worshipping the Divines, your starting Integrity, how strong your Convictions are, how many contacts you start the game with, how many followers you can have, and presence-based skills.

A Note About Low Stats

Bonfire is specifically balanced for you to roll 3d6 in order, with 10 being the average result but don't worry about feeling like you have low scores or they're not in the order you want: you'll have a chance to rearrange and modify them later.

But even if you have objectively lower stats than the rest of the company, you'll still be able to contribute in a meaningful way in your own area of expertise because Bonfire is built as a team game, so nobody is going to be good at everything.

In Bonfire, you'll almost always be weaker than your opponent: what makes a hero is not supernatural abilities, but the simple fact that he fights longer and harder for what he believes in than other men.

Helpful Tips for New Players

Bonfire is a little different than most RPGs so it's important to keep things in mind:

1) You will never be good at everything: you'll have to rely on teammates.

2) Utilizing different skill sets to help each other is the best strategy to overcome any obstacle. If something seems hard or tedious, it’s because you need to adapt and use a new strategy to overcome it.

Each additional skill set you can incorporate into any challenge increases your chance of surviving exponentially.

3) Don't try to read and understand every rule. Yes, read through the rules generally, but start with a specific character concept and focus on how your character interacts with the world.

Think outside the box: Bonfire is built to reward that kind of thinking.

4) You are going to die. Don't get married to your first few characters.

The pace of the game is intended to be slower and more thoughtful: the more you slowdown and think, the more likely you are to succeed (whatever that means to you) but remember to keep moving forward.

5) Monster body parts are worth a lot.

Example

Alright, let’s roll up a character.

For stats, I got the following:

Str 9

Dex 6

Con 7

Int 9

Will 13

Pre 10

Looking it over, I have average Str, Int, and Pre but a good Will but poor Con and Dex.

That tells me that I probably could get away with a fighter as long as I wasn’t a frontliner but it seems like I should, instead, go for an Expert or Weird-Adept since both rely on Will: I would just need to choose a race to give me a small boost to my Int (although I wouldn’t exactly be suffering with a 9).

Step 2: Receive CrP

Alright, you have your scores. Now it’s time to determine how many Creation Points (or CrP, for short) you’ll start with. These CrP will be spent on modifying your character, buying them their skills and increasing their Scores. They may also be spent on rerolls at certain steps.

Even still, you may want to switch your stats around. This may be because you have almost the right stats, but you have a specific character concept in mind. For instance, using the example stats in Step 1, your party may need a diplomatic character more than a strong character. In this case, it would really help to swap Strength and Presence.

You can freely switch around your stats as need but, in that case, you receive 0 CrPs.

If you switch only 4 of your stats, you receive 10 CrPs.

If you switch 2, you receive 25 CrPs.

And if you keep your stats the way they are, with no changes, you gain 50 CrPs to work with.

Fractional CrP

During Character Creation, you'll have times when things give you discounts, sometimes in percentages. In these cases, track the fractional CrPs.

Example

If I wanted to, I could swap Pre for Wis and to more of a Servant or swap Will for Dex and lean into the backline fighter but I’m actually happy with the idea of going Expert so I’m going to keep them where they’re at and get all 50 CrPs.

Step 3: Select Race

Your character’s race will change how they interact with the world and what they’ll be good and bad at so pick carefully.

Details are found in Chapter 2:Races so go there and pick one and come back here when you’re done.

Example

I think the strong move for me is to go with elves: they get a nice boost to Int and have a high Stress Threshold Modifier and Experts are cheap for them, although I am further tanking my Con as a result, which is fine, because that’s what the party fighter is for.

After adjustments, my stats look like this:

Str 7

Dex 6

Con 3

Int 13

Will 13

Pre 12

Step 4: Select Archetypes

Your character has an area of expertise represented by two Archetypes.

You choose a Primary and a Secondary Archetype and pay the price in CrP for both based on your race’s Archetype Cost section. Descriptions of the different Archetypes are found in Chapter 3:Archetypes along with more details on how to combine them.

If you’ve chosen to swap around all your stats and have no CrPs to work with, congratulations, you’re now in CrP debt and need to make it up by the end of Character Creation.

You must select two Archetypes before going further.

Example

I already talked about going Expert/Expert and I think I’m going to stick with that but I get to choose 2 different Skill Suites which flavor what this character is about.

I also think I’m going to specialize one of my Archetypes as well, probably my Primary one.

In terms of Skill Suites, I’m going to go with Athletics & Weirdcraft. While I have poor physical stats, choosing Athletics here seems like a good choice because it gives me a lot of movement Skills, like Endurance and Move Silently, which are nice for keeping me out of combat.

It also means that, as I level, it’ll also balance out where I’m bad at.

I picked Weirdcraft because I like the idea of an elven cat burglar who uses Weird to fortify their abilities and picking it allows my character to use cantrips.

In terms of Specialization, I’m going to pick up Thief since that seems to be on-brand for my vision of the character.

What that means will be covered a bit later but, for now, that means that I’m at 25 CrP (-5 for each Expert, -20 for Specializing once).

Step 5: Roll Flaws

All heroes have flaws. That’s what makes them relatable and human (even if they’re an orc). Character Flaws earn you additional CrP, which is great.

For a list of Flaws flip to Chapter 4:Flaws.

If you’ve gone into CrP debt and you’re not out of it by the end of this stage, you’ll need to go back and reselect your Archetypes so that you are or go back to your starting set of stats and begin Character Creation all over again with them.

Example

Alright, onto my favorite step: rolling Flaws.

For the first one I roll a 376 which gives me Hypochondriac for a base 15. That’s pretty good so I’m going to keep it and I’m actually going to keep it at Severity 1.

For my next one, I get 740, which is Myopic. It has a base 20 but since it’s my second Flaw, it would give me a base 15.

But I kind of think that my character is going to be dealing with a lot of stuff at close range so I’m actually going to pump it to Severity 3 which gives me 30 extra CrP for a total of 45 CrP for this Flaw.

I get 142 next, which Blind: meh. Let’s reroll for 1 CrP. I get 89, Asthmatic, which I don’t want since I’m going to be Athletics-base so I’m going to reroll again.

I then get 5 which gives me Ageusia. As it stands, since it’s my 3rd Flaw, it won’t give me any CrP (10 - 5 - 5) at Severity 1.

I don’t mind this Flaw so I’m going to bump it up to Severity 3 as well, which at least gives me 10 CrP to work with.

So, for all Flaws, I get a total of 70 CrP but I did 2 rerolls so my net is 68, which brings my total CrPs to 93.

Step 6: Adjust Stats

Now, it is time to do the final adjustments to your stats. This isn't your final adjustments: you'll have a chance to increase them again level up.

The price to increase a Stat by 1 is 10 + (the stat's score * 3). This can't bring you above a 23 in a stat, although it's not recommended to use this method to increase a stat above 6 or 7 as the cost is prohibitively expensive.

Example

So, looking ahead to the Skills chapter, I can see that if I raise my Str and Con by 1 each then I can reduce their penalties to my Skills.

I think, for the Skills I’m going to pick up, most are going to use my Strength Modifier (Climbing, Jumping, Swimming) so I actually think it might be worth it.

For Con, there’s only really Endurance and it’s so cheap it would be better to save my CrP to spend it on the Skill instead, although there’s something to be said for the fact that Con helps you not die so easily.

But I’m still only going to spend it on Str, buying 3 rolls, costing me 15 CrP, bringing my total down to 78.

I roll a 12 on the first one, so that increases my Str to 8, but then I roll a 2 and an 8 on the second and third rolls so I'm out of luck.

Str 8

Dex 6

Con 3

Int 13

Will 13

Pre 12

Step 7: Calculate Character Vitals

Now it’s time to flesh out character’s vitals; their Vitality, Integrity, Fatigue Threshold, and level of induction into whatever faith they choose.

Bonus CrP

Bonus CrP
Integrity of Last Character Bonus CrP
Full of Integrity 25
Lots of Integrity 15
Average Integrity 10
Little Integrity 5
No Integrity 0

If this is your first Bonfire character under this GM, you receive a bonus 10 CrPs.

If you’re here because you’ve had a character die or retire, this bonus CrP is based on the Integrity Category your character was in when they died.

If you’re here because you’ve rolling up secondary character (if you're playing in a West-Marches style game where you can have more than one character), you receive the standard 10 CrPs.

And if you're here because you're rolling up a sidekick or protege for a character already in play, you don't receive this bonus until after the main character has died or retired and then you use their final Integrity score.

Example

Since this is my first character in this campaign I get a 10 CrP bonus, bringing my total up to 88.

Starting Stress Threshold

Your starting Threshold is your race's Stress Threshold Modifier + your Will score + a roll of your Primary and Secondary Archetype Category's Stress Dice.

Experts, Socialites, & Weird-Adepts receive +d6, Fighters & Servants a +d4.

Divide that by 4: that’s the amount of the Stress in each Category.

For fractions on Stress Categories, round up on Unsure but down on the rest.

So, if you’re a Human Double-Down Socalite (2d4) and you roll a 2 with a Will of 8, you have a 25 Stress Threshold. Your Unsure is 1 - 6, Bloodied between 7 - 12, Wounded between 13 - 18, and Critical between 19 - 25.

Record your Stress Threshold on your character sheet.

Example

Being an elf gives me a 20 Stress Threshold Modifier and being a Thief/Expert gives me a +2d6, with which I rolled a 3 and a 4, giving me a total of 40 for my Stress Threshold ( 20 + 3 + 4 + 13 (Will) ).

Not too shabby.

The way to quickly calculate Stress Categories is to divide in half and then divide in half again. Unsure is 1 to halved half, Nervous is halved half + 1 to half, Shaken is half + 1 to half + half halved, Breaking is half + half halved + 1 to your full Stress Threshold.

Confusing enough?

So, for a 40 Stress Threshold, half is 20 and half of 20 is 10.

Unsure is 1 to 10.

Nervous is 11 (10 + 1) to 20.

Shaken is 21 (20 + 1) to 30 (20 + 10).

Breaking is 31 (30 + 1) to 40.

Starting Vitality

To calculate your base Vitality, add a roll of your Primary and Secondary Archetype’s Vitality Die to your Constitution + their Vitality Size Modifier.

Divide that by 4: that’s the amount of the Vitality in each Category.

Your Trauma Threshold is twice that (rounded up). Trauma is talked about more in Chapter 3:Combat.

For fractions on Wound Categories, round up on Hurt but down on the rest.

So, if you’re a Human with and your Vitality Dice is a d6 and a d4, if you roll a 3 and 2, with a Con of 12, you have 32 Vitality. Your Hurt is 1 - 8, Bloodied between 9 - 15, Wounded between 16 - 24, and Critical between 25 - 32.

Record your Vitality Die on your character sheet.

Example

This is going to be rough.

Being an elf gives me a 10 Vitality Modifier.

Since I'm a Thief/Expert, my Vitality Dice are a d4 and a d6, and I roll a 1 on both.

That gives me a total of 15 for my Vitality ( 10 + 1 + 1 + 3 (Con) ). This means that, if the person is using a large weapon, I could easily be killed in one shot so I need to stay out of combat, especially melee combat.

The way to quickly calculate Wound Categories is the same as calulating Stress Categories but swapping the names.

So, for 15 Vitality, half is 7.5 and half of 7.5 is 3.75.

Hurt is 1 to 4 (because we round up).

Bloodied is 5 (4 + 1) to 7.

Wounded is 8 (7 + 1) to 10 (7 + 3 (rounded down this time)).

Critical is 11 (10 + 1) to 15.

Starting Integrity

Your starting Integrity is a function of your Pre. Refer to the following table:

Starting Integrity
Presence Starting Integrity
1 5
2 6
3 8
4 10
5 11
6 12
7 12
8 13
9 13
10 13
11 13
12 13
13 14
14 14
15 14
16 15
17 16
18 18
19 20
20 21
21 22
22 23
23 24

Example

Since we have a Pre of 13, we start with 14 Integrity; not bad.

Starting Fatigue Threshold

Your Fatigue Threshold starts at Critical, however, it can be lowered by wearing armor and wielding shields you're not fully trained in.

Example

This is easy: we start at Critical.

Levels of Induction & Max Favor

There are 3 levels of commitment to a cult, that determines how often you get Favor and how much Favor you can have:

Unanointed

These are the lowest level: those outside the cult and its mysteries. They gain no benefits of any kind.

Anointed

These are those that are the lay members of the faith. They gain small bonuses to their max Favor for the deity they’re devoted to. You can only be anointed to one Covenant at a time.

If you have a positive Devotion to a deity, one of their cults, or one of their Covenants, you can choose to begin the game as an anointed to that deity. Otherwise, you can become Anointed during gameplay once you have that Devotion.

You can only be anointed to one deity at a time.

Servants

These are the highest rung of the commitment ladder and serve as the officers of the cult of the god. They’re priests, abbots, hierophants, pontiffs, nazarites, hermits, etc. These are men and women that have taken vows to devote their life to the cult.

In game terms, this means that these are those who have a Servant Archetype as either their Primary or Secondary Archetype.

Max Favor

Maximum Favor
Integrity Cat. Max Favor
No Integrity Cannot Invoke
Little Integrity 0
Average Integrity 1
Lots of Integrity 2
Full of Integrity 3
Anointed/Servant +2

A person can only have so much Favor, with the Divines giving a little extra leeway for those of strong character. The Max Favor a person can have is limited to their Integrity Category.

Anointed members increase this threshold by 2 while Servants get that +2 and also increase their Max Favor by their Archetype level, but both cannot gain any Favor while in the No Integrity Category, regardless of level.

Should a person drop an Integrity Category, if their Favor is above their new max, it automatically drops.

Starting Favor

Regardless of what level of induction a person chooses, they start with their Favor at max.

Example

Because I’m pretty squishy, having a small bank of Favor wouldn’t be a terrible thing to have in my back pocket but it does cost me a Devotion that fleshes out my relationship to my faith.

I think it’s worth it so I start as Anointed, which gives me a Max Favor of 3 and 3 Favor to start with.

I’ll also need to consider how my faith reflects my character but that can wait.

Out of Order Character Creation

If you’re a little bit more familiar with Bonfire Character creation, the 3 last steps (step 8, 9, and 10) can be taken in any order you’d like, even skipping back and forth between them.

Step 8: Skills

Skills are additional areas of expertise that your character has obtained above his or her race and class.

Both cost CrP and are found in Chapter 5:Skills but, before you rush over there, you need to determine the starting Ranks for your Skill Suites, which you have to do before buying any Skills.

Keep in mind, once you do go rushing over to buy Skills, that you don't add any of your free purchases from your Archetype at this step but you do apply any discounts you get from your current Archetypes (so, if you're Specialized, use those discounts - otherwise, you get your Generalist's discounts).

Calculating Starting Ranks

There are 7 non-Combat Skill Suites:

  • Athletics
  • Lore
  • Streetwise
  • Survival
  • Strategy
  • Trades
  • Weirdcraft

There are 5 Combat Skill Suites:

  • Armor
  • Melee Weapons
  • Ranged Weapons
  • Shields
  • Unarmed

To determine your starting Rank in each, follow the guide below. Note that, if you get Ranks in a Skill Suite here, you automatically gain Training in that Suite.

  • Your Primary Generalist's Main Skill Suite starts at Rank 2.
    • If you get two (noted with an "and", not "or"), one starts at Rank 2, the other starts at Rank 1, otherwise pick one to start at 2.
      • If you're a Double-Down Expert, your 3rd and 4th Skill Suites start at 0.
    • When you Specialize, you gain Rank 1 in its Main Skill Suite
      • If you get two (noted with an "and", not "or"), one starts at Rank 1, the other starts at Rank 0, otherwise pick one to start at 1.
      • If your Primary and Secondary Archetype both reference your Secondary Archetype's Main Skill Suite, use your Primary's Generalist Archetype' Main Skill Suite.
  • Your Secondary Generalist's Main Skill Suite starts at Rank 1.
    • If you would normally get two, you only get one of them.
    • When you Specialize, you gain Rank 0 in its Main Skill Suite.
      • If you would normally get two, you only get one of them.
  • If, for any reason, a Skill Suite doubles up, you only get a +1 to its Rank.
    • This is true each time this happens (so tripling up gives you an additional +1; quadrupling up gives another +1, etc.)
  • Finally, select 3 Skill Suites: these start at Rank 0.
    • If you're a Fighter, your chosen Skill Suites should match to Combat Skill Suites you’ve already picked or you need to select them now.
      • Remember that 2 of these have to be different Skill Suites.
    • You can, instead, choose Skill Suites you already have Ranks in, but it only increases its Rank by 1 and cannot bring a Skill Suite above Rank 4.
    • All other Skill Suites start as Untrained (marked with a U).

Note that you get the Advanced Language Skill for free in your native language with its Rank starting at your Int.

Example

Alright, onto purchasing Skills but first, let’s get some Skill Suite Ranks.

Remember that I’m a Thief/Expert who chose Athletics and Weirdcraft for their Main Skill Suites.

So, for Athletics and Weirdcraft, one is going to start at 2 and the other at 1. I’m actually going to pick Athletics because I think my character will need it more.

I’m actually kind of thinking that my character was kind of a jock growing up and was very physical until they got sick and their stats plummeted; so I have the know-how, I just lost the natural talent for it.

Because I specialized into Thief, I also get another bump to a Skill Suite, specifically Streetwise. I also get Language (Thieves Cant) but that’s not relevant right now since we’re just focusing on Suites.

Since it’s Streetwise, it starts at Rank 1, which is neat.

My Secondary Archetype is still Expert and my Main Skill Suites are still Athletics and Weirdcraft, however, since this is my Secondary and I already have Ranks in them, I only get a +1 Rank to one of them and I’m going Athletics, which brings it up to Rank 3.

Finally, I need to pick 3 Skill Suites to start at Rank 0 with the rest being Untrained, which means I’ll get a penalty when using them.

I’m going to pick Melee and Ranged Weapons so I might be able to participate as a flanker and Lore for that tasty knowledge.

So, my Skills look like this:

Athletics 3

Lore 0

Streetwise 1

Survival U

Strategy U

Trades U

Weirdcraft 1

Armor U

Melee Weapons 0

Ranged Weapons 0

Shields U

Unarmed U

Buying Advanced Skills

This usually takes the longest for new players but becomes really quick once you get the hang of it.

I usually start by going down the list of Skills and picking everyone I want to buy without any consideration for the cost.

For this character, I’m going to focus on Athletic Skills, so the list looks something like this. I’ve also recorded their cost and their starting Rank, which is based off of the Suite they came from.

Skill - Cost - Rank

Acrobatics - 7 - 3

Climbing - 7 - 3

Endurance - 4 - 3

Escape Artist - 7 - 3

Jumping - 5 - 3

Move Silently - 9 - 3

Swimming - 5 - 3

Listening - 6 - 1

Quarter Mastering - 5 - U

I’m just going to focus on purchasing one Skill but I usually jump around when I’m buying them.

Upping Acrobatics to Rank 4 would normally cost me 16 CrP ((3 * 3) + 7) but, since I have a Skill Adept from Thief and one from Expert, that reduces the cost by 2 so I’m going to pay 14 CrP instead.

Note that I don’t get the double-down benefit for Expert because I’m no longer doubled-down.

If I wanted to increase Acrobatics to Rank 5, from there, it would cost me 19 CrP since every Rank adds +3 to the cost so it’s really easy to figure out the increase once you’ve done the baseline calculation.

Step 9: Flesh Out Personality

Your character also has a personality (shocker) that sets them apart.

What do they want? What do they believe? Who do they like? What do people think of them?

These questions are answered using Goals, Convictions, Devotions, Descriptions, Racial, and Reputation, which we’ll fill out now.

The “Characteristics”, as they’re collectively called, are also given a Rank that reflects their strength (Goals being the exception).

Goals

Goals serve two purposes.

First, they help your GM figure out what you want to do with the character: where you want to take them and what they’re trying to accomplish. At this stage, if you haven't already, you should bring your GM to talk about the shape of the campaign and what Goals will work the best.

Second, they help you get CrPs that you can then turn around and use to make your character stronger.

A character can have 3 Goals at any one time, although it’s fine if you only start with 1.

You should discuss with your GM what Goals are going to work for the campaign to get on the same page. The GM has the final say on what Goals are appropriate to take.

Have a Goal that you can continue to work for but also have a Goal(s) that are actionable as you get bonus CrP for completing them but you only get this bonus once per level so you should aim to have a goal to be completed before the end of first level, a goal to be completed by the end of second, and a goal to be completed by the end of third.

Example

This would be the time to talk to the GM about what time of game they’re running so the character’s Goal can align with that idea and the other players’.

For this game, it’s going to be set in the fantasy equivalent of the Italian city-states with the law just being another one of the plethora of gangs roaming the streets and the players are going to be starting their own crew with the hope of rising up through the ranks.

So, for that, I think that my character wants to found a merchant house: basically go legitimate. Or as legit as you can go in this setting.

Technically, I get 3 but I only need 1 so I’m going to wait for the game to get rolling before filling out the other 2.

Convictions

Convictions are beliefs, worldviews, and areas of confidence that your character has. They’re powerful but volatile.

They can be simple “People are good” or complex “Nobody wants to be bad at their job”. They can also be inward facing “I’m brave”.

Convictions don’t reflect objective reality; only reality as that character sees it.

So a character with 3 Strength and the “I’m Strong” Conviction isn’t strong; he’s just very confident he is.

You can also have conflicting Convictions because people are complicated but individual Convictions can’t have conjunctions of any kind in them.

The starting number of Convictions your character starts with is based on their Int.

Starting Conviction Number
Intellect # of Convictions
1 1
2 2
3 2
4 3
5 3
6 3
7 4
8 4
9 4
10 4
11 4
12 4
13 4
14 5
15 5
16 5
17 6
18 6
19 7
20 7
21 8
22 8
23 8

All Convictions start at Rank 0.

You gain a number of “Conviction Points” equal to your Pre that you can divide among your Convictions to increase their Ranks on a 1-to-1 basis.

Unspent Conviction Points are lost after character creation but you can wait until after you’ve spent CrP on your Convictions before distributing them (which you should).

Increasing Your Convictions With CrP

Your character might have spent time cultivating their personality instead of hitting the obstacle course or the library, in which case, their Convictions are going to be stronger than normal.

This translates to increasing a Conviction’s Rank with CrP.

The cost is 7 + (Current Rank * 2).

A new Conviction is only 7 CrP and starts at Rank 0.

Thinking of Characteristics

Thinking of Characteristics on the fly is hard but there's two ways of handling this: either picture a character from fiction you like or find interesting and try to describe them. These are their Characteristics, and you can crib off them to start with.

Or if you have no idea where to start or are just a risk taker, you can use the Characteristic Generator, which will give you a random Characteristic. These Characteristics may not always make sense, but they can often serve as a jumping off point for your imagination.

{{description | titlecase}}

{{conviction | titlecase}}

{{devotion | titlecase}}

Conflicting Characteristics

Because human beings are wonderful, chaotic being, they're capable of believing two entirely opposing things at the same time and this is represented in Bonfire by having conflicting Characteristics.

I would actually recommend you start with a conflicting Conviction (or Devotion). It adds a bit of depth and interest to your character, points a struggle that you would be interested in roleplaying out to your GM so that they can weave that into the adventure or campaign, and gives you a place to grow. Let yourself be surprised by who your character becomes.

Example

This character gets 4 Convictions due to their 13 Int and 12 Ranks to distribute due to their 12 Pre.

Unless I have a specific character concept in mind, what I usually do is give half the Ranks to the first Conviction, half of the remaining to the next Conviction, half to the next, and so on until I run out of Ranks or Convictions.

So, using that method, my Convictions look like this:

Conviction 1: Rank 6

Conviction 2: Rank 3

Conviction 3: Rank 2

Conviction 4: Rank 1

I want to figure out what Conviction 1 and 2 are before the game begins because it gives a base from which to build off my character but leaving 3 and 4 open gives me the space to fill those in once I know what kind of character will work with the style and party.

I think the first one is going to be “Riches are the ultimate security” because I want to explain why he has his Goal and why he would join a gang.

The second one I’m going to randomly generate using the Conviction Generator. I got “The Fates are cruel - Don’t give them extra chances to torture you”. Interesting; I like it.

Devotions

What relationships does he have? What organizations does your character associate with? Is he religious and, if so, is his loyalty more to his cult or to his god? How does he feel about that thing?

Relationships between individuals don’t need to be reciprocal or even contemporary. A young fighter may be inspired by a girl who doesn't love him back or by a long dead king he greatly admires. These are still viable candidates for his Devotion.

Everyone receives two free Devotions: one to their character’s clan/family and another of their choice. Each Devotion comes with a "relationship verb" and the thing itself. So, his clan Devotion could be "Hate Clan" or "Have mixed feelings about Clan" or "Loyal to Clan"

These Devotions start a 2.

Increasing Your Devotions With CrP

You can also increase your Devotions or purchase new ones as well.

All new Devotions start at Rank 1 and cost 7 + (Number of Devotions * 2) CrP to purchase.

From there, you can increase their size which costs 7 + (the Devotion’s Rank * 6).

Example

So, I get two Devotions starting at Rank 2, one of which has to do with my character's faith since they’re part of a cult so let’s take care of that first.

I can talk to my GM about what faiths are available in the campaign world and, if one doesn’t fit, we can discuss other options.

Most games have a Divine of Thieves so that seems like a good choice but now I need a relationship verb.

I actually think that it would be interesting to do ‘admires’ and have the Divine being a crippled god that uses their wits to outsmart others and get what they want; I think that would really appeal to my character and give a good reason for him to want to join the cult.

So the full Devotion is “Admires the Divine of Thievery”.

For the second one, it relates to his clan. Talking to the GM, this means the character’s crew so this outlines how I feel about the gang, although I could single out a single player or NPC that’s in that crew.

I’m going to go with “is using” as the verb; “Is Using the Crew”.

He sees the crew as a means to his Goal, not as a goal themselves. That should keep him loyal and create some opportunities for the GM to test that with perhaps the character slowly growing to care for his gang or growing apart and betraying them.

Descriptions

Descriptions are physical things about your character, whether it’s something specific (“I have blonde hair”, “Tall”) or something that more relates to your demeanor (“Grumpy”, “Charming”): these are things that relate to what people notice about you when they first meet you.

Descriptions don’t always reflect objective reality; only reality as other characters see it. The rule of thumb is that, if it's covered by something else (a stat or skill, for example), it is how others perceive you, otherwise treat it as objective.

So, a character with 3 Strength and the “Strong” Description isn’t strong; he’s just perceived as though he is. A character with the "Grump" and "Tall" Description, however, is actually grumpy and tall (for whatever race they are) and people can spot that almost right away.

Descriptions are weak and you’ll tend to have only a few but they aren’t Stressful to use, which makes them very versatile and able to give you a quick boost.

You start with 3 Descriptions starting at Ranks 3, 2, and 1, respectively.

The highest Rank Description will be what people notice about you first: does your character seem agile? Are they aggressive in their movements? Are they exceptionally clean?

Increasing Your Descriptions With CrP

Like Convictions and Devotions, you can increase and buy Descriptions, although at a much steeper cost.

The base cost for Descriptions are the number of your character’s Descriptions * 6.

New Descriptions start at Rank 1.

Increasing the Rank of a Description by 1 is the Base Cost + (Rank * 12) CrP.

Example

What are the first three things a person would notice about my character? I imagine him as sickly, tall, and determined. Those are my Descriptions. Done.

Racial Temperament

Your Racial Temperament comes from your race and behaves like a Description with a Rank of 3, which is why it has its own subsection in the Description section of your character sheet.

With GM permission, you can change this based on the setting and how your character personally feels.

Increasing Your Temperament With CrP

Like Descriptions, you can increase your Temperament’s Rank, although it is cheaper to do so.

Increasing the Rank of a Temperament by 1 costs 6 + (Rank * 8) CrP.

Example

As an elf, I lean towards being Patient and I’m happy with that.

Contacts

This is the number of unredeemed contacts a character starts with, reflecting previous relationships he's created before he became an adventurer. More on Contacts and how to redeem them is found in Chapter 4: Challenges.

Starting Contacts
Presence Unredeemed Contacts
1 0
2 0
3 0
4 1
5 1
6 2
7 3
8 4
9 5
10 5
11 7
12 7
13 10
14 13
15 16
16 20
17 24
18 28
19 32
20 36
21 40
22 44
23 50

Example

He gets 10 unredeemed Contacts so I’ll record that in the Contact section for now.

Reputation

Finally, Reputation, which acts like a Description but is controlled by your GM.

Reputation, in a nutshell, is what your character is known for and how other people see them. So, if you want to convince someone that you’ll keep your word, having a Reputation for doing so will help you out.

Reputation takes the form of 3 incomplete sentences starting with “I’m known for...”. Each time you finish a period of training, your GM will finish or change out one or more of those sentences and assign points to them that represent their strength. She’ll choose how to finish them based on how your character has been acting or the results of their actions.

That’s right: just like in real life, you don’t really have control over your Reputation, though there is a way to influence it as you go.

All your Reputations start at 0.

Step 10: Buy Equipment

A character starts with one of the following kits. After doing so, he rolls the kit's Extra Cash dice to determine any extra starting money to buy additional gear. When buying new items, use the Source price.

The individual sizes are notes next to the item. Note that anything with * at the end denotes that the item is worn and so the size has been adjusted accordingly.

You're also given the sellback price (in sc) in case you don't want the item. For weapons, you'll notice that you're giving a generic size of weapon you can select from - the sellback price is unaffected by which weapon you would have picked up.

Free Heirloom

After you pick your kit, you're going to select one of the pieces of equipment to be an heirloom - a special piece of equipment that's a little nicer than the rest of your gear for whatever reason. This item starts with a +2 Description of your choice. See the Superior Equipment section in Chapter 6:Equipment for more details.

Left-Over CrP

You may also cash in any left-over CrP for sp at 1 CrP for 10 sc, but you don’t have to. You can save your CrP to spend later at your level up.

After all the buying and selling don’t forget to adjust your Carry.

Kits

{{kit.name}}
Item Size Sell Back
{{item.name}} {{item.size}} {{item.sellback}}
Weight: {{kit.weight}} Extra Cash: {{kit.cash}}

Example

I think I’m going to go with the Thief’s Kit, although, considering my low Str, I might have to buy more bags to carry everything, sell off the extra weight, or pass some gear off to a stronger party member.

For my 2 Small Weapons, I’m going to pick the stiletto and dagger because that gives me a bit of versatility and seems right for my character.

I’m also going to use some of my extra cash to buy a composite bow since that doesn’t rely on my Str and is lighter and quieter than my other options.

Step 11: Record Archetype Abilities

Now is the time to get any free purchases and record any Skills you obtained free from your Archetype choice, as well as Archetype Abilities. Weird-Adepts will need to go to the Acquiring Rudiments sidebar in Chapter 2:Archetypes to roll up their Rudiments. They might also find it helpful to open the SRD in another tab and go to Chapter 6:The Weird so they can easily reference that information.

Example

This is where you apply free purchases for Skills based on your Archetypes.

My character is a Thief/Expert, focusing on Athletics and Weirdcraft, which means that I get 1 free purchase of 5 different Athletics and 5 different Weirdcraft Skills due to the Skill Focus abilities.

Since I didn’t replace my Secondary Archetype yet, I don’t have to forfeit an ability, so that’s nice.

Because I’m a Thief, I also get 3 free purchases of Language (Thieves Cant), free purchases from my Thief's Training ability and free purchases from the Skill Focus (Streetwise, 3) I get from that Archetype.

Note that I need to pick an Advanced Skill for my Thief’s Training that’s unique to my character; I’m going to pick Glamour.

Step 12: Transfer to Character Sheet

Congratulations: you’re on the home stretch! Finish your character off by transferring your notes to a fresh character sheet.

Chapter 1Step-by-Step Overview

Which Race Should I Choose?

Your race effects character creation in 3 ways: Stat Score Modifiers, Gameplay Rewards, and Archetype Costs. If you're new to RPGs in generally, go for a race that interests you based on the flavor.

Stat Score Modifiers

These modify the base stats that you roll. You can use it to balance out your character's weak spots or you can use it to maximize what your character is already good it. We recommend the latter as Bonfire is a game built around teamwork: you'll have friends who will be good at things your character isn't.

Note that these adjustments can't bring score above 20 or below 1.

Gameplay Rewards

Each race is meant to encourage a certain type of play. For instance, orcs gain bonuses for starting things, like combats or Confrontations, so they reward players who are aggressive, while elves get rewarded for being careful with how they engage with others. These are noted under the Racial Temperament section in their summary.

Archetype Costs

Some races can spend less time mastering things than others, freeing up time (CrP) to focus on other pursuits or becoming true masters of their vocation. This is reflected in the Archetype Costs.

Changelings

Changeling Summary

Modifiers

-4 Str

+2 Dex

+3 Int

Small Sized (- 1 ft to Measure, +3 to Melee & Ranged Defense, less movement, and require less food)

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

Stress Threshold Modifier is 20

Racial Temperament

Crafty

Racial Ability

Feisty: Whenever they roll a Grit Die, on a 1, reroll the die: you must keep the second result.

Archetype Costs

Expert: 0
Fighter: 15
Servant: 10
Socialite: 5
Weird-Adept: 5

For having stolen weirdsecrets from the covetous Alwealda, we and our children are cursed. We bear it happily for the price is worthy of the reward. Let others look skyward; we shall look ahead.

Changelings are strange little beings. The rumors are that their demons who've trade places with human children left out in the wild or that they're the stillborn children of wizards and witches. Either way, their wiliness and technical prowess make them welcome guests where every they end up.

Appearance

Changelings are about the size of a 10-year-old human, with extremely pale skin, unusually long fingers and large eyes. Besides this, they appear like little humans, with wispy hair on their head and face.

They dress in whatever the area custom is but tend towards bright and clashing colors.

Personality

Changelings are wily and crafty, and, while not lacking in morality, tend to get caught up on whatever project they're currently on. They enjoy puzzles more than anything - the thrill of having everything click into place just perfectly is the finest thing a person can experience.

They also tend to be on the shy side, as much as possible, keeping out of the limelight. Worldly power and accolades hold little appeal for them, but there is a sense of wanting to be apart something greater than keeps them reaching out to the outside world.

Dwarves

Dwarf Summary

Modifiers

-3 Dex

+4 Con

-2 Pre

Small Sized (- 1 ft to Measure, +3 to Melee & Ranged Defense, less movement, and require less food)

Vitality Size Modifier is 20

Stress Threshold Modifier is 15

Racial Temperament

Unconquerable

Racial Abilities

Stout: Can wield weapons and shields as if they were Medium-sized.

Stonekin: Your Fatigue and Panic Thresholds start as one better (e.g. Critical instead of Wounded, or Breaking instead of Shaken).

Archetype Costs

Expert: 5
Fighter: 0
Servant: 25
Socialite: 15
Weird-Adept: 25

Why does it matter where we come from? Sod off.

Dwarves are called the 'Stonemen' not because they're made of stone but because they're hard as rock. They're obstinate and incorrigible and, as a rule, they never do anything that someone else wants them to do. As such, they're the most disagreeable beings in the Middle Realm. They're also the most straightforward, brave, and loyal beings as well.

Appearance

Dwarves are the opposite of elves. They're short, barrel chested with thick hair growing all over their bodies. This hair ranges from coal black to a golden hue, depending on which hold the dwarf hails from. They also always support big bushy beards that are near hard as steel.

These beards are their pride and joy and they take great care in them. Woven into each beard is the tale of that dwarf's life and accomplishments as well as their job within the hold. You can learn a lot from reading a dwarf's beard.

Besides this and their tools, the dwarves really don't take care of themselves, eschewing anything showy or fancy, like nice fabrics or baths.

Dwarf anatomy is, thankfully, a mystery to most outsiders. All dwarves, to other races, appear human and use human pronouns, though in dwarvish, there are no pronouns because that's more bothersome. There is a rumor that there are female dwarves but that there's 0 sexual dimorphism in the species, which makes courting a very careful affair, but the running theory is that female dwarves are just anvils.

Personality

As stated before, dwarves are stubborn. They're very rarely, however, psychopathically so. More often, once they have decided something, they tend to get defensive and refuse to relent unless they absolutely have to.

This makes dwarven governments and social structures very slow moving and difficult to work with but, it also means that if you get a dwarf to agree with you, they will happily die on that hill.

In fact, the only time that a dwarf seems to be happy is when he's being stubborn about something.

Finally, dwarves do not ascribe to social niceties. It's not that they're incapable to understanding them or aware of them: they just don't think they're worth paying attention to, in the same way that most people don't notice insects.

Elves

Elf Summary

Modifiers

-2 Str

-4 Con

+4 Int

+2 Pre

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

Stress Threshold Modifier is 20

Racial Temperament

Patient

Racial Ability

Star Shield: when resisting a spell’s Effect, any Boons that you get on your Check can be given to your allies if they’re affected by the same spell and it requires Mental resistance or if the spell requires Physical resistance and you’re within 5 ft.

Archetype Costs

Expert: 5
Fighter: 10
Servant: 5
Socialite: 0
Weird-Adept: 0

We who were trapped in prisons of flesh look to our forebears. For as the Alwealda ascended to return to the Divines, we, their children, will also ascend when we too have perfected ourselves in their sight.

The Elves are the first born of the Divines. Originally, the inhabitants of the Painted World, the source of all magic, they now inhabit the Middle Realm as mentally ethereal beings.

Appearance

Elves are slender beings that are widely considered classically beautiful, though many find their features alien and off putting. They uniformly have long ears that taper to a point at the end.

Their eyes are pure white, with no iris or pupil visible, this matched with their sharp teeth, can give them a feline turn to their face.

Elves naturally survive off the ebb and flow of magic that drifts through the air of the Painted World. While still present in the Middle Realm, these winds are a sliver of their natural magnitude and so Elves need to find other sources; the main one being through the magic inherent in all living creatures. While vegetables do have magic in them, an Elf would have to consume 100s of pounds of lettuce each day to not die of starvation. The only realistic way of getting enough magic to survive is through the consumption of meat, making them omnivores in theory but carnivores in practice.

Personality

To describe an Elf as “careful” would be a huge understatement. They tend to live longer than other races, not because some supernaturally long lifespan, but because they're always careful about their actions. They see other races as brash and impetuous while they're in turn seen as slow and cowardly.

It's not they're incapable of great emotion or quick action but elves seem to understand that with every action comes a consequence, whether that action was well meaning or not, and that this karmic force is more powerful than any other law or power.

However, once set on a course, it is hard to dissuade an elf, for they do nothing lightly.

Gaunts

Gaunt Summary

Modifiers

-2 Str

+2 Dex

+2 Will

+3 Pre

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

Stress Threshold Modifier is 10

Racial Temperament

Choose one: Salvation Secured or Damnation Secured

Racial Abilities

Precious: Gain a Devotion at Rank 15 that represents what they became a Gaunt for

Further Sacrifice: Lower your max Vitality by 1: gain 1 Favor. This can take you above your Max Favor.

Archetype Costs

Expert: 0
Fighter: 0
Servant: 25
Socialite: 0
Weird-Adept: 10

For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? It is not enough for a man to ask what he would die for, but he must ask himself, what would he live for?

Gaunts are said to be depraved creatures stuck between life and death. They love filthy lucre more than what made them human. They're those that, for whatever reason, have sold part of their souls for either money or at a chance at eternal life in the world to come.

Appearance

Gaunts of all races look generally the same as the soul shiving process drains them of their vitality. Their skin turns ghost white, their hair a weak grey, and their eyes become milky as if they're blind. Their bodies becoming desiccated, thin and reedy.

They still need to eat, drink, and do other bodily functions - they are, even after all that, living.

Gaunts tend to dress in flamboyantclothing that is a mix and match of whatever they kind find. Most say this is because they loot the clothing off of those they kill but it's more likely because they just wear what they can find or because they wish to make up for their dull color palette

Personality

As stated, gaunts get a bad rep for being whollywithout morals but that's not always the case. Some have undergone the process because they need to feed their families or out of a powerful sense of devotion or religious zeal so actually gaunts run the spectrum of Personality types: they're just saddled with their reputation because of an admittedly not small section of them.

What makes up the gaunt's Personality is why he made the sacrifice to do what he did. Why was so precious to him that he would make such a huge sacrifice for? That's a complicated question and not easy to answer by the gaunt player should have their answer before play begins.

Humans

Human Summary

Modifiers

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 15

Stress Threshold Modifier is 15

Racial Temperament

None

Racial Abilities

True Grit: Increase the size of your Grit Die by 1.

Skilled: Gain a non-leveling ability from any Archetype.

Archetype Costs

Expert: 0
Fighter: 0
Servant: 0
Socialite: 0
Weird-Adept: 0

In the days of yore, the Divines and the Giants fought in a war unending. And from their struggles fell their blood and sweat to the earth. From that mixture arose the first man and women, born of blood, sweat, and earth; the prices we must pay for all things.

Humans are the first natives of the Middle Realm. They are creatures born from strife, who’ve carved for themselves a place in the world through fire, steel, and grit.

Appearance

The Humans of the Middle Realm look like you and me. Their skin, eye, and hair color range widely, adapted to the region of that Human’s origin, with darker skins more common towards the equator.

If you don’t know what a Human looks like, I don’t know what to tell you.

Personality

The truth is Humans are odd and quirky individuals that seem to have the defining trait of their curiosity and ambition.

Truthfully, you probably have your own opinion about how humans behave and why they behave the way they do and nothing I write in this little blurb is going to convince you otherwise.

Orcs

Orc Summary

Modifiers

+4 Str

+3 Con

-4 Int

-4 Pre

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 15

Stress Threshold Modifier is 15

Racial Temperament

Aggressive

Racial Ability

Destructive: When using equipment to gain a bonus, orcs may gain an extra +d6! to their Check in exchange for an additional 1 Wear on the item.

Archetype Costs

Expert: 10
Fighter: 0
Servant: 15
Socialite: 20
Weird-Adept: 10

Days of ashes and nights of fire; we were great warriors then. But our swords and shields were stolen from us and now we, the nomads, search for things that no hand can hold. Where must we go? We who search the wasteland for our better selves?

Heirs to a great empire long since lost to the ages, the orcs cling to tradition in the wake of uncertain and dark times. Some say that they value only strength but to truly known an orc is to know the soul of honor.

Appearance

Orcs have dark green or grey skin with porcine nose and tusks that jut up from their lower jaw. They tend to be stocky, with thick muscles and hunched shoulders.

Their hair is wiry, closer to steel wool than anything else and their eyes are completely black, with no pupils or irises, giving them an indescribable inhumanness to it.

Naturally, orcs are scavengers, able to survive on practically anything, no matter how rotten or foul.

Personality

An orc’s life is defined by struggle: from birth to death, they conceptualize the universe as having a vendetta against them. This can often give them a martyr complex and make them morose traveling companions at times because they feel the weight of the world.

They can also come across as aggressive, which some have pointed out is a defense mechanism, but orcs would simply scoff at that.

There’s nothing an orc values more than their honor and the chance to prove themselves against a worthy foe. This is often seen in their deities across orcish cultures, which are almost exclusively pantheons of their greatest foes. It is taken for granted that you are only as good as your enemies.

Ratfolk

Ratfolk Summary

Modifiers

-6 Str

-4 Con

+3 Will

+5 Pre

Small Sized (- 1 ft to Measure, +3 to Melee & Ranged Defense, less movement, and require less food)

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

Stress Threshold Modifier is 15

Racial Temperament

Helpful

Racial Ability

Packrat: Double your Carry from Strength (e.g. 2S of Carry becomes 4S or 1S 1M)

Archetype Costs

Expert: 0
Fighter: 15
Servant: 10
Socialite: 15
Weird-Adept: 15

What a broken and fractious world; what a fallen state to toil in. Is it not enough to suffer the cruelty of fate that we should inflict wounds on one another? Consign yourself to oblivion or pick up your brother and fight for the hope of starlight in the infinite void.

Ratfolk are social creatures. They love people and being around people. Others find them pleasant to be around. As such, Ratfolk can be found as diplomats, traders, and minstrels .

Appearance

Ratfolk are smaller and slimmer than other races, with lithe, fur covered bodies that range from auburn to dark black. They have beady eyes and long tails. For the most part, they appear like their smaller cousins, though with lighter frames and opposable thumbs.

Personality

As stated, ratfolk are people people. They're extremely social and, as a rule, are extroverted. They tend to be agreeable and try to get along with everyone but this shouldn't be taken as people pleasing or weak because ratfolk are clever - dangerously so.

People tend to think that because ratfolk are so easy going that they're push overs and that they can be taken advantage of but ratfolk sees it as "I'll scratch your back, you scratch mine" kind of deal so they're not just going to do things to do things. They very much believe in the social contract, but their animal nature makes them ruthless as some points.

In fact, ratfolk can be quite ruthless to those they deem outside their pack, which has earned them some reputation as having a herd mentality. For ratfolk the only war is total war.

Chapter 2Races

Introduction

Archetypes represent your character’s background training and starting skills and there are two types of Archetypes: Generalist and Specialist.

Leveling Terminology

When an ability says "At first level and every 3rd level after that..." or "at every 3rd level, including the first...", it means the ability increases at 1st, 4th, 7th, 10th, etc. If an ability says "At every 3rd level", that means 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th, etc.

Generalist Archetypes

These Archetypes represent the overall theme.

For instance, Fighter Archetypes tend to be good at things related to combat. So, if you’re looking to make a combat focused character, you can look there. They are Expert, Weird-Adept, Servant, Socialite, and Fighter. You must pick two starting out.

Generalists will have a wide variety of discounts within their theme that are good for just getting straight bonuses.

Purchasing Archetypes

First choose a Generalist Primary and a Generalist Secondary Archetype and pay the price in CrP for both based on your race.

You use the Primary Drawback sections from the Primary, and combine both the free Advanced Skills (listed under the Main Skill Suite) and the Archetype Abilities sections, though you completely remove 1 ability marked with * from your Secondary Archetype, unless you Double Down.

If two characters have the same ability, unless it says otherwise, those abilities stack.

Doubling Down

All Generalists, except for the Servant, can be selected as both your Primary and Secondary Archetype, called Double Down. So, you can be a Fighter/Fighter but not a Servant/Servant.

If you Double Down, you don't receive your abilities twice; instead you receive each ability once but most will have their power increased in some way. This is noted in the "Double Down" sidebar at the end of the Archetype. These extra benefits only last while both Archetypes match. When you Specialize your Secondary, if you're not Doubling Down again, you will need to forfiet an ability at that point.

Specialist Archetypes

These represent a more focused version of the Generalist Archetypes.

They’re more expensive but come with additional powers. When you purchase a Specialist Archetype, it replaces the Generalist Archetype of the same type except with GM permission. So, for instance, if you’re an Expert, you can replace it with the Ranger or the Thief.

Purchasing Specialist Archetypes

At 1st level and at every level up, you can purchase a Specialist Archetype which replaces your Generalist Archetypes. If at 1st level, see the Specialist Archetypes at 1st Level sidebar below.

You can replace one or both at each level, in either order, barring double-down Weird-Adepts who have to specialize both at the same time into the same Specialist Archetype.

If you do choose to specialize just one of your Generalist Archetypes when you're Double-Downed, you lose the Double-Down benefits.

You can also choose to replace neither if it doesn’t fit your character because once you purchase a Specialist Archetype, you are stuck with it.

Specialist Archetypes completely replaces everything from the Generalist Archetype they’re replacing though it doesn’t retroactively remove things you’ve already rolled for or free purchases.

So, a Fighter, with a d8 Vitality Die decides, at level 4 to become a Soldier with a Vitality Die of a d6. He doesn’t then reroll all his Vitality Die - from that point forward, he simply uses the d6 instead.

They also gain a free purchase of that Specialist's Main Skill Suite as noted in Step 8 of Chapter 1:Step-by-Step Overview.

You’ll pay an additional 20 CrP for each one you’re replacing regardless of race.

Your GM may choose to reject an Archetype combination based on the fact that the two Archetypes don’t fit together thematically. So, while a Thief/Priest (Beast Covenant) might be really powerful because of the Beast Covenant’s Shape Changing ability, if there’s not a Patron of Thieves and Animals in the campaign world, you’re out of luck.

Remember that if you’re replacing your Secondary Archetype, you’ll still need to select a leveling ability from your new Archetype to remove.

Specialist Archetypes at 1st Level

If you’re more familiar with the game, your playstyle, and which Archetypes suit you, you might consider purchasing your Specialization(s) at 1st level. That’s perfectly fine, but you’ll still need to pay the CrP for both the Generalist and the Specialist.

You’re considered to have purchased your Generalist Archetype first AND THEN purchased your Specialist, which means that you still get any free stuff from abilities that say "at first level" from your Generalist, so Experts get some free skills and Weird-Adepts get their starting Rudiments.

Your Primary Specialist’s Primary Drawback also replaces your Primary Generalist’s.

Generalist Archetypes

Expert

Choose this Archetype if you want to use your wits to defeat your opponent or avoid combat altogether.

Experts are those that focus on real-world non-combat skills, as opposed to relying on the Divines, magic, or their sword arm as a source of strength. They tend to rely on Intellect and Willpower, primarily, though there are Experts that focus on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution for more physical skills.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suites Two Different non-Combat Suites of your Choice

Archetype Abilities

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All non-Combat Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

*Skill Focus (Chosen Skill Suite 1, 5) At every odd level, including the first, Experts receive 5 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the first Skill Suite you chose. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different skill focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the character.

*Skill Focus (Chosen Skill Suite 2, 5) At every odd level, including the first, Experts receive 5 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the second Skill Suite you chose. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different skill focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the character.

*Skill Focus (Chosen Skill Suite 3, 5) At every 3rd level, including the first, Experts receive 5 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from a third Skill Suite you chose that must be different from the first two. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different skill focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the character.

Primary Drawback

None

Expert Double Down

Main Skill Suite

Experts can choose 4 different non-Combat Skill Suites when calculating their starting Ranks, however, the fourth Skill Suites chosen don't get Skill Focuses and don't confer any additional bonuses.

Skill Adept

All non-Combat Advanced Skills are reduced by 3 CrP and you gain a 30% discount to non-Combat Skill Suites.

Skill Focuses

The first two you get these every level up, instead of every other. The third you get every odd level, including the first.

Fighter

Choose this Archetype if you want to kill monsters and worthy foes in mortal combat and like thinking on your feet.

War is a ladder by which capable people are able to climb the ranks of society. Fighters focus on combat and battle, either by training and discipline or by out maneuvering their opponent. Unsurprisingly, this Archetype focuses on Constitution, but how you approach combat may decide whether you favor Strength, Dexterity, or even Intellect or Willpower.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Athletics or Strategy

Archetype Abilities

*Martial Focus (Chosen Combat Skill Suite 1) A Fighter picks things up as they go, otherwise, they get themselves and their companions killed. At first level, the Fighter receives 2 free purchases of the first Combat Skill Suite chosen at 1st level and at every odd level, not including the first, the Fighter receives an additional free purchase of the first Combat Skill Suites chosen at 1st level. This must be different than your second chosen Combat Skill Suite.

*Martial Focus (Chosen Combat Skill Suite 2) A Fighter picks things up as they go, otherwise, they get themselves and their companions killed. At first level and every 3rd level after that, the Fighter receives 1 free purchase of the second Combat Skill Suites chosen at 1st level. This must be different than your first chosen Combat Skill Suite.

*Martial Focus (Any Combat Advanced Skill, 2) At every odd level, including the first, Fighters receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Combat Skills you chose. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

None

Fighter Double Down

Martial Adept

All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 3 CrP. They also gain a 30% discount to all Combat Skill Suites.

Martial Focuses (Chosen Skill Suites 1)

This increases to 3 free purchases at first level.

Martial Focuses (Chosen Skill Suite 2)

You gain 2 free purchases at first level and an additional purchase every odd level, not including the first.

Martial Focuses (Any Combat Advanced Skill, 2)

This increases to every level.

Servant

Choose this Archetype if you want harness powers beyond the mortal realm to alter the battlefield and circumstances to your favor.

Servants represent those that have devoted themselves to higher causes, lifting their eyes from the Middle Realm to a more pure order, whether that’s the Divines, the Ancestral Spirits, or the Bones of Ymir. Servants play the best with others, often modifying the other Archetype’s powers with Divine assistance.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suites Trades and Lore

Servants get 3 free purchases of the Religion Advanced Skill for free.

Archetype Abilities

*Called & Chosen A Servant seeks to do the will of those who sent them, furthering their agendas in the Middle Realm and so they are blessed. They add their total level to their Max Favor.

Simple Faith A Servant that's not been initiated into the deeper mysteries of their cult harbors a faith that is simple and pure before their patrons. At every level after the first, they gain a permanent +1 to their Max Favor. Unlike Called & Chosen, this bonus isn't removed when the Servant Specializes, although it no longer grows.

Depths Of Devotion A Servant understand the bonds of giving your life to a cause greater than your own and its strengths. They gain a free Devotion to their Divine, starting at 3. They also start Anointed in their cult.

*Former Life A Servant can be called from anywhere and any walk of life. Select any Archetype ability; This can be from a Generalist or a Specialist Archetype. Former Life has all the same effects as that ability, though it still counts as a separate leveling ability

This ability is still removed when you specialize the Servant Generalist Archetype, however, if it gave any permanent bonuses (like Ranks in a Skill), those stay with you as normal.

Symbol Of Faith As part of their initiation, the Servant receives a holy symbol of their faith. This symbol doesn't help channel their holy power but does help them keep the faith. When brought into a Confrontation that relates question their faith or going against their cult's tenets, they receive their Grit Dice instead of the standard d6!.

*Breath of Knowledge A Servant is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Servants get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

None

Socialite

Choose this Archetype if you want to talk your way out of problems and inspire others to give you your way.

Socialites are people people. They seem to get a real kick out of interacting with others, especially if it ends with them getting their way. While others' first weapons are swords, a Socialite's first weapon is their charm. Unsurprisingly, Socialites tend to rely on Intellect and Presence.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suites Streetwise and Trades

Archetype Abilities

Animal Magnetism Socialites, regardless of their personalities, have a surety that goes beyond what people can see on the surface and it makes them very persuasive. At first level, Socialites gain 5 additional "Conviction Points" (see Chapter 1.1: Step-by-Step Overview) that they can put in Convictions. They have to be spent before the end of character creation.

Identity Focus (Characteristic 1) As a Socialite grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At first level, they select 1 of the following: Conviction, Devotion, or Description

Conviction: at every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of two different Convictions by 1 or gain a new Conviction at Rank 0.

Devotion: at every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of one Devotion by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

Description at every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of one of your Descriptions by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Identity Focus (Characteristic 2) As a Socialite grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At first level, they select 1 of the following: Conviction, Devotion, or Description.

Conviction: at every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

Devotion: at every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of one Devotion by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

Description: Every 3rd level, starting with the first, you can increase the Rank of one of your Descriptions by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Resilient Spirit A Socialite is able to withstand even the most dire of pressures: after all, if one can survive a party, one can survive basically anything. At every level, including the first, the Socialite permanently increases their Stress Threshold by 2.

Work On Your Personality A Socialite knows that time spent on your personality is never wasted. When purchasing Characteristics with CrP, the Socialite receives a 4 CrP discount.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 2) Through the course of her career, a Socialite develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 2 free purchases of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

None

Socialite Double Down

Animal Magnetism

You start with an extra 10 Conviction Points instead of 5.

Identity Focus (major Characteristic)

Conviction is changed to 2 different Convictions by 2 Ranks, gain 2 new Convictions, or 1 Conviction by 2 Ranks and 1 new Conviction.

Devotion is changed to 2 Devotions by 1 Rank, 1 Devotion by 2 Ranks, or 1 new Devotion every level.

Description is changed to every level. Saving gives you a new Description every odd level, not including the first.

Identity Focus (minor Characteristic)

Conviction is changed to 2 different Convictions by 1 Rank, 1 Conviction by 2 Ranks, or 1 new Conviction every level.

Devotion is changed to every level or a new Devotion every odd level after the first.

Description is changed to every odd level, including the first or a new Description every other odd level after the first.

Resilient Spirit

The bonus is increased to 4, instead of 2.

Skill Focus

The Socialite receives 4 purchases each level, instead of 2.

Weird-adept

Choose this Archetype if you want an eclectic set of powers that you can apply to most situations in a creative manner but may not be helpful for all problems.

Though much study and/or natural talent, Weird-Adepts can channel the Painted World, using its power to alter reality. Weird-Adepts rely more on clever applications of spells rather than outright doing damage and so can often subtly shift the playing field in their favor. They rely mainly on Intellect and Willpower since they need a high Stress Threshold as it is extremely stressful to shape Weird.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Weirdcraft twice

Archetype Abilities

Applied Folkweird While anyone can shape a simple cantrip, the Weird-Adepts knows how to apply those lessons to shape a real spell. After 10 seconds of light concentration (they can move up to a Jog and make Checks, although they do so on a d10!, including Attack and Defense Checks) with at least 1 hand free and the ability to speak, the Weird-Adept generates a number of Spell Points equal to their Level + Weirdcraft Skill Suite Rank or the applicable Weirdcraft Advanced Skill's Rank which must be immediately spent to shape a spell.

Any SP remaining after the initial Shaping of a spell becomes fixed within it; these may only be used to extend its Interval per the normal rules, and each spell tracks its SP separately. The Weird-Adept can begin concentrating to gather more SP immediately after Shaping a spell, but these new SP can only be used to Shape a new spell, not added to an existing one.

Should the Weird-Adept not be able to get enough SP to even get 1 Interval, they can take Stress equal to the SP they're missing in Weirdburn to get at least 1 Interval of the spell up and running.

Bending reality and shaping primordial force is not an easy thing to do and nature doesn’t like it. When they first shape a spell, they take 1 Stress for every 10 Drain (rounded up) the spell has +5 for every Category above Never that their Fatigue Threshold is at (5 for Critical, 10 for Wounded, 15 for Bloodied, etc.). This is a one-time cost so continuing to shape the same spell doesn't further Stress them out (as long as they don't suffer weirdburn, of course).

Rionhuld is a Weird-Adept/Fighter with a Weirdcraft of 4 and an Animism of 7. He goes to shape the Weaponsharp Spell in preparation for battle. He’s 6 seconds into the 10 second wait time when they’re attacked. He manages to dodge the outlaw’s blade, even defending on a d10! and, 4 seconds later, his spell takes form.

Because Weaponsharp is an Investiture spell, he gets 7 SP to shape with, so he picks the Circle and Burst Rudiments, giving it a drain of 6.

The spell takes effect, he takes 6 Stress from the fallout (since his Fatigue is Critical) and immediately begins shaping again, this time, he goes for Haste. After 10 seconds, he gets 4 SP because he doesn’t have the Animism Advanced Skill so uses his Weirdcraft Skill Suite Rank. He goes for Personal and Aura but he doesn’t have the SP to cover that entirely so Weirdburns for the difference. This gives him 13 Stress (7 from the Weirdburn and 6 from normal fallout).

Note that Rionhuld can’t add those 4 SP to the Weaponsharp already shaped: he needs to put it towards a new spell.

Rudimentary Knowledge Weird-Adepts know the basics of shaping the Weird and so start out with 5 random Rudiments. They gain a new one every 3 levels after that.

*Skill Focus (Weirdcraft Skill Suite) At every odd level, including the first, Weird-Adept receives 1 free purchase of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite.

*Skill Focus (Weirdcraft, 2) At every odd level, including the first, Weird-Adept receives 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Weirdcraft Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different skill focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the character.

Primary Drawback

None

Weird-Adept Double Down

Rudimentary Knowledge

Start with 9 Rudiments, with 2 being your choices and the rest random. Gain a new one every other level.

Applied Folkweird

Shape after 7 seconds of concentration and gain SPs equal to twice your level + Weirdcraft Skill Suite Rank or the applicable Weirdcraft Advanced Skill's Rank.

Skill Focuses

You get these are every level up, instead of every other.

Acquiring Rudiments

At 1st level and as dictated by your Archetypes, you’ll have the opportunity to acquire new Rudiments, which you can then use to shape spells. You’ll do so by picking a Rudiment table and then rolling on it. If you roll a Rudiment you already have, you can reroll for free until a new one comes up. For Effects, you roll on the Effects Rudiments table and then go to the corresponding sub-table.

On all tables, you can modify your roll by up to 1 for every 3 Ranks of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite you have. This does wrap around so, if you have Weirdcraft of 9 and roll a 11 on the Animism Effects Table, you can choose any Rudiment between 8 and 2. You may also spend 1 CrP to reroll any of the tables, even during level up.

Players that seek out the knowledge to gain a specific Rudiment during play can forgo this roll and simply gain that Rudiment.

At first level, it is required that you have at least 1 Rudiment from each type (so, 1 Shape Rudiment, 1 Origin Rudiment, and so on) but once that’s satisfied, they can go back.

You can also purchase additional Rudiments for 30 CrP a pop, although, if that's the case, you get to choose the Rudiment.

Shape Rudiments
Roll (d8)
1 Circle
2 Chain
3 Cone
4 Personal
5 Salvo
6 Sphere
7 Ray
8 Wall
Origin Rudiments
Roll (d6)
1 Aura
2 Touch
3 Burst
4 - 5 Near
6 Far
Effects Rudiments
Roll (d8)
1 Animism
2 Calling
3 Charm
4 Glamour
5 Investiture
6 Occult
7 Sortilege
8 Reroll

Roll on this the Effects Rudiments table to determine which Effects Table to roll on. If you have a Rank in a Weirdcraft Advanced Skill in a specific Tradition, you can skip the Effects Rudiments table and go straight to rolling on any table you have training in.

Animism Effects
Roll (d12)

2 Bestial Sight
3 Corpse Hide
4 Endow with Power

6 High Jump

9 Outcry

12 Stitch Flesh

4 Corpse Tongue

Expert Specialist Archetypes

Adventurer

Choose this Archetype if you want a good range of skills and be able to help others in Skill Challenges.

Adventures gain the most free skills of all Archetypes allowing for the largest breath of knowledge, however, they’re cheaper skills. They can also help others, giving them a chance to try again at Skill Checks they fail.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suites Two Different, non-Lore, non-Combat Skill Suites

Archetype Abilities
