*Helping Hand The Adventurer is not just about knowing things but also giving others a helping hand in times of need. When another person uses an Adventurer’s help, either as an Asset, or via him Helping Out or Preparation, they receive an additional +1 to their roll at every odd level, including the first.

Middle Name: Danger For the Adventurer, danger is calming and straightforward and that’s what they crave. Whenever an Adventurer takes damage, they can heal half that amount in Stress, rounded up.

*Outthinking While they may not be the best with the blade, the Adventurer is often able to beat their opponents by outthinking them. Gain a use of your Grit Dice whenever you use a Str-, Con-, or Dex-based Skill that affects a combat, regardless of whether or not it's successful. Gain an additional one for every 3 levels after that.

Skill Focus (Any < 7 CrP, 7) At every level, including first, Adventurers receive 7 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any non-combat Advanced Skills under 7 CrP in base cost (before Skill Adept). These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All non-Combat Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Adventurers tend to eschew book smarts for street smarts: the Lore Skill Suite and any Lore Advanced Skills cost double if he's purchasing them (so he can still pick up Lore Skills under 7 CrP as part of his Skill Focus).

Assassin

Choose this Archetype if you want to dispatch unaware opponents quickly, either by stabbing your target in the back, by poisoning them, or by slitting their throats.

The Assassin is a master killer, gaining a chance to increase their damage against unaware opponents and being able silence helpless ones quickly. They're also masters of poison use, knowing how to most effectively apply their killer medicine.

Vitality

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Streetwise

Archetype Abilities

*Backstab When using any small melee weapon against an unaware target (one that is either not aware of your presence or one that is unaware that you, personally, mean harm to them), the Assassin’s weappon's base damage explodes on the highest and second highest result, except for d2!s. i.e., d4!s explode on natural 3s and 4s. They also gain an additional dice of damage at every odd level, including the first, when backstabbing, which doesn’t increase the total number of dice for /D armor but isn't affected by anything that would otherwise increase the weapon's damage.

The backstab is a tactic of precision and so can't be paired with Combat Tactics but can be paired with Skill Challenge Tactics.

If an opponent flees and the Assassin is within half their weapon Recovery, they may Backstab using half their additional damage dice from this ability, rounded up. This, however, he can do with any weapon (although he'll need to snapshot his attack if using a ranged weapon unless he attacks the same second they flee).

Silent Takedown If an Assassin attacks an unaware opponent with any weapon and beat his victim's defense by more than 10, the attack has the opportunity to be silent. If the victim fails their Trauma check, they simply keel over quietly its duration, after which, they can get up and start yelling (should the Assassin have left them alive).

If, however, the Assassin beats their defense by 10 but their victim succeeds at their Trauma check, the Assassin has still managed to silence them for 3d6! seconds, however their victim isn't helpless and can otherwise act normally.

Improved Coup De Grace An Assassin has studied the weak parts of their target’s anatomy and can quickly make a killer strike. Coup de Graces only take 5 seconds. This is always done completely silent.

Cool Headed Where others would get blustered, the Assassin stays cool, even when he’s stressing. When making a Skill Check, lower the base amount of Stress you get by 1.

*Skilled Poisoner An Assassin has intimate knowledge of poisons and how to use them. When someone is poisoned by the Assassin, increase that poison's Lethality by 1 for every level, including the first, that Assassion has obtained.

If the first roll against the poison is greater than 10, the poison has been so artfully placed that it also silences the victim, only a success allows them to cry out.

*Friends in Dark Places An Assassin has connections that others don't, making poisons and tools of their trade more easily available. An assassin gains an NPC contact that allows them to buy poisons and toxics as if they were one price category closer, down to Source, but only if they has access to them. This NPC needs a name, one or two word personality, how they came to know the assassin, and where they're stationed. They act as a Poor Knowledge and Poor Organization Contact unless additional Contact Points are spent or their usablity is increased through play.

If this contact dies or the assassin moves areas, they can create a new hookup at level up, although this doesn't count as a leveling ability.

Primary Drawback

Being a trained killer is not an honorable profession and people don’t like murders around. If your profession becomes publicly known, you lose 5 Integrity.

Mastermind

Choose this Archetype if you want to beat Skill Challenges more through use of Tactics rather than raw Ranks in a Skill.

The Mastermind is a plotter: preparing themselves and laying out plans before they step foot into the Skill Challenge. They get bonuses for utilizing all the options presented in the Tactics section, meaning that, by the time they step into the ring, they’re unbeatable in their element.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite One non-Combat Suite of your Choice

Archetype Abilities

*Active Listener A Mastermind has contacts and knows how to use them. When using an Asset, the Mastermind gains a bonus to their roll equal to their level.

Manage Minions Any Mastermind worth his salt will keep a stable of minions around to help him out, even if they're the other players. When he uses one of their Skills, or vice versa, via Helping Out, all Stress gain is halved for everyone. This doesn't affect Stress from Complications or Failures, however.

Prep Pays Off People take pride in having their plans work out, the Mastermind doubly so. Whenever a reroll from a non-Asset Preparation results in a success when the original roll would have caused a failure, the Mastermind receives 1 free use of their Grit Die for the rest of the Skill Challenge.

*The Right Tool For The Right Time If you’re careful with how you treat your equipment and come prepared, you can see yourself through a tough spot. Once per Skill Challenge ignore the degradation of a piece of equipment you use on a Check. You can do this an additional time for every 2 levels after that.

Skill Focus (Any, 3) At every level, including the first, Masterminds receive 3 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Failure means that the Mastermind didn’t plan as well as he should have. He gains an additional 2d6! Stress at the end of any Skill Challenge for each Obstacle that he fails, even if he got what he wanted out of the Challenge.

Opportunist

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a lucky character who can alter the unexpected to be in his favor.

There’s just something about these types of people that seem to warp probability in their favor. And those lucky few who use this to their advantage to go far.

Vitality Die

At first level: the higher of 2d4. All other levels: d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite According to your Secondary Archetype

Archetype Abilities

Lucky The Opportunist is naturally blessed with the ability to get out of trouble and use that adrenaline that comes as death comes near to dodge the grim reaper and keep running. After the results are given, the Opportunist can take 2 Stress to modify his results by 1. These may be done with the following conditions:

🜂

They can never be used to make you a better fighter. Stress gained this way can only be used to dodge death or escape a bad situation but never to make your character a superman.

🜂

The character must think of a situation that saves his rear end, something that happens to him that’s to his advantage.

The key here is that it can’t be impossible but it can be highly improbable. The chandelier rope breaking right at that moment separating him from a blood thirsty guard, a pigeon flying across an archer’s view intercepting an arrow, etc. are all acceptable.

It can’t be the result of skill. Him deflecting the blade with his hand like a badass is right out.

Should the character be unable to think of a scenario that fits both of these criteria, he’s unable to gain Stress to save himself.

*Fail Forward Some people seem to stumble into where they need to be, even when they completely fail. When the Opportunist fails an Obstacle, drops a Wound Category, or concedes a point, he gains a roll of his Grit Dice. At first level, he can only have 1 of these types of Grit Die at one time but this limit is increased by 1 for every 3 levels after.

*No Worries When things go bad, sometimes it's enough to remind yourself that they can't go back forward. Whenever the Opportunist fails a Check, they take 2 less Stress. This increases by 1 every odd level, not including the first.

*Natural Advantage An Opportunist lives on his wits and his ability to use every advantage. At the start of every Combat, Confrontation, or Skill Challenge, he may change one thing about the field for every 5 Stress he takes. These changes must be consistent with an overarching setting (he can’t choose to have the inn change to a ship or flood right at that moment but he can choose to have a convenient chair or barrel right behind one of his enemies or reposition himself next to the fighter).

This Stress is lowered by 1 every odd level, not including the first, down to 3, though he may use this ability multiple times.

Primary Drawback

Luck is a top-heavy thing: Opportunists don't get their Min Vitality or Min Stress when they roll their Vitality and Stress increases.

Professional

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a character that gets stronger as they fail to overcome Obstacles.

While other Experts focus on knowledge, the Professional focuses on when to apply that knowledge and how to use their time effectively. The work with the Clocks of the Skill Challenge primarily, rather than being just good at Skill Checks.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite One non-Combat Suite of your Choice

Archetype Abilities

*Friends in All Places The Professional has a vast array of contacts that only grow as they become more experienced. When a Professional levels up, they gain a number of additional Unredeemed Contacts equal to their level.

They can also call on their network when entering a new area: when they travel to a town, city, or region that's more than a day's travel away, they also gain a number of additional Unredeemed Contacts equal to their level, however these Unredeemed Contacts are locked to that area: they're non-transferrable.

Tinker's Talent A Professional knows how to take good care for their equipment and so it lasts far longer than it otherwise would. A Professional can make two Maintenance Checks between gaining Wear, where others can only make one Check.

*Watching Each Other’s Back Whenever one does their job, everyone can rest easy. If you and at least one ally are Multitasking, each person gets a +1 to one of their rolls. This bonus is increased at every odd level after that.

Skill Focus (Any, 3) At every odd level, including the first, Professionals receive 3 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

Primary Drawback

The Professional is a man of reputation and so, when it is besmirched, it affects him gravely. For every 5 Integrity you lose or spend, lose an additional 1.

Ranger

Choose this Archetype if you want to have a good range of survival skills, use your team to overcome Obstacles, but also move quicker on and off the battlefield.

The Ranger’s strengths rely mostly in their survival skills, making them excellent to have in the wilderness but they also gain a bonus to their movement that allows them to out-pace others during skirmishes.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Survival

Archetypes Abilities

*Quick Footed The Ranger relies on being able to cross great swaths of land quickly, chasing down their prey. At every odd level, including the first, the Ranger increases his base movement rate categories by 1 foot + 1 per Movement Category above a Crawl. He can't increase it again until all other movement categories have been increased in a similar manner.

The Ranger also gains a +1 to their ranged defenses for every 10 ft of additional movement they have.

For example, a first-level, human Ranger can choose Crawling, Walking, Jogging, Running, Sprinting. If he chooses Walking, his Walk becomes 7 ft / second (because it is +2 since Walk is 1 Movement Category above Crawl). At level 3, he can choose Crawling, Jogging, Running, or Sprinting, but not Walking. If he chooses Running, his Running speed becomes 19 ft / second (since Running is 3 Categories above Crawl, adding that base +1).

After he's increased all, he can go back and increase his Walk again.

Put Your Heads Together For survival, communication is key and doing so quickly is often extremely important. When using each other as Assets, all allies of the Ranger have their Organization considered 1 better.

*Hiking Conditioning A Ranger is used to running and jumping for hours on end with equipment on their back so gain a +1S to their Carry every odd level, including the first.

Skill Focus (Survival, 5) At every level, including the first, Rangers receive 5 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Survival Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different skill focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All non-Combat Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

Primary Drawback

A Ranger finds armor restricting and irritating: all Armor Advanced Skills are 2 CrP more expensive and the Armor Skill Suite is 10 CrP more expensive.

Sage

Choose this Archetype if you want to play an extremely knowledge person as well as use that knowledge to give bonuses to your company.

The Sage gets some of the most expensive and cerebral skills for free but also, because of his intense training, he has the ability to instantly reroll any skill he chooses.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suites Lore Twice

Archetype Abilities

*Memory TrainingThe Sage’s training doesn’t just revolve around studying but also on how to study, allowing them better recall of information than those without such mental discipline. The Sage may reroll 1 Int, Wis, or Pres based Skill Check for 7 Stress. They lower this Stress gain by 1 every 3 levels after that, down to 3.

*Frank Discussion You can often get more out of a discussion than you can simply thinking about something. When used as an Asset, the person receives a +1 to their Skill Check. This bonus is increased by +1 every odd level after that.

Skill Focus (Lore, 5) At every level, including the first, Sages receive 5 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill from the Lore Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All non-Combat Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

Primary Drawback

The Sage has spent most of his time buried in study and so may take a bit longer to react to reality: they always roll an initiative die 1 size larger.

Thief

Choose this Archetype if you want to play an expert in stealth and intelligence gathering.

The Thief has the widest variety of skills, picking from a uniquely built suite, rather than a predetermined one on top of their other free skills.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Streetwise

Thieves receive 3 free purchases of Language (Thieves Cant).

Archetype Abilities

Thief’s Training At every odd level, including the first, the Thief receives 4 free purchases in Advanced Skill from the list found below. This can be doubled up into a single skill or spread between any number of them.

- Any 1 Selected At 1st Level (cannot be selected multiple times / level)
- Appraisal (Specific)
- Law (Culture)
- Climbing
- Move Silently
- Escape Artist
- Scavenging
- Hiding

*Brother/sisterhood When you know others have your back and you have theirs, it’s much easier to keep your calm. Every ally who is within shouting distance of the thief increases their Stress Threshold by 5. This bonus increases by 1 every odd level after that. The Thief also gains this bonus when another ally is within shouting distance as well.

*Skill Focus (Streetwise, 3) At every level, including the first, Thieves receive 3 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill from the Streetwise Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different skill focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All non-Combat Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Thieving is not an honorable profession. A Thief loses 5 Integrity should their profession become publicly known.

Wilderman

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a pioneer or trapper, raised by wild animals but with a kinship to the same.

The Wilderman is a savage by most standards. They tend to be those raised in the wild by feral creatures, or those mountain men that retreated to the frontier so long ago that they’ve lost the rounded edges that civilization originally bestowed on them.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Survival Twice

Archetype Abilities

Animal Affinity The Wilderman has a natural connection to the beasts. As such, he can form bonds with them quicker than humans. A Wilderman can use one of his followers at any time to attract an environmentally appropriate animal companion instead determined by the GM.

*Environmental Conditioning Being outside in all seasons and weather, hardens the Wilderman. He take 1 less damage and Stress from weather. This bonus is increased by 1 every odd level after that.

One Pack The Wilderman knows that you either survive together or die separately. Anyone can use anyone else’s Grit Dice (with the owner's permission). The Grit Dice uses the Grit Dice size of the person redeeming it and it is affected by any abilities that person has, however the person redeeming the die takes 2 Stress each time and it doesn't work on Grit Dice gained through Favor.

Animal Friend Being around animals allows you to really get in their head and communicate with them on a level that civilized people just can't. This ability allows the Wilderman to get into a Confrontation with any Natural Animals to move their disposition from Hostile to Neutral or from Neutral to Friendly, though not from Hostile to Neutral in one Confrontation. This is only temporary, however, ending a few hours after first contact.

*Savage Man In A Savage Land A Wilderman is used to fighting in all conditions, good or bad. They gain a +1 to their Checks when they're suffering from penalties from terrain or weather. This bonus is increased by 1 every odd level after that.

Skill Focus (Survival Skill Suite) At every level, including the first, Wildermen receive a free purchase in the Survival Skill Suite.

Primary Drawback

A Wilderman finds no comfort in society and they often find themselves ill-at-ease in the company of others: all races are considered 2 steps down the Racial Preference table.

Fighter Specialist Archetypes

Barbarian

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a cunning fighter that uses combat Tactics to best your opponent, rather than raw skill.

“Barbarian” is often a derogatory term used by people who consider themselves civilized but the truth is that the Barbarian is a title of honor. The Barbarian is a survivor and survives on wit, rather than raw power.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Survival

Archetype Abilities

Advanced Tactics A Barbarian is a skirmisher and doesn’t rely on formalized training methods like other fighters. As such, their greatest strength is the utilization of Tactics. At every odd level, including the first, a Barbarian can increase the bonus or lower the penalty for a Tactic by 1, though they can never make a penalty a bonus nor go beyond double a bonus’s original amount. So, the max you can get the Feint to is +10 to Attack and +0 to your Defense.

This doesn't remove requirements (such as moving) or special penalties (such as dealing half damage while Feinting against people who Step Back or Retreat).

Tribal Weaponry Trained from birth with tribal weapons, the Barbarian thinks of the disparate weapons of their culture as one.

At 1st level, the Barbarian picks a 2 handed weapon, a ranged weapon, and a small weapon. These weapons are considered their own “Tribal Weaponry” weapon category for the Melee Weapon Skill Suite (even if they’re ranged).

They may purchase Advanced Skills for them like any other weapon category.

*Constant Vigilance Pay attention or end up as monster chow. The Barbarian and their allies receive a -1 to their Initiative. This bonus is increased by 1 every 4 levels after 1st.

*Hiking Conditioning A Barbarian is used to running and jumping for hours on end with equipment on their back so gain a +1S to their Carry every odd level, including the first.

*Martial Focus (Tribal Weaponry, 4) At every level, including the first, Barbarians receive 4 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Combat Skills that would apply to their tribal weaponry. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Barbarians haven’t benefited fully from the learning of more advanced civilizations. All Skills with Int as a relevant ability cost 2 CrP more.

Berserker

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a warrior that charges into battle and gets stronger the more wounded they become.

The Berserker is a child of war, often raised from an early age in the most punishing conditions to harden them. In battle they fly into a primal rage, craving through enemies like warm butter.

Vitality Die

At first level: the higher of 2d8. All other levels: d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Athletics

Archetype Abilities

*Pain Tolerant The Berserker has learned to simply overpower his pain sensors and keep fighting. At 1st level, he gains a + 3 bonus to his Trauma check. This increased by 1 every odd level after that.

Aggressive Fighter The Berserker never backs down. In a Morale Confrontation, they can never be forced to take a defensive action.

*Scarification For every battle and victim, the Berserker scars himself to commemorate his victory. Over time, these scars serve as armor as his skin hardens. The Berserker gains 1 DR at first level and every 4 levels after. This ability does stack with armor but the scars chaff and rub, so double any penalties gained from wearing it.

This scarification is unsettling to look upon. The Berserker also gains a Description “Intimidating Presence” at Rank 3 because of them. This is separate from the Description “Battle Scars”.

Battle Frenzy These warriors are able to drive themselves into a crazed frenzy, giving them almost supernatural abilities. While in a Battle Frenzy, the Berserker doubles his bonuses from Pain Tolerant and Scarification and makes them temporarily immune to Fatigue.

The DR granted from Scarification also applies to the damage dealt by Running and Sprinting, however, it is effectively halved for Sprinting.

On top of this, whenever they kill an opponent, they heal an amount of damage equal to the amount under 0 he puts them. So, a Berserker deals 10 damage to a person with 6 Vitality left, bringing the enemy to -4 and healing the Berserker 4 Vitality.

The Battle Frenzy increases as the warrior nears death. When a Berserker is Hurt they gain an additional dice of damage equal to their Grit Die and when Wounded they gain another. This doesn't increase the effective dice number.

There are drawbacks to the Frenzy. The first is that the Berserker can take no defensive actions. This includes any defensive Tactics but also prevents him from actively crouching behind his shield for cover and, when doing aggressive actions, they are less careful, doubling their penalties from the same. Additionally, there is a price to pay for driving your body for so long; when you drop out of the Frenzy, you take 2d6! damage, on one Wound.

This Frenzy is awoken by the Berserker and takes 3d6 seconds to get into, during which time the Berserker beats his chest, screams at the sky, and just generally psyches himself up. The more wounded the Berserker becomes, however, the easier it is to get into the right frame of mind, so remove a d6 for every Wound Category he has dropped.

*Shared Frenzy Some of the manic power the Berserker commands overflows and invigorates his allies. Those on the Berserker’s side can Run for an additional 3 seconds per Berserker level, including the first, and can Sprint an additional 1 second per Berserker level, including the first, without taking damage or increasing that Running and Sprinting damage dice.

*Martial Focus (Melee Weapons, 2) At every level, including the first, Berserkers receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Melee Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Berserkers are killers and can sometimes get lost in the glory of battle. After downing every foe on the battlefield, they need to make a Willpower check. On a failure, they’re unable to calm down and attack the nearest person, friendly or not. After every attack they make, they can make another Wis check to try and snap out of it. Failure indicates they keep attacking.

Brawler

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a street brawler that can grab, disarm, shift, and trip your opponent to your heart's pleasure.

On the streets or in the arena, you’ll find the Brawler, battling it out. For the joy of throwing their opponents around like a rag doll, they fight. Brawlers are unarmed fighters primarily, eager to toss anyone that opposes them aside.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Streetwise

Archetype Abilities

*Registered Weapons The Brawler knows how to appear like a threat, even when unarmed. They always count as having a weapon for Weapon Style.

Opportunistic Fighter Part of being a streetfighter is seizing every chance you get to get ahead. A Brawler and his allies score a Near Perfect Attack and Defense on a roll of 18 and 19.

*Immovable By planting yourself and watching your structure, you can really push people around. You gain a bonus to your effective Vitality Size Modifier for Knock-Backs equal to your level. On top of this, you also lower your enemy's Vitality Size Modifier for Knock-Backs by half your level as well, down to a minimum of 5.

*Martial Focus (Unarmed, 4) At every level, including the first, Brawlers receive 4 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Unarmed Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Something about being a Brawler makes them shun weapons where they can’t get up and personal with their opponent. The Ranged Weapon Combat Skill Suite’s Advanced Skills cost 2 CrP more.

Cateran

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a fighter that flanks their opponent, keeping them from moving or engaging others in combat.

The Cateran is all about flanking your opponent and keeping other fighters locked down. As such, they work best with other fighters.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy Twice

Archetype Abilities

Baby-sitting While an individual Cateran may vary in his ability to take care of infants, they all share the ability to keep combatants locked down.

Whenever a person engaged with the Cateran tries to disengage, the Cateran gets an immediate free attack that, if it hits, deals half damage. This happens regardless of where they are on the Clock and doesn’t affect when their next attack happens.

Closed Openings Flanking is the art of dividing people’s attention and the Cateran has perfected that art. Anyone flanked by a Cateran lowers their attack die by 1 size, regardless of who they’re attacking.

*Mutieren A Cateran knows to move their blade to get into places their opponents wouldn't expect. If facing an enemy whose weapon has a base Parry or who is carrying a shield, the Cateran receives a bonus to Attack equal to halve their level, rounded up. This ability isn't effective against people who gained their Parry solely through training.

*Shadowing By keeping close to their opponent, the Cateran can negate people’s defensive posturing. By taking 7 Stress, a Cateran can negate any bonuses an opponent gets from moving, whether that’s shifting, stepping back, or whatever and also stops their opponent from moving.

They lower this Stress gain by 1 every 3 levels after that, down to 3.

Bum Rush A Cateran can also use his allies to more effectively flank their opponents. When flanking from the side, you and your allies lower your target’s defense die by 1, including the dice of those using shields (though they still get a chance to Parry). This doesn’t, however, give you any benefit for attacking from directly behind.

*Martial Focus (Melee Weapons, 2) At first level and every level up, Caterans receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Melee Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

The Cateran is a group fighter and fighting alone can be unnerving for him. When engaged with enemies alone and not flanking, the Cateran is unable to use his Integrity but can still use his Grit Dice.

Man-at-arms

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone who uses their Skills to gain even greater bonuses against their opponents.

The Man-at-Arms uses his own know-how against his opponents. She gets more deadly the more Advanced Combat Skills she gains. With this she can adapt to who she is fighting where others can’t.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Athletics

Archetype Abilities

Know Your Enemy A Man-at-Arms is good at watching her foe and exploiting weaknesses.

For every 20 seconds she is either Threatening someone or someone is Threatening her, she gains a cumulative bonus to Attack, Parry, Recovery, or Damage. They get a +1 for each of her Advanced Combat Skills in the weapon, armor, or shield the opponent is using. This stacks.

So, if she is fighting someone using a sword and leather armor and she has Ranks in Attack (Swords) and Damage (Swords) and Defense (Light) and Recovery (Light), she gets a +4 which she can apply to Attack, Parry, Recovery, or Damage.

This bonus can apply to multiple people but the bonus, and what it is applied to, is tracked separately for each. Everything resets should that foe become no longer threaten her.

So, if the Man-At-Arms is Threatening two foes for 20 seconds, she can apply her bonus to attacking one, while the other bonus goes to defending against another. If one she is defending against leaves, she has to continue applying her bonus to attacking the other. Should that foe threaten her again, she gains no bonuses against him but can change to attacking him as well.

The time this bonus takes to accrue is lowered 1 second for every level after the first, down to a minimum 1 second.

Monster Attacks & Defenses

While it doesn't make sense under normal circumstances for a person to take the Advanced Melee Skill (Attack, Claws), Tacticians can hugely benefit from learning about different types of monster attacks and so might be interested in picking up these more niche Skills.

In this case, the Melee (or Ranged) Combat Skills are related to specific types of attacks - claws, bite, divebomb, constrict, etc. - while the Armor Combat Skills relate to the type of hide - feathers, fur, extra-thick, chitin, etc.. If you're not sure, talk to your GM.

Counting Coup Part of being a Man-at-Arms is keeping a reputation for your skill in combat and this can often become a game that everyone gets caught up in. If you give yourself a penalty to Attack, you gain 1 Integrity and gain Relaxation equal to that penalty if you score a hit. If you've already used this ability once this Combat, your allies may do so as well, gaining an additional point of Relaxation (but not Integrity) for each teammate (or Tactician) who's successfully counted coup before them.

*Martial Focus (Any Combat Skill Suite, 2) At every level, including the first, Man-at-Arms receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from any Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Men-at-Arms fight and when they lose, it’s hard on them: they lose 5 Integrity for every combat they’re knocked unconscious or fail a Trauma check in due to humiliation.

Knight

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a heavy armored tank that inspires others to fight hard.

The Knight focuses on shield and armor, and with their larger Vitality Die, they tend to be pretty tanky. Additionally, their Inheritance allows them to get the more expensive weapons for free.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

*Chivalry From their strict code comes a strength and confidence that others can only dream of and envy. For the duration of a combat, you gain a number of Grit Dice equal to your level. You can only apply 1 of these bonus Grit Die to a single roll, though that doesn’t stop you adding Grit Dice that you’ve gotten from other sources.

*Call To Valor A Knight is a hero and inspires others to rise above. For the duration of a combat, all allies gain access to a pool of Grit Die equal to the Knight's level. They can only apply one of these bonus Grit Dice to a single roll, though that doesn’t stop them adding Grit Dice that they got from other sources. The Grit Dice is the size of the person’s Grit Dice that redeems it.

Inheritance This character may have had an extra leg up in life, allowing them the opportunity to start with better equipment than others. They gain an additional 250 sc that must be spent on one item that represents an heirloom passed down to them. They also gain 15 sc for each CrP cashed in at the end of Character Creation instead of the normal 10.

*Martial Focus (Special, 2) At every level, including the first, Knights receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Armor, Shield, or Melee Combat Skill Suites. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

The Knight is a creature of honor and respects Integrity where they find it. They may be killers, but they have a code, whether articulated or not. A Knight may never use a long-ranged weapon on a foe that has greater than Average Integrity.

Skirmisher

Choose this Archetype if you want to play an extremely mobile guerilla fighter that gains bonuses for ambushing.

Skirmishers never stay in one place longer than they have to and so are rewarded for constantly being on the move. They’re also adept at making the most of their enemies' disorientation, either from surprise or from the chaos they cause.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Athletics

Skirmishers gain 4 free purchases in the Endurance Advanced Skill

Archetype Abilities

Dire Ambush Catching an enemy off guard can spread confusion and disorientation that can limit an enemy’s ability to respond. Whenever the Skirmisher hits a surprised enemy, that enemy receives -2 to Attack and Defense for the next 7 seconds. Additionally, should they move above a Walk during this time, they gain an additional -2 for each Movement Category above such for that duration.

*Combat Ready A Skirmisher is ready to go at any time. They receive a -1 to their Initiative. They increase this bonus by 1 every 3 levels after that.

Attack On The Run Skirmishers have a special gift when it comes to aiming and moving. Instead of lowering their Attack Dice by 2 per Movement Category when using ranged weapons, they lower it by 1 per Movement Category instead.

*Guerilla Fighting Skirmishers are masters at getting in, doing some damage, and getting out, causing confusion as they move.

If someone attacks the Skirmisher while she is at a Jog or higher, or misses an attack when she moves from Engaged to Threatened with someone, the enemy is left open for two seconds. If hit within that window, then the enemy receives a -3 to Attack for 7 seconds + their level.

Raid Tactics Confusion allows the clear-minded to dart in and out, dealing terrible damage. While receiving penalties from the Skirmisher, enemies are unable to capitalize and get no free attacks when someone goes from Engaged to Threatened for them.

*Martial Focus (Ranged Weapons, 3) At every level, including the first, Skirmishers receive 3 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Ranged Weapon Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

The Skirmisher moves and so quickly loses her edge when pinned down. She receives a -2 for every 5 seconds she hasn’t moved at least 5 ft in combat.

Soldier

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a warrior that sticks close to the rest of the company and allows them to adapt more quickly to changing situations.

Bonfire characters are not meant to stand alone, and this goes double for the Soldier, who works the best with others. They’re able to shadow others around the battlefield and really focus on being good at one or two weapons.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

Small Unit Tactics Soldiers work as a team. If they or anyone they’re adjacent (including enemies) uses a tactic that moves them (Shift, Step Back, etc.), the Soldier or their adjacent ally may also use that Tactic or Shift with no penalties.

*Buddy System Soldiers fight as a unit, moving and acting as one where possible. When an adjacent ally switches Tactics, the Soldier may immediately switch to that Tactic as well. On top of this, adjacent allies also receive a bonus to their Trauma Threshold equal to the Soldier’s level.

*Weapon Specialization At first level, the soldier selects 1 weapon. At first level Soldiers receive a +1 to Attack, and Parry and a -0.5 to Recovery and +0.5 to Damage (both rounded up) with that weapon. They increase this bonus by 1 or .5 (depending) for every 4 levels after that.

*Martial Focus (Any Combat Skill Suite, 2) At every level, including the first, Soldiers receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from any Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

A Soldier focuses so much time drilling with his preferred weapon that he can often forget that principles with one weapon can apply to another. All Ranged Weapon and Melee Skill Suites are 15 CrP more expensive.

Tactician

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone that is extremely versatile, being able to switch weapons, weapon styles, and tactics on the fly, as well as gaining a greater benefit from resting.

The Tactician is a jack of all trades but master of none, focusing on being slightly less skilled at a multitude of weapons. This means that the Tactician will probably have the right weapon for the right enemy. On top of this, the Tactician is skilled at the use of Combat Tactics (hence the name) which allows them to seize openings that others can’t. Overall, the Tactician focuses on versatility.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

Quick Or Dead A Tactician lives on his wits. While others rely on training, he works on instinct and so can often take advantage of situations that others can’t. By taking 5 Stress, this ability allows the Tactician to change his Combat Tactic, Weapon Style, and weapon he is using, regardless of where he is on the Clock or whether or not the dice have been rolled.

He must qualify for the Tactic to use it (so he can’t suddenly Charge if he’s not already at a Run). If you choose to swap out weapons, he is never counted as unarmed, it happens, for all intents and purposes instantaneously, and he doesn't need to wait his weapon speed for his next attack - he simply waits the difference between their Recoveries (down to a minimum of 0 seconds).

He can use this ability multiple times and the Stress it inflicts is lowered by 1 every odd level after, to a minimum of 1.

*Second Wind Finding the perfect time to rest is what the Tactician is all about; he and nearby allies gain additional Vitality equal to his level when they Take a Breather.

*Skill Focus (Strategy, 4) At every level, including the first, Tacticians receive 4 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill from the Strategy Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different skill focuses) but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All non-Combat Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

*Martial Focus (Any Combat Skill Suite) A Tactician picks things up as they go, otherwise, they get themselves and their companions killed. At every level, including the first, the Tactician receives 1 free purchase of any Combat Skill Suite they're Trained in. This can be stacked with their other free Skill Suites from other Martial Focuses.

Primary Drawback

A Tactician focuses so much on being versatile that their specific specialization suffers. All Combat Advanced Skills cost 3 CrP more.

Thug

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone slips through armor and wears down their opponent so they can't fight back.

The Thug is designed to hit hard and make each strike count. As such they have abilities that remove an enemy’s damage reduction and increase the chance to knock someone out.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Streetwise Twice

Archetype Abilities

*Critical Strike Sometimes the winner isn't the one that can deal out the most pain but the one who knows where to put the pain. The Thug gains a +1 to effective damage when deciding whether or not an attack triggers a Trauma Check though this extra "damage" isn't added to the d20! roll. This bonus increases by 1 every odd level after 1st.

*Run 'em Ragged At the beginning of combat or a Skill Challenge, the Thug gains a pool of Stress equal to 5 times his level. On a successful hit or against any Check that's opposed by another person (even if they're unaware of him), he may subtract an amount of Stress from that pool. If he does so, he inflicts that much Stress on his target, which is healed when the person Takes a Breather.

*Precision Attack The Thug is an expert at making every attack count. At first level, he lowers the DR of his opponent by 1. He lowers it an additional 1 every 3 levels after that. For /d DR, this is subtracted from the final total.

Example, a level 4 Thug with a knife (3 dice) vs Scale (2/D), would reduce the enemy’s DR to 4 (6 total DR - 2 from Precision Attack), while one using a club (1 dice) would reduce it to 0 (2 total DR - 2 from Precision Attack).

*Martial Focus (Any Combat Skill Suite, 2) At every level, including first, Thugs receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from any Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

The Thug never really rises above his street rat origins: the Leadership, Administration, and Recruiting Advanced Skills all cost double.

Vanguard

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone that charges in and tries to get as many people to attack them as possible.

The Vanguard is the first in the fray, usually engaging multiple enemies at the same time and trying to do as much damage as possible to soften them up for their allies to follow.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

Against Them All When they’re in the thick of it is when the Vanguard thrives. The Vanguard adds a free roll of their Grit Dice to their Attack rolls against 1 opponent when engaged with 2 or more enemies.

*In, Out, & Around Knowing how to slip in and out of your opponent’s guard allows the Vanguard to get in and out of a jam quickly.

By gaining 5 Stress, the Vanguard may change their engagement zone with one opponent, without any associated penalties.

So, if they’re Threatening their opponent, they could move to Engaged or they could move to Unthreatened.

Additionally, if their enemy has successfully employed the In Their Guard Tactic, the Vanguard can move them back out to simply Engaged.

They can do this multiple times.

The Stress cost is also reduced by 1 for every 4 levels after the first, down to a minimum of 1.

*Crowd Control Surrounded by enemies, the Vanguard learns to use the crowd against themselves, forcing his enemies to get in each other’s way.

A Vanguard can use his full defense against an additional opponent if the two opponents are adjacent to each other and, should anyone try to disengage with him, he may take 5 Stress, in which case, he gains a free attack against them although this is at half damage.

*First Strike The Vanguard hits hard and hits first. Or at least, they try to.

At the beginning of combat, Vanguards receive a pool of Measure equal to their level. When they first become Engaged with an opponent, they may spend the points from that pool to temporarily increase their Measure for the purposes of determining who strikes first and whether or not you can hold the enemy at bay, on a 1-point-to-1-foot basis.

If you choose to use this ability to hold your enemy at bay, the extra measure continues to apply until they break your hold or either of you unegage.

So, a level 6 Vanguard would have a pool of 7 ft to work with. If wielding a Stiletto (Measure 1.5 ft) and closing in to Engage with an enemy wielding a Rapier (Measure 4 ft), he could spend 3 ft of it to allow him to get his hit off first, perhaps crippling his enemy before they have change to respond. Doing so would leave him with 3 ft in his pool for the rest of combat.

After that, combat resumes as normal, so he wouldn’t be able to attack the Rapier wielder if he is being Fended Off.

*Martial Focus (Any Combat Skill Suite, 2) At every level, including the first, Vanguards receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from any Combat Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level (unless from different Martial Focuses) but are applied after other Combat Skills have been bought by the Character.

Martial Adept This character has a knack for combat. All Advanced Combat Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Martial Adepts.

Primary Drawback

Vanguards are a position of honor, and they don’t take charging into battle lightly. A Vanguard loses 1 Integrity for every battle they’re not the first on either side to land a melee attack.

Servant Specialist Archetypes

Ashcaller

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a servant that heavily relies on the social aspect of the game.

The Ashcaller is a person that carries the legacy of those he loves with him. They’re able to call upon the spirits of the dead to aid him both through a manipulation of the Middle Realm but also as a font of Willpower.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore

Ashcallers receive 2 purchases of the Religion (Ancestors) Advanced Skill for free.

Archetype Abilities

Sacred Anchor The Ashcaller can summon the spirit of any person whose bones they carry. This summoning is how the Ashcaller invokes their Miracle.

When an Ashcaller prays to a particular spirit, they enter into a Confrontation with them with a number of rounds equal to the amount of Favor spent, trying to convince them to help. At the end of the Confrontation, the Miracle is invoked and the Ashcaller rolls his Grit Dice with a bonus (or penalty) equal the difference in points. This Confrontation takes 1 second per round.

The spirit, of course, regardless of win or lose, gains the Devotion “Tired of the Ashcaller” with a value of 1, or increasing it by 1 if they already have it.

Additionally, the other ancestor spirits become a bit jealous, gaining the Devotion “Dislikes the Ashcaller” at value of 1, or increasing it by 1 if they already have it.

Ancestor Covenant As part of their initiation into their order, the Ashcaller is gifted with the bone of one of their Ancestors and tasked with honoring their legacy. This is often a minor ancestor so this bone doesn’t start as a Relic but may become one as a result of play.

Playing the Spirits of the Dead

Summoned spirits of the dead are not their full personalities but merely shards of what they once were: their strongest characteristics shine through but the subtlety of the once living person is often lost.

So, spirits will often only have 3 Characteristics. Often this is just their 3 strongest Convictions but it can also be their Devotions, Flaws, Temperament, or even Goals, or some combination.

Spirits' personalities should make getting them to invoke certain Miracles easier or harder. After all, kind, sweet, Aunt Mildred won't want to summon a plague on a village and so will resist harder and Uncle Vortigern the Mad.

For the first spirit, the players should be encouraged to fill this out and know at least something about the bones of the person they carry.

The Ashcaller may also harvest and sanctify bones, according to how accepted ancestor worship is in the area, allowing them to summon more spirits. If these were NPCs (or even PCs), simply take the 3 Characteristics that you felt best defined them and use that for their spirit.

Tongue Of The Dead Whenever an Ashcaller invokes a Miracle and any of the Grit Dice explode, the next Confrontation with a spirit you get a free use of your Grit Die. This bonus does stack if multiple dice explode.

Honoring & Honored The Ancestors smile on those that strengthen their legacy. Whenever an Ashcaller gains Integrity, decrease the “Tired of” and “Dislikes” Devotion of their spirits by that amount. Completely reset these Devotions if the Ashcaller goes up an Integrity Category.

Eternal Favor An Ashcaller is loved for their devotion to their Ancestors beyond others. They add their total level to their Max Favor.

*Departed Council By reading the embers and smoke of their holy fires, the Ashcaller is able to channel the knowledge of those left behind.

By spending a Grit Die, they’re able to summon spirits and use them as an Asset for a Skill Check. The spirit’s Knowledge and Organization is considered Poor, although the Ashcaller can increase one or the other for every 3 levels after their 1st level.

They also receive 1 free purchase of the Religion (Ancestors) Advanced Skill at each level, including the first.

Symbol Of Faith The Ashcaller continues to find mooring in their holy symbol. This symbol doesn't help channel their holy power but does help them keep the faith. When brought into a Confrontation that relates question their faith or going against their cult's tenets, they receive their Grit Dice instead of the standard d6!.

*Breath of Knowledge A Servant is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Ashcallers get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

Ashcallers have turned their back on the Divines and so are unable to gain any benefits from others spending Favor. Additionally, Miracles invoked against them automatically get their full Grit Dice value.

Because of their Anointing, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one.

Doombearer

Choose this Archetype if you want to help out your team-mates by predicting the future.

Whether born to a faith or not, it appears that there are some people who are born with the gift of foresight: who are able to peer, briefly, into the currents of fate and see the patterns there. Those who know what they’re looking for can turn this to their advantage, twisting that fate away from woe to weal futures

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore

Archetype Abilities

Godscath The Forereader’s ability is seen as a greater awakening of the Divine nature in all sentient beings and so she is able to harness more godly power. She has a Max Favor equal to his Integrity Category + his level.

Doomsay Through ceremony and ritual, the Doombearer is able peer into the murky future and, perhaps, with the help of the Divines, change it. During this ritual, she selects a certain number of his Favor and “locks” it into a Doom.

Dooms tell of an event and proclamation about what will happen. The event needs to be an action, although the actor(s) doesn't need to be specified, while the fallout describes the desired outcome. Either can be as specific or as vague as the Doombearer wishes.

When the Doom is fulfilled, if the time between the Doom’s creation and it being fulfilled is less than 24 hours, nothing happens. However, if it is greater than that, the Doombearer can apply all of the locked Grit Dice to a single Check or dice roll that might further the desired outcome with each dice getting a +1 to its total.

For every 12 hours that pass, you get an additional +1, so after 32 hours, you get a +2, 44 hours, a +3, and so on.

Note that the first event matching the criteria of the Doom fulfills it, regardless of whether the Doombearer wants it to or not, but the event has to match every criteria set out as part of the Doom.

A Doom can be forfeited but can only be done at twilight and the Doombearer takes 1 Stress per level.

Should the Doombearer die, all his Dooms remain in effect until they're fulfilled. Also, should the Forereader’s Favor drop below their currently locked Favor (from lowering a Integrity Category, for example) they’re forced to forfeit one of their Dooms immediately and take the normal amount of Stress.

*Doomleeth Having your Doom fulfilled is a huge confidence booster and a huge relief to a Doombearer’s companions now that the other boot has dropped. Whenever a Doom is verifiably fulfilled without the direct involvement of the Forereader, the Doombearer gains a use of their Grit Die and she and her companions heal a number of Stress equal twice the bonus the Doom received.

‘Verifiably fulfilled’ means that Doom came to pass in a way that leaves no doubt or questions. So a Doom “When Athelwulf is attacked by an enemy, he will take no wounds” can be verified because if Athelwulf attacked and either dodged the attack or took no damage, then the Doom was fulfilled. If Athewulf took any damage at all (even if it was reduced due to the Grit Dice), the Doom isn’t verifiably fulfilled.

This does mean that more vague Dooms can never be verifiably fulfilled. For instance, “When Isidora needs to rely on her wits, she will come out on top” is probably too vague to work. The best way to make sure a Doom can be verifiably confirmed is to confer with your GM when you make the Doom on what it would mean for a Doom to be verifiable: perhaps attaching specific mechanical states to it.

Wirdhew With a Doombearer around, the future may seem more certain, even if that’s not the case. if you would gain more than 4 Stress due to a Check, instead half the total. So, if you got 6 Stress from an explosion, take 3 instead.

*Wideken A Doombearer is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Doombearer get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

Those that are awakened to the greater truths but they’re often left marked. The Forereader gains one of the following Flaws at its maximum Severity for no CrP: Blind, Deaf, Deranged, Hemophilic, Limp, Missing Eye, Mute.

Because of their Anointing, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one. Also, due to their inherent link with Ymir, they're unable to take a Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary.

Concert

Choose this Archetype if you want to buff up your companions in all areas of the game and buff up yourself in the process.

The Concert is a people’s person in the deepest sense. They help others be their best self, buffing others by linking their souls together.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite According to your Secondary Archertype

Concerts receive double the Skill of your Secondary Archetype. Replace any instances of “or” with “and”

Archetype Abilities

Conduit Of The Soul The Concert is a vessel for the divine in all living things. They add their total level to their Max Favor.

Soul United The Concert, by using the links between people, is able to strengthen themselves and others.

A person is considered Soul Linked if the Concert has a Devotion that includes a person or vice versa. This can be met with a general Devotion.

If they met both conditions (both have a Devotion to each other), they’re considered Soul Fettered. This doesn’t count if both have a general Devotion to one another: at least one Devotion has to be specific to either the Concert or the other person.

One Being Any Miracle is considered in her Covenant when invoked on someone the Concert is Soul Linked to.

On top of this, if it is someone they’re Soul Fettered with, she gains half the Favor (rounded down) spent this way back.

We're All Friends The Concert has a unique ability to just chill everyone out and get them to relax, even around age old enemies. If someone who she is Soul Linked with is about to be attacked by a sentient foe, before the first blow is actually thrown, the Concert can spend 5 Favor to initiate a Confrontation to get both sides to back down.

If it is someone she is Soul Fettered to, she may do this for only 3 Favor.

*Muse The Concert inspires others to rise to the challenge just solely based on her strong belief in them. When starting a Confrontation, Combat, or Skill Challenge, the Concert receives a number of uses of her Grit Dice equal to her level + 1, for the duration of that Confrontation, Combat, or Challenge. She may give these to anyone she is Soul Linked to.

If they are Soul Fettered, that person receives the max value of the dice when they redeem them.

She gains an additional Grit Die for every level she’s obtained.

Symbol Of Faith The Concert continues to find mooring in their holy symbol. This symbol doesn't help channel their holy power but does help them keep the faith. When brought into a Confrontation that relates question their faith or going against their cult's tenets, they receive their Grit Dice instead of the standard d6!.

*Breath of Knowledge A Servant is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Concerts get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

A Concert’s being is linked to others and so their fates are entwined. If someone who is Soul Linked to the Concert dies, they gain 20 Stress each time.

However, if someone they are Soul Fettered with dies, they gain no extra Vitality and no Vitality Die roll on level up. If more than one dies, that subtract 1 for each person from their Max Vitality.

Because of their Anointing, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one.

Gothen

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a servant with a more solid list of Miracles that affect the world beyond just bonuses.

A Gothen is one who invested their second soul into a Bonfire, thus they carry a part of the flame with them where they go. They are a divine elementalist, with a larger selection of Miracles than your average priest but they’re not pulled from the traditional Miracle list.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore

Archetype Abilities

Linked To The Bonfire The Gothen has the soul of the Bonfire and so is a generator of holy power that flows from them. They increase their Max Favor by half their Gothen level, rounded up.

Gothen's don't gain Favor like other Servants as they have no strict cult, church, or hierarchy and no Holy Days. They simply reverence the Bonfire and draw from its divinity constantly. This gives them 2 Favor a day, however, they can never benefit from special Favor or go above that max for any reason.

Shape Ymir The Gothen shapes the world through their connection to it and so their Miracles are more immediate than other servants. They may pray for any spell from the Animism and Occultism Traditions with their Grit Dice from Favor behaving like a Channeling Dice.

Miracles cast this way always have a Shape of Circle, an Origin of Aura, and take 2d4! seconds to shape. These Rudiments do not increase the Drain of the spell and the Gothen can choose to have it effect either those linked to the Gothen (i.e. anointed into the fire cult) or everyone else.

Purify The Mortal Coil The Gothen can remove their mortal coil to manifest their true nature but doing so may kill them. For every 3 Vitality the Gothen sacrifices, they gain 1 temporary special Favor to a max of their total level * 3 per day.

This Favor doesn’t count towards your Current Favor but has to be immediately added to keep a Miracle going or to create a new Miracle (or both). All damage dealt this way goes on one Wound and the Favor is wasted if not used immediately.

Mantle Of Fire The Gothen’s power projects out from him to protect those he wishes. By sacrificing 1 Vitality, the Gothen can make something within the Shape of a Miracle immune to its affect.

*Master Of The Dark The Gothen can read the flames and ashes, gaining insight into things others can’t see. At every even level, the Gothen receives either 1 free purchase of either the Lore or Survival Skill Suite.

Symbol Of Faith The Gothen continues to find mooring in their holy symbol. This symbol doesn't help channel their holy power but does help them keep the faith. When brought into a Confrontation that relates question their faith or going against their cult's tenets, they receive their Grit Dice instead of the standard d6!.

*Breath of Knowledge A Servant is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Gothen get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

The Gothen literally glows with inner light, sheding Normal light in a 10 ft radius around them and Dim light an additional 10 ft beyond that. It also gives enemies a +10 to spot them. This can be half hidden by clothing and fully shrouded by medium or heavier armor.

When they invoke a Miracle, the Bonfire swells within them, making 10 ft around them Bright Illumination for 3 seconds. The Gothen is penalized as well if they don’t close their eyes, though there’s no permanent damage. This cannot be hidden.

Finally, as part of their induction and/or training, the Gothen is marked, gaining the Burn Scars Flaw at 1d4 Severity. They may choose where the burn is but they gain no CrP for it initially. If they later increase the Severity, they get the normal CrP.

Because of their Anointing, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one.

Liminalist

Choose this Archetype if you want to command other beings that enhance or expand your skill set and don’t mind taking the risk that they might burst free and kill you.

The liminalist is one that reaches, not for the other realms, but for the endless, shapeless void between them, pulling the demons from them and bending them to their will. A liminalistis to a demonologist what a theoretical mathematician is to an engineer.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore

Liminalists are seekers of unknowable things. They receive 3 free purchases of Religion (Syncretism), which allows them to see commonalities between different religions.

Archetype Abilities

Hewn Oblivion The liminalist, though a combination of will and exploitation of Divine power, is able to pull demons, leftovers of creation, from the aetherial void and binds them to his will. Demon stats can be found in the Bonfire Bestiary.

The liminalist spends 1 or more Favor to bind a demon with a Circle value equal to the total of his roll. So, if he spent 2 Favor in the summoning, with a Grit Dice of a d6!, he could get a demon between Circles 2 and 12. They must take what they roll.

There are different types and categories of demons, each with different abilities that can get a specific job. Some are brutish and stupid, while others are cunning and skillful. Some come linked with certain symbols, such as gateways or the birth of children, that give them powers related to them.

Demon Summoned
Roll (d20) Demon Summary
1 Amayon Hurts those around it
2 Astaroth Inflicts Stress
3 Belphegor Spawns smaller demons
4 Deumusian Scares those around it
5 - 6 Gargoyle Big ol' brutes
7 Ghoul Jack of All Trades
8 - 9 Imp Manipulators
10 Incubus/Succubus Changes people's personality
11 Janusarian Unkillable in zone
12 - 13 Merihem Repositions things/people around
14 Padagogus Fortifies your Resolve
15 - 16 Sabnock Weakens those around it
17 - 18 Scox Mailer demon
19 - 20 Sycophant Secret Tellers

The demons pulled are randomly rolled on the Demon Summoned table.

The demon appears within 5 ft of the summoner and rolls a d3 initiative dice.

Demons are notorious shapeshifters and beguilers but through this ability, the liminalist is able to force them (somewhat) into a single shape, though this is often a grotesque and twisted form. This means that, when they're summoned, a Liminalist can invest a number of points into a demon equal to their Circle. What these can be invested in and how much it costs to do so is noted in the demon's entry, however, once invested, they cannot be changed while the demon is still bound.

Demons, even relatively dumb ones, are intelligent creatures and will struggle to overcome their bindings. Anytime you change a demon’s command after the first given, the demon rolls a d10! + its Circle (and the Circle of any other demons controlled by the same liminialist) vs a d20! + the Liminalist's Pre Check Mod in a one round Confrontation.

If it wins, the summoner loses control and the demon goes rogue. See the A Demon Unbound sidebar for more information.

Any Servant in the area can try and gain control of it; spending Favor and rolling Grit Dice. If the total is greater than the rogue demon’s Circle, they gain control... for now.

Demons are wily creatures, always trying to find loopholes in their orders and while there are implicit bindings in the summon that prevent obvious loophole breaching, they’ll do the bare minimum of what’s asked of them.

This binding does make them more susceptible to suggestion as well and others may enter into a Confrontation with the demon to get it to do or reveal things, on one condition: it can’t go against their summoner’s orders.

So, a demon ordered to patrol a hall can be forced to reveal information about its master or how many people are in each room, but it can’t be forced by others to stop patrolling (or even not attack the players, should it be told to kill anyone in the hall).

The summon lasts for 1 minute but can be increased by 1 minute if the control spends additional Favor. Demons are forced to stay within eyesight of their current controller.

If the liminalist dies or suffers a Mental Breakdown, the demon is unsummoned.

A Demon Unbound

While in the Middle Realm, a demon is not in their natural form - they're forced into one that is extremely unpleasant, which has been compared to wearing a hair shirt that is one size too small. This, understandably, puts them in an eternal bad mood where, while bound, they'll do everything they can to make their summoner's life miserable while still following orders and within the constraints of the binding.

A demon that’s escaped its bindings is a terrible thing as their full power is unleashed, directed at the one who brought them into existence.

The demon gets back the full complement of its shapeshifting powers. Not only can it change its overall size but any exponential areas to modify drop to the one for one price.

They can shift all their points once a second as well.

The demon first seeks to kill its summoner out of revenge and then, if they’re still around, it seeks any who were working with the summoner. After doing so, it’ll try to do as much damage as it possibly can before it winks out of existence.

*See The Unseen As a liminalist, you learn to get a feel for the void and what ‘could be’ in the ‘is not’ that can be. He can modify his d20 roll on the Demon Summoned table by an amount equal to his level in either direction.

*Hubris Bridled The worst thing a liminal can do is summon a demon from a higher Circle than he has power to control and so he learns to fight his confidence and learn to control his ego, projecting this to others around him.

The liminalist can take Stress to raise or lower Grit Dice results by a like amount, however, he can never lower it below 1 or raise it above its max value

He may also do so for others but takes twice the Stress.

Clerical Error The Liminalist doesn’t ascribe to one faith but games the system to gain favor because he knows the Divines’ celestial accountants aren’t keeping that close of an eye on things. They increase their Max Favor by their total level

They also gain Favor as Servants do, although the performance of the rituals is more lip service than actual belief in most cases and so don’t start with the normal Devotion that Servants start with.

Primary Drawback

Liminalists who focus on their craft have more powerful bindings but that can be a problem. Should the liminalist die or suffer a Mental Break, any demons he has bound become unbound instead of simply becoming unsummoned.

Because of their cavalier attitude towards faith, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one, nor become Anointed.

Paragon Acolyte

Choose this Archetype if you want a smaller but stronger array of powers that benefits greater from your Integrity.

These people take hero worship to another level and by emulating their idols, they convince the already shaky reality that they’re the reincarnation of said hero, giving them amazing powers.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Any One Relating to His Hero's Story

Archetype Abilities

Paragon’s Legacy The Paragon Acolyte can channel his hero, allowing him to recreate events from their life on a smaller scale. The player selects 5 feats that the hero performed during their lifetime and, whenever they invoke Miracles related to one or more of those feats, they increase the Grit Dice they get from Favor by 1 size. It is further increased 1 size for every 4 levels after the first.

Like Stories Of Old Feeling the power of the old stories rush through your veins, it allows you to soar higher than mortals dare. Whenever you roll the maximum amount on their Grit Dice, you gain another use of your Grit Die.

*Manifest Destiny Fate is always on the side of the hero, then and now. Whenever the Paragon Acolyte spends a Favor, they receive 1 free Boon in addition to the rest of the Miracle. This Boon follows the basic rules of those found in Chapter 4:Challenges but can apply to combat and Confrontations. The Boon happens regardless of success or failure. They gain 1 additional Boon for every 3 levels after the first.

Mantle Hero At the end of each day, the Paragon Acolyte receives 1 Favor for every point of Reputation in their strongest Reputation, minimum 1, but does not gain Favor by Holy Days or Sacrifices.

Greater Being Linked to their hero’s spirit, they can increase the amount of Favor they can get. Their Max Favor is their Integrity Category + their total level.

Symbol Of Faith The Paragon Acolyte continues to find mooring in their holy symbol. This symbol doesn't help channel their holy power but does help them keep the faith. When brought into a Confrontation that relates question their faith or going against their cult's tenets, they receive their Grit Dice instead of the standard d6!.

*Breath of Knowledge A Servant is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Paragon Acolytes get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

Every hero has a weakness that can lead to their downfall. During character creation, the Paragon Acolyte tells the story of the hero’s downfall. When it becomes relevant, the Paragon Acolyte cannot spend Integrity or Grit Dice to help him.

Because of their Anointing, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one.

Priest

Choose this Archetype if you want your companions to benefit from their Favor more and receivea kick-back for doing so.
