Priests focus on shaping Miracles on other people rather than themselves, making them a good support Archetype for other classes. Their Miracles vary widely based on their patron Divine.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite None

Priests receives 3 purchases of the Religion (The Priest’s Covenant) Advanced Skill for free

Archetype Abilities

Divine Covenant During Character Creation, a Priest selects 1 Covenant and 1 Cosmic Link, representing their deity’s sphere of influence and personality, respectively.

Covenants change which Miracles the Priest has access to while Cosmic Links change the ways you gain and spend Favor.

Anatomy of the Divine

Covenants

Divines have spheres of power that represent their aspects. These are codified into Covenants, or promises they make with their servants in exchange for a portion of the Divine’s power.

Cults of that Divine typically pick one, maybe two Covenants, of their chosen Divine to focus on.

For instance, Wülder, a Gothic god, watches over Raiding, Industry and Trade. There could be 3 different priests to Wülder, one focusing on his role as the Bridge Between Men, one seeing him as primarily a watcher over people going on cattle raids, and one worshiping him as the greater crafter and source of inspiration.

While they all worship the same Divine, the Miracles they can invoke in his name are different.

This means that priests of different cults may not get along with each other and there can even be intra-faith wars to purge heretics (those that focus on different Covenant from them).

The main bonus of Covenants is that they make Miracles within them easier to invoke. The specifics are elaborated on in the Invoking Miracles in Chapter 5:The Divine.

Cosmic Links

The Higher Planes are those that exist above the crude and primitive world and so, naturally, the Divines are linked to the events and behaviors of the celestial bodies that make their homes in the heavens.

A Cosmic Link is the specific celestial body that the Divine is associated with, and it usually gives an insight to the personality of the god. The Cosmic Link doesn’t necessarily mean your Patron is primarily the Divine of that Cosmic thing. So, a Divine associated with the moon might not be primarily a moon god, in the same way that while Venus was associated with the Morning Star, she was primarily viewed as a love goddess by the Romans. Still, your holy symbols may incorporate the moon motif commonly to represent her.

For clarification’s sake: when something says “decrease” in this section’s explanations, you go down the chart by that many steps. If it says “increase” go up, so increase will always be a bonus, and decrease will always be bad.

Comet

This is associated with fervent but fleeting powers. Whenever you invoke a Miracle, you gain two Grit Dice with a +3 but lose an additional Favor.

Evening Star

The evening star is a source of strength and beauty: it's the first star to rise in the evening. When you invoke a Miracle, if you roll below the average, you gain the average instead. So, if you roll d8 and get a 3 or less, you get 4 instead.

Moon

The moon is a steady force, its effects are subtle but constant. When you invoke a Miracle, if you roll two Grit Dice, keeping the highest.

Morning Star

The morning star is the last star in the heavens before day and is a lone watcher. When you invoke a Miracle and roll the minimum amount, you don’t lose any Favor.

Sun

The sun is the lord of heaven, strong and unbending, its power unquestioned. When you invoke a Miracle and roll the max amount, you don’t lose any Favor.

Cyclical

Often hailing from older, more primitive times, the Cyclical deity represents earthly inevitabilities in a dichotomy, sometimes with themselves and sometimes with an opposing deity. This can be Spring and Summer, life and death, creation and destruction. They may be weak now, but they will wax unstoppable. When you invoke a Miracle, and roll under its average, your next Miracle gains a +1. This is cumulative.

If you roll above its average, this bonus is then removed, and you get a -1 to your next Miracle. Again, this is cumulative and resets when you roll below.

So, if you have a d6! Grit Dice, and you roll a 2, the next Miracle you invoke gets a +1. That next Miracle you roll, you get a 3 for a total of 4 (because of the +1), giving you a +2 the next roll. On that roll, you roll a 5 for a total of 7 ( 5 + 2 ). The next Miracle you then invoke gets a -1

Shepherd Of The PeopleIf someone else prays for a Miracle within sight of the Priest, the Priest can spend his own Favor to increase the power of that Miracle. This just treats the Favor he spent the same as Favor spent by the person praying except that he gains half, rounded down, of all the Favor spent this way back. If the person is Anointed in the Priest’s cult, the Priest also receives another use of their Grit Die.

Honor Of The DivinesWhile invoking a Miracle, if you or someone you've spent Favor on rolls the maximum value on your Grit Die, you also gain an extra use of your Grit Die.

Favored Of The Divines The Priest’s mission isn’t a selfish one, but it does have some benefits and they’re loved for their devotion to their Divines beyond others. They add their total level to their Max Favor.

*Catechism By studying the holy texts, the Priest is about to discern the will of the Divines and better understand the Higher Realms. They receive a free purchase of the Religion (Divines) Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Symbol Of Faith The Priest continues to find mooring in their holy symbol. This symbol doesn't help channel their holy power but does help them keep the faith. When brought into a Confrontation that relates question their faith or going against their cult's tenets, they receive their Grit Dice instead of the standard d6!.

*Breath of Knowledge A Servant is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Priests get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

A Priest has sworn themselves to a Higher Power and as a token of their Covenant, they must select a taboo; an action or thing they must never do, such as cut their hair or eat meat. This must be appropriate to the Divine and be approved by the GM before play begins.

Because of their Anointing, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one.

Symbolist

Choose this Archetype if you want to spend your Favor to gain permanent bonuses to help you and your companions adapt as needs be.

The Symbolist is the word and the law, both being sacred to him. His worships reality itself and channels the innate power in the corpse of Ymir to shun magic and miracles. He grips the law so tightly as to bend it to his will.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Survival

Archetype Abilities

Linked To The Bones Of Ymir Harnessing the divine energies of the Middle Realm, the Symbolist is able to become a part of the world in a more real way. He gains Favor equal to his Integrity Category + 1/2 his level, rounded up. Unlike other Servants, he can’t gain additional Favor through the normal means (sacrifices and holy days): this Favor is static and only increases with level.

Marks Of The Earth Through ceremony and ritual, the Symbolist is able to invoke Miracles that are normally reserved only for the Divines. Given an hour, the Symbolist can endow a mark on him or another person. During the ceremony, he selects a certain number of his Favor and “locks” into the mark.

Doing so essentially invokes a Miracle on that person, however, unlike a normal Miracle, it persists for as long as the person marked wishes it and there is a distinct chance of failure: the Symbolist must roll over 10 on their Grit Dice. He gains an additional roll of the Grit Dice for every Favor he locks in, which add to his total.

If the Miracle is unsuccessfully invoked at the end of the ceremony, the mark, and the Miracle by extension, didn’t take and that Favor is freed once more, however, the Symbolist can’t try the ceremony again on that person until they increase an Integrity Category.

If it was successful, that Miracle becomes active, blessing the Symbolist and/or marked person. The mark can only be removed at the will of the person or Symbolist and can’t be removed by normal means (so washing won’t get rid of it). The Favor is “locked” and can't be used for other marks and Miracles until released.

Mark of the Earth Bonus
Modifier Stat
+1S Carry
-2 Recovery
+2 Damage, Defense, /DR, Walk or Strol/Crawl Speed, Skill Suite, Description, Devotion
+3 Parry, DR, Jog Speed, Advanced Skill, Conviction, Knock Back Threshold
+4 Run Speed, Vitality, Stress Threshold
-4 Initiative
+5 Sprint Speed, DR specific to a non-weapon damage type (no Slashing but fire is okay, for example)

Unlike normal, the Miracle doesn’t give the full Grit Dice as a bonus whenever the Miracle is applicable: instead the person gains a bonus (or penalty depending on what the person wants when they roll) for each Favor locked into that Miracle when applicable.

Like normal Miracles, however, this can modify things you normally couldn’t, like Movement speed or Knock-Back, or what-have-you. Refer to the following table as a guideline. This is not a definitive list but GMs should use it determine what the bonus might be.

Should the Symbolist die, all his marks are released. Also, should the Symbolist’s Favor drop below their currently locked Favor (from lowering a Integrity Category, for example) they’re forced to unlock one of their marks and dispel a Miracle.

*Law Of Averages The Symbolist is a pillar of certainty in a sea of chaos. If the Symbolist rolled under the average on a dice, he may gain 5 Stress and the next roll someone makes gives them a +1 bonus to their roll. Additionally, if he rolled over the average, he may spend 5 Stress for the next roll to be at a -1 penalty. This can negate perfect attacks and defenses as well as fumbles.

This bonus is also increased by 1 at every odd level after the first.

Conduit Of Reality The Symbolist can invoke Miracles from the following Covenants: Dream, Guardians, Adversity, Battle, Beauty, Fate, Fire, Home, Honor. He is unable to invoke any Miracles outside of these Covenants, even for the normal price.

*Breath of Knowledge A Servant is a well-versed individual, regardless of their faith. At every level, including the first, Symbolists get either 2 free purchases of any Advanced Combat Skill, 4 free purchases of any Advanced non-Combat Skill, or they can increase their Convictions and cult-related Devotions by 1.

Purchases of Skills can’t be doubled up on each other, even if they come from other sources (Skill Focus, Martial Focus, or Work on Your Personality).

Primary Drawback

By anchoring themselves to the Bones of Ymir, the Symbolist cuts off his connection to the God’s Realm in a way: other Servants are unable to invoke beneficial Miracles on him and they also increase their Grit Dice by 1 size when invoking destructive Miracles on him.

Because of their Anointing, they're also unable to take another Servant Archetype as a Secondary, nor are they allowed to Double Down in this one. Also, due to their inherent link with Ymir, they're unable to take a Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary.

Socialite Specialist Archetypes

Advocate

Choose this Archetype if you want to be supportive in a Confrontation without being the center of attention and responsibility.

While other Socialites like the limelight, the Advocate doesn’t mind playing second fiddle and in fact, thrives there. When supporting others in a Confrontation, the Advocates gets a lot of bonuses.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore

Archetype Abilities

Support Group An Advocate has their friend’s back: cheering them on and supporting them. If you add a Devotion or Conviction to an ally’s Check, you and the person halve the amount of Stress you would take, rounded down.

On Second Thought Staying in the back can allow the Advocate to jump in on a point and snatch victory from the jaws of defeat. After hearing the results of a Confrontation Check, the Advocate can add one more Devotion or Conviction but gain an additional d4! Stress that’s added on top of the normal Stress they would get.

*Team Spirit The party that supports each other triumphs. At the beginning of a Confrontation, the Advocate gains a number of Grit Dice equal to their Advocate level that lasts until the end of that Confrontation.

If they spend those Grit Dice on another’s Check, that person receives the max value of that Grit Dice but can still roll it to check for explosions.

*Resilient Spirit An Advocate is able to withstand even the most dire of pressures: after all, if one can survive a party, one can survive basically anything. At every level, including the first, the Advocate permanently increases their Stress Threshold by 1.

*Identity Focus (Devotion) As an Advocate grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of one Devotion by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As an Advocate grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 1) Through the course of her career, an Advocate develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 1 free purchase of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

Advocates can kind of lock up when they’re in the driver's seat. When they make a Confrontation Check, they shrink their dice by 1 size.

Armiger

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a battlefield commander, using the Morale rules to win combats.

The Armiger is one that has been granted the right to bear a cost of arms, either their personal sigil or their liege lord. People are naturally drawn to these individuals and they find their strength in the support of this crowd.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

Raising The Banner Armigers attract the best and brightest to their banner. As such, they start rolling for followers at level 2 and they gain double the bonus to attracting followers from Integrity. On top of this, they only gain the -1 to their roll for every other follower they attract.

Standard An Armiger has the right to bear a heraldic crest that identifies him. He may emblazon this on a banner or his shield, but by having it proudly displayed, while he is still fighting, all his allies use his Integrity Category to determine their starting Morale category.

*Force of Personality The values and virtues of the Armiger are infectious and can inspire others to greater heights. They get no Stress when adding Devotions or Convictions to Recruit Checks or while Rallying.

*Invictus The Armiger not only gets others to do their duty but to go above and beyond. When they successfully Rally a person, bringing them down under their Panic or Stress Threshold, both the Armiger and that person gain 1 Grit Dice that lasts until the end of the combat, Confrontation, and/or Challenge. This increases by 1 Grit Dice for every 3rd level after the first.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As an Armiger grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Identity Focus (Devotion) As an Armiger grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of one Devotion by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Strategy, 4) At every level, including the first, Armigers receive 4 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Strategy Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 1) Through the course of her career, an Armiger develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 1 free purchase of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

Armigers are standards of the people and when they fail to live up to that, they’re judged more harshly. If the Armiger is forced to retreat from a Combat or Confrontation for any reason, they lose 5 Integrity.

Champion

Choose this Archetype if you want to be a hero that outlasts their enemies: an inevitable end to their enemies.

A crusader for a cause, paladin of the king, an inexhaustible bounty hunter tracking his prey over months, an inquisitor seeking out heretics to the end of the earth. These are Champions. Their oaths and devotions are the weapons they wield and, from sacrifice to a cause greater than themselves, strength.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

*Juggernaut The Champion is fueled by their zeal and when others push them down it causes them to come back swinging. When the Champion takes Stress or Damage in a Combat, Confrontation, or Challenge related to one or more of their Devotions, they gain a roll of their Grit Dice to their next Confrontation Check.

These do stack but the Champion has to spend them all the next chance they get.

*Power of Devotion The Champion can power through when others would give up. The Champion can add an applicable Devotion or Conviction for no Stress to a Trauma Check or a Rally that targets them.

Solemnity of Cause A Champion considers his obligations with a solemn contemplation and as his beliefs are challenged, the stronger they grow. Whenever he wins a Confrontation Check that involves at least 1 of his Devotions, He can subtract that Devotion’s Rank from the Stress he would normally get from it.

Allies taking Stress as a result of participating in the Champion’s Check also have their Stress reduced by his Devotion’s Rank.

*Fanatical Honor The Champion’s oath and zeal to upholding it allows them to rise above others. Their Max Integrity is increased by 1 every 4th level, starting at 1st level.

Note that they still gain a Grit Dice for hitting 25 Integrity but gain another when they max out.

*Identity Focus (Devotion) As a Champion grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of one Devotion by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As a Champion grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

Primary Drawback

Champions take their oaths very seriously and don’t take new ones on lightly. Anytime they can purchase Devotions for CrP, the price of a new Devotion is 7 + (Number of Devotions * 5) CrP.

Diplomat

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone that bends others to their will through sheer force of personality.

The Diplomat is a strong-willed character that makes the most of emotional Appeals: learning how to use them to great effect to sway his opponents.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Streetwise

Archetype Abilities

Gray Eminence In his arena, the Diplomat is king and nothing can shake him. When making a Confrontation Check, the Diplomat and his allies take 2 less Stress.

*Strength of Integrity The Diplomat is one whose integrity is paramount and, because of that, they have an inner confidence. When you spend a Grit Die on a Confrontation Check, you also gain a reroll of the main Check die, taking the highest.

*Inner Resolve The Diplomat is confidence made manifest, especially in their realm of choice. At the beginning of a Confrontation the Diplomat gains a number of Grit Dice equal to their level. They can only apply 1 of these bonus Grit Dice to a single roll, though that doesn’t stop them adding Grit Dice that they got from other sources.

These Grit Dice last until the end of the Confrontation.

*Resilient Spirit A Diplomat is able to withstand even the most dire of pressures: after all, if one can survive a party, one can survive basically anything. At every level, including the first, the Advocate permanently increases their Stress Threshold by 1.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As a Diplomat grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Identity Focus (Description) As a Diplomat grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. Every 4th level, starting with the first, you can increase the Rank of one of your Descriptions by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 1) Through the course of her career, a Diplomat develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 1 free purchase of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

Diplomats put their reputation on the table whenever they engage in a Confrontation. They lose 5 Integrity whenever they lose a Confrontation.

Foil

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone that convinces people through using their weaknesses against them and protecting yourself from their charms.

The Foil focuses on using the other person when convincing them of something. He can steal the opponent’s dice in Confrontation and when things get tough, he can tag in another person to take on the Confrontation.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Streetwise

Archetype Abilities

*Cherry Picker The Foil knows how to make the most of their Flaws. If you purchase this Archetype during Character Creation, you can Cherry Pick your Flaws but each additional Flaw only loses 5 CrP of its values, instead of the normal 10.

If you gain Flaws from the Identity Focus (Flaw) ability, you can Cherry Pick those instead of rolling randomly.

Mentalist The Foil can read people intuitively in an instant. When your opponent makes a Confrontation Check, you learn one of the Characteristics they’re using for that Check.

Honest Failings The Foil isn’t ashamed of their Flaws and it shows. If you use a Flaw on a Check, you gain no Stress from it.

*Trojan Argument The Foil can put doubt into your mind about your position without you even realizing it. When a Foil defends against an Appeal or line of Reasoning, they automatically get 1 point, regardless of the outcome.

Increase this by 1 every 5th level.

*Inflicted Self-Consciousness There’s just something about the Foil that makes you very aware of your own flaws. When an opponent tries to respond to an argument by you or an ally using a Description or Flaw, they gain Stress equal to your Foil level.

*Identity Focus (Description) As a Foil grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. Every 4th level, starting with the first, you can increase the Rank of one of your Descriptions by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Identity Focus (Flaw) As a Foil grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. Every odd level, starting with the first, you can increase the Severity of one of your Flaws by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Severity 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

This Flaw is rolled randomly unless you have the Cherry Picker Ability, although you’ll have to reroll if you would roll on the Physical Flaws table and you receive no CrP for it, regardless.

Primary Drawback

Foils are so good at mirroring others that they often forget to reflect on themselves; it takes them twice as much CrP to improve their Convictions.

Fusilier

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone that uses firearms to stun and overpower people through use of fear.

Firearms are new and exciting but also dangerous. While not as damaging or as far reaching as other ranged weapons, they do terrify in a primal way, a thing that Fusiliers have learned to exploit.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

Standard Issue Fusiliers often tend to gain their firearms from the military and a lot of time, they take them home (much to the chagrin of the quartermasters). They may start the game with 4 handgonnes, 10 fire lances, or a hakenbuchse.

Of Lead & Powder A Fusilier trains with guns, pushing their skills to the limit, allowing to get creative in their uses. Fusiliers may wield and fire handgonnes with one hand and count as small weapons for the 2 1 Handed Weapons Style. They’re also able to deploy a hakenbuchse’s trip pod in 2 seconds instead of 5 seconds and fire lances only gain 1 Wear after 2 uses.

With all firearms, a Fusilier can light the brand in a swift motion, taking no time at all, lowering the firing time by 4 seconds.

Roar Of The Beast There’s something terrifying of the smell of smoke and the rage of fire and a Fusilier knows how to use this to their advantage. If in a Morale Confrontation, Appealing to those that are flinching gain an extra 2d6! to their Check.

Further, those that travel with the Fusilier gain an immunity to this after a combat and lower their flinch times against all firearms by 1 second per shot they weren't hit by.

Roar of the Beast Lite

If you’re not running the Morale rules, here is another option to not have the Fusilier nerfed because of this change:

The Fusilier can select a number of flinched enemies up to his Warfare Skill Rank to gain an additional -2 to their Defense for each Wound Category they've dropped.

*Boomstick By adding just a little something to the powder mix, the Fusilier can make that bang from the firearm going off exceptionally loud. The minimum amount of time an enemy flinches from a Fusilier’s firearm going off increases by 1 every odd level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

Due to all the gunfire a Fusilier has been around, they have a harder time hearing than others. The Listening Advanced Skill costs 6 CrP instead of 4.

Knave

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone that beats their opponents though sheer force of apathy.

The Knave is a mean villain - mean in the sense of being crude and villain in the sense of being low class, but unlike others, the Knave doesn’t seem to mind and that’s where their strength lies.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite None

Archetype Abilities

Invoke Pity The Knave makes you very aware that you’re punching down (even when you’re not). When someone defends against a Knave’s argument with an Appeal or Line of Reasoning, they gain twice the Stress.

Glory Hole Those that try and use their status against the Knave find little but apathy. When in a Confrontation with the Knave, enemies can’t spend Integrity or Grit Dice on any Checks.

Wrestling With a Pig When you wrestle with a pig, you both get muddy but the pig loves it. You can sacrifice Integrity to bring down an opponent’s Check on a 1-to-1 basis, however, if you bring their total below 0, they also gain a d4! Stress on top of any other Stress they would normally get.

In Weakness, Strength While others see their Flaws as something that holds them back, Knaves consider them with pride since they’re what make them unique. When adding a Flaw to a Confrontation Check add 1 / 2 levels you've updated, rounded up.

*Identity Focus (Flaw) As a Knave grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. Every odd level, starting with the first, you can increase the Severity of one of your Flaws by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Severity 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

This Flaw is rolled randomly unless you have the Cherry Picker Ability, although you’ll have to reroll if you would roll on the Physical Flaws table and you receive no CrP for it, regardless.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As a Knave grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 2) Through the course of her career, a Knave develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 2 free purchases of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

Knaves aren’t really heroes at the end of the day, even if they try to be. Shrink their Grit Dice by 1 size.

Mountebank

Choose this Archetype if you want to play someone that convinces their opponents through fast talking: coming on strong for a quick win but suffering in the long game.

The Mountebank is one of tricks and quick thinking. He relies on dazing the person with words, hoping they won’t take the time to catch onto his tricks.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Streetwise

Archetype Abilities

Sweet Talker The Mountebank comes with sly and honeyed words. When using a Conviction or Description for a Check, the Mountebank gains an extra point, regardless of the outcome.

Double Doubt The Mountebank has a particular way of hammering home a point that really drives the doubt deep. If they beat an opponent who is using an Appeal or line of Reasoning against them, their opponent gains an extra d4! of Stress that is added on top of the normal Stress they would get.

*Know-it-All The Mountebank can convince you that the sky is green due to their confidence and ability to make nonsensical logic look straightforward. When using a line of Reasoning as an argument, they get a bonus to their roll equal to their level.

*Fast Talker The quicker the Mountebank talks, the less time you have to find holes in their logic. For a number of rounds equal to the Mountebank’s level, starting on round 1, they add a roll of their Grit Dice to every Confrontation Check they make.

*Identity Focus (Description) As a Mountebank grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. Every 4th level, starting with the first, you can increase the Rank of one of your Descriptions by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Streetwise, 4) At every level, including the first, Mountebanks receive 4 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Streetwise Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 1) Through the course of her career, a Mountebank develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 1 free purchase of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

The Mountebank is the devil in disguise and his untrustworthy nature makes him never quite sure if you can trust him. After their first Confrontation with the Mountebank, they gain “Distrusts the Mountebank” Devotion at Rank 5.

Noble

Choose this Archetype if you want to debuff your enemy while gaining strength through winning Appeals.

The Noble is typically aloof and hard to impress and so can convince people simply by making them unsure about their conviction, shrinking their dice in Confrontation.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

Royal Background Nobles form an elite class of society, giving them a strong sense of self and confidence. At first level, they gain the “Noble” Description at Rank 1 and can increase it by 1 every 3rd level.

If the player wants, they can swap out the "Noble" for the "Parvenu", representing either new nobility or a non-noble bloodline, such as being the scion of a wealthy merchant family.

Class System By reminding others of their lower station in life, you can remind them just how petty their needs are. At the start of any Confrontation, you get a number of points equal to your Noble or Parvenu Description.

If points don’t matter, you can add them to any Confrontation Checks you make for no extra Stress.

*Friends in All Places Even a down-on-their-luck, traveling Noble has connections they can pull on. At level 1, they gain an additional 5 Contact Points. As they level up and their fortune increases, old family friends will start coming out of the wood work: they gain an additional Contact Point at every level up and every odd level (not including the first), they increase their maximum number of Followers by 1.

*Confidence in Knowledge A Noble is taught from a very early age in things of great importance and that knowledge often gets wrapped up in their beliefs about the world. When using a Description or Conviction on a Check that also uses a Skill, you halve the amount of Stress gained from the Check.

*Noble Bearing Nobles are taught to have confidence in a way that others are not: a self surety that makes even the weakest arguments feel like they have weight. At the start of a Confrontation, you gain a number of rerolls equal to your level that last until the end of that Confrontation.

Allies also gain this benefit, however, all rerolls from them are in a shared pool.

*Identity Focus (Description) As a Noble grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. Every 4th level, starting with the first, you can increase the Rank of one of your Descriptions by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 1 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As a Noble grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 1) Through the course of her career, a Noble develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 1 free purchase of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

Nobility is a collective illusion and so those of royal blood, no matter how limited strive to keep that illusion in place. Nobles lose 1 Integrity and gain 1 Stress whenever they're not referred to by either their proper title, "my lord", or "sir".

In the case of Parvenus, the character is more aware of their low-born roots and will do everything they can to separate themselves from the commoner class. As such, they're required to spend 10% of their coin (both starting and acquired during play) on nice clothes and lodgings (however, they gain no additional Relaxation for doing so).

Officer

Choose this Archetype if you want to use the Morale rules to allow your company to adapt and rally to snatch the from the jaws of defeat.

The cunning Officer is able to read a battlefield like a book and with a single command, swings the fulcrum of battle in her side’s favor. He is the party leader and the standard to which others flock.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Strategy

Archetype Abilities

Morale Boosters Even a small victory can raise the hopes of a group. When the Officer or an ally successfully hits an enemy, the Officer gains a +d4! on their next Confrontation Check. This stacks with successive hits but this bonus must be spent on the next available Check before the end of the combat.

Momentum Those in leadership can often turn a small victory into a large one. Whenever the Officer makes a successful Confrontation Check, they gain a free roll of their Grit Die that lasts until the end of the Confrontation.

These Grit Dice can be used on Checks made by you or your allies.

*Fog of War The Art of War is the art of information and the Officer knows how to wage that war. If the Officer targets a Panicked or Fatigued enemy with a Confrontation Check, they add a free roll of their Grit Die to that Check. If the target is both Panicked and Fatigued, they add 2 rolls instead.

*Team Building Nothing is closer than a band of soldiers. Every hour spent with the Officer gives an amount of Relaxation equal to the Officer’s level x 2.

*Esprit de Corps The Officer can easily form a close knit bond between himself and his men that can last a lifetime. At every level up, the Officer can give a positive Devotion relating to himself to a willing character or NPC, starting at Rank 1.

On top of this, all those that already have a positive Devotion relating to the Officer raise that Devotion by 1 Rank.

*Identity Focus (Devotion) As an Officer grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every odd level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of one Devotion by 1 or save it and gain a new one at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Strategy, 4) At every level, including the first, Officers receive 4 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Strategy Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

Primary Drawback

Officers don’t really know how to fight alone and may take the better part of valor in a combat. When fighting alone, Officer characters gain 1 Stress every time they make an Attack Check.

Philosopher

Choose this Archetype if you want to become stronger as you let your opponent win rounds so that you can crush them with one fell swoop.

The Philosopher reserves his strength, allowing his opponent in a Confrontation to escalate for him. While others suffer strain from not meeting the argument straight on, the Philosopher uses it to his advantage.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore

Archetype Abilities

Rhetorical Passion The Philosopher is filled with knowledge and the love of knowledge. When they use a Skill on a Confrontation Check, they can add a Conviction for free.

Total Victory When the Philosopher has you, they really have you. When an opponent concedes to an argument, your side gets an extra point.

*Socratic Method A Philosopher is versed in the best ways to present an argument so, even when they lose, their argument still has weight. When you or an ally concedes to an argument, you still gain a point. At 10th level, this increases to 2 points.

*Fabian Strategy Sometimes victory is achieved by giving ground and letting your opponent move into the best position. When you lose after using a line of Reasoning, you gain a bonus equal to your level on your next Confrontation Check.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As a Philosopher grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Any Int, 4) At every level, including the first, Philosophers receive 4 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills that have Int as one of their Stats. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 1) Through the course of her career, a Philosopher develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 1 free purchase of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

The Philosopher tries to not let things get personal: they gain +2 Stress when Appealing, regardless of the outcome.

Rascal

Choose this Archetype if you want to play some that relies more on the circumstances of the Confrontation than on their raw stats.

The Rascal gains a few skills, but their main strength is their cunning ability to avert danger, though any brush with death leaves him shaken. On top of this, in Confrontation, the Rascal wins because he can leverage circumstances in his favor.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Trades

Archetype Abilities

Self Assured The Rascal is supremely confident where others are not. When they make a Confrontation Check, the first Skill or Conviction they add to the roll doesn’t add any additional Stress.

Grease Paint & Glitter The Rascal knows how to make dry knowledge come alive. When using a line of Reasoning, Skills gain 1 point + 1 for every 5 full points of difference, instead of the normal 1 per 10.

*Total Certainty The Rascal is one to truly believe what he says, if only for that moment. When using a Conviction for a Check, they add a roll of their Grit Die to that Check.

Lucky The Rascal is naturally blessed with the ability to get out of trouble and use that adrenaline that comes as death comes near to dodge the grim reaper and keep running. After the results are given, the Rascal can take 2 Stress to modify his results by 1. These may be done with the following conditions:

🜂

They can never be used to make you a better fighter. Stress gained this way can only be used to dodge death or escape a bad situation but never to make your character a superman.

🜂

The character must think of a situation that saves his rear end, something that happens to him that’s to his advantage.

The key here is that it can’t be impossible, but it can be highly improbable. The chandelier rope breaking right at that moment separating him from a blood thirsty guard, a pigeon flying across an archer’s view intercepting an arrow, etc. are all acceptable.

It can’t be the result of skill. Him deflecting the blade with his hand like a badass is right out.

Should the character be unable to think of a scenario that fits both of these criteria, he’s unable to gain Stress to save himself.

Allies of the Rascal soon find themselves infected with this luck and can use this ability for 3 Stress instead of the normal 2.

*Identity Focus (Conviction) As a Rascal grows, she becomes more confident in who she is and what she wants. At every level, including the first, you can increase the Rank of a Conviction by 1 or save it and gain a new Conviction at Rank 0 the next time you would gain a Rank.

*Skill Focus (Any, 2) At every level, including the first, Rascals receive 2 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

*Skill Focus (Intuition, 1) Through the course of her career, a Rascal develops a keen ability to read people and situations. They receive 1 free purchase of the Intuition Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

A Rascal favors no weapons as they tend to get you killed: All Ranged Weapon and Melee Skill Suites are 15 CrP more expensive and all Ranged and Melee Advanced Skills are 3 CrP more expensive.

Weird-adept Specialist Archetypes

Augur

Choose this Archetype if you want to a weird-adept with a wider of rotating range of strengths, giving some breathe of powers and greater power.

An Augur is one who watches the stars. The times and seasons are linked to the swirl of constellations overhead and the ways of magic. Those that watch them carefully can harness their power. An Augur gains bonuses based on the passage of time, making them change with the times.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore and Weirdcraft

Augurs receive 2 free purchases of Navigation Advanced Skill and 1 free purchase of Mathematics Advanced Skill.

Archetype Abilities

Daily Omen Boon
Day of the Week Tradition
1st Animism
2nd Calling
3rd Charm
4th Glamour
5th Investiture
6th Occult
7th Sortilege

Judicii Stellatum As part of their training, Augurs are taught how to harness the magic that drifts down from the stars and constellations. This gives them a steady pool of Spell Points whenever they cast a spell.

At their first total level, all spells the Augur casts have 7 SPs. This can be spent to modify the spell that they’re shaping. It does take a moment to summon the astral forces, so shaping a spell takes 3 seconds.

They increase this by 1 SP every odd total level, not including the first.

Bending reality and shaping primordial force is not an easy thing to do and nature doesn’t like it. When they first shape a spell, they take 1 Stress for every 10 Drain (rounded up) the spell has +5 for every Category above Never that their Fatigue Threshold is at (5 for Critical, 10 for Wounded, 15 for Bloodied, etc.). This is a one-time cost so continuing to shape the same spell doesn't further Stress them out (as long as they don't suffer weirdburn, of course).

Kanygandi Starblood is a 1st level Augur/Socialite is about to get into a Confrontation so decides that she wants to shape Charismatic Glamour. So, she breathes in the astral power, taking 3 seconds, and gains 7 SP. Or she would if she didn’t time this perfectly because today she rolled the Glamour Tradition so she gets an extra d4! SP (she rolls a 2) and if it wasn’t the 3rd week of the month and she got Aura which gives her another 1 Sp to work with. This gives her a total of 10 SP to work with.

*Lectio Cotidie At the beginning of each day, the Augur reads the signs and divines which of the astral winds, and thus which Weird Tradition, is most dominant on that day. This happens in a cycle based on the days of the week.

When shaping a spell from the Tradition linked to the day, the Augur receives an extra d4! SP to spend on that spell. This extra dice is increased by 1 size every 3 levels after the first.

If you lose track of the day of the week, you’ve lost track of the stars and don’t gain the bonus for that day.

Weekly Omen Boon
Week of the Month Category
1st Shape
2nd All
3rd Origin
4th All

*Signum Hebdomada The Augur knows each week brings a new fate and with it, new boons. The Augur gains an additional bonus of 1 SP whenever shaping a spell that applies to the particular Rudiment. This is increased by 1 SP every 5 levels after the first.

So, for instance, if this week is associated with Shape, roll on the Shape Rudiments Table found in Chapter 6:The Weird. If you roll, say Chain, all Chain spells you cast gain an additional SP.

If you lose track of which week, you’ve lost track of the stars and don’t gain the bonus for that week.

*Vestibulum Omen The calends are a special time, when the moon is new and the stars are able to shine; unfiltered, they empower the Augur. The Augur has a pool of Grit Dice equal to 2 + their level that they can use for spell shaping any time during the month.

This pool refreshes on the first day of every month.

If you miss the first day of the month, you’ve lost track of the stars and don’t gain the bonus for that month.

Libro Diebus An Augur keeps a Book of Days where they store their divination knowledge. They gain 3 Rudiments of their choice at 1st level and an additional, random Rudiment every odd level after.

*Skill Focus (Weirdcraft & Navigation) At every level, including the first, Augurs receive a free purchase of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite and Navigation Advanced Skill.

Primary Drawback

Augurs are extremely superstitious since everything is controlled by fate and the stars. Bad luck means a bad fate. They take 1 Stress every time they roll a 1 on a d20.

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double specialize in their Primary.

Augur Double Down

Judicii Stellatum

Their SPs are increased by 1.5 (rounded down) per total level.

Lectio Cotidie

Incease the number of SPs you get to a d6!.

Signum Hebdomada

This is increased to 1 additional SP for every 3 levels you’ve obtained.

Libro Diebus

This is increased to 5 additional Rudiments of their choice with a new, random one every level.

Mage

Choose this Archetype if you want to raw power and flexibility.

The mage is one that allows himself to be buffeted by the astral winds and so channels great power but also is in great danger. The mage has the most raw power of the Weird-Adept Archetypes but it could backfire on him.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite According to your Secondary Archetype

Archetype Abilities

Wild Magic Shaping The Mage is able to channel the power of the stars, harnessing it and creating magical energy. While doing so the weird-adept must stand still (forcing any Defense Checks to be on 2 dice sizes lower - usually 1d10!) and he glows with light, being illuminated by a column that reaches above them. This light is equivalent to a candle’s brightness.

After 7 seconds, the Mage gains their Spell Points. Unlike other Archetypes of this type, however, a lot is left up to chance. The Mage rolls randomly for the Shape and Origin of the spell and d3! SP that they can spend on the Effect (which you select after learning what the Shape and Origin is).

They also gain an additional d3! “free” SP that can either be spent on the Effect, or to modify what they rolled on the tables on a 1 to 1 basis.

When considering Drain, the Mage only has to worry about the Effect’s Base Drain and so, essentially, gets the other Rudiments for free. As long as he has more Spell Points than Drain, he can keep the spell cast.

So, for example, a level 3 Mage finishes channeling and casts Flash Bang. He rolls randomly and gets Circle, Double, and Aura, He rolls d8 and gets a 5 the Effect. He rolls his free dice and gets a 3. Since he’s shaping Flash Bang, he doesn’t want it to be an Aura (since he’ll be caught in it to), so he spends 2 of his free points to move it to “Near”, and then uses the final point to give him 6 SP so he can actually cast it.

Flash Bang has an Interval of 5 Seconds, so he subtracts 3 from 6 when he casts the spell and then, after 5 seconds, does so again to essentially recast it. As long as you have SPs you can keep a spell active.

You can also suffer weirdburn from keeping a spell up too long: if your spell’s Drain is greater than your current SP, the spell is still cast, but you and everyone within 200 ft takes 1 Stress for every point you’re over.

Going back to the above example: if you have 9 SP, and you keep the spell up for 15 seconds, you and those within 200 ft take 4 Stress ( 20 - 3 - 3 ). Should you continue to keep the spell up, you’d take an additional 3 Stress every 5 seconds.

It is recommended that even though you don’t technically get those points until after that 7 second duration, that you roll everything ahead of time and figure out what you’re going to cast ahead of time. The GM is not obliged to stop the count for you if you haven’t been spending those 7 seconds wisely.

You can stop shaping at any time; however, you take Stress equal to the amount of SP you have left - Weird is a powerful primal force and once unleashed, it is not stopped without cost. You also cannot cast or keep up a spell and Channel. This doesn’t remove those SP but the Mage does lose 1 SP every 6 seconds.

Bending reality and shaping primordial force is not an easy thing to do and nature doesn’t like it. When they first shape a spell, they take 1 Stress for every 10 Drain (rounded up) the spell has +5 for every Category above Never that their Fatigue Threshold is at (5 for Critical, 10 for Wounded, 15 for Bloodied, etc.). This is a one-time cost so continuing to shape the same spell doesn't further Stress them out (as long as they don't suffer weirdburn, of course).

Channeling in Armor

Wild Magic Users (Mages and Wizards) both draw their power from the stars. As such, anything that gets between them and this, makes channeling more difficult. While this is negligible while wearing clothing, armor, being a mite bit heavier, does slowdown Spell Point acquisition.

🜂

Light Armor increases channeling time by 5.

🜂

Medium Armor increases it by 10.

🜂

Heavy Armor increase it by 15.

Wild Surge Conduit The Mage puts himself more at danger than other casts but is able to experience greater power. If the total number of SP from channeling is greater than 4 + total level, a Wild Surge occurs.

In addition to whatever happens with the spell, it is also recast. The new version, however, is Circularly Shaped, with an Origin of either Aura or Far, and its Range doubled as the weird-adept sees fit. They also take Stress equal to how much they were over.

Empowered Channeling A Mage relies on an innate understanding of the flow of magic through his body and overtime he can increase its effectiveness.

For every total level, not including the first, the Mage can either increase the size of any 1 of his dice by 1, or decrease her channeling time by 1, down to a minimum of 3 seconds.

*Astral Fulcrum There is nothing between the Mage and the raw Weird and that allows her to force what others can't. The Mage can take 10 Stress in which case they gain all their SP in the first second. This is in addition to the normal Fallout.

However, they still need to complete the channeling: if they don't, they receive an additional 10 Stress. As they become more powerful, however, they learn how to mitigate that danger, lowering the Stress inflicted by 1 every 4 levels after the first.

Unlearn Dogma As the Mage grows in power, they can set aside things that are holding them back. At every level, including the first, a Mage can forget a non-Effect Rudiment. If they do so, they gain an Effect Rudiment of their choice.

Method Of Loci A Mage gains 2 new, random Rudiments at 1st level and an additional Rudiment every odd level, not including the first. Any new Rudiments must be Effect Rudiments.

Primary Drawback

The Mage rejects martial prowess as a role and so all Ranged Weapon and Melee Skill Suites are 15 CrP more expensive and all Ranged and Melee Advanced Skills are 3 CrP more expensive.

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double specialize in their Primary.

Mage Double Down

Skills

Double Down Mages gain 2 purchases of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite.

Wild Magic Shaping

Increase all channeling dice to d4!s

Wild Surge Conduit

Increase your Wild Surge threshold becomes 5 + (total level * 2)

Empowered Channeling

This ability now starts at first level. Your free dice automatically increases every 3 total levels. This is in addition to the normal increase.

Method Of Loci

Gain a new, random Rudiment every level but only gain the normal number of Rudiments for specializing (2).

Runegalder

Choose this Archetype if you want to play a weird-adept and are familiar with other games' spellcasters.

Unlike other magic-users, the Runegalder seals magical power in his bond, allowing him to not risk his body when working with supernatural forces. This allows him to cast quickly and consistently but limits the amount and flexibility of his spells.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore and Weirdcraft

Runegalders receive 3 free purchases of Literacy in their native language.

Archetype Abilities

Vancian Shaping The Runegalder chains the power of spells to various runes that he then invests, sealing them with his blood until he’s ready to release them.

Every 24 hours, the Runegalder can seal 3 spells. He can also bind an additional spell for every 3 total levels he’s obtained. This means that he may cast those spells at any time by simply speaking the rune they’re linked to, once prepared.

Speaking the rune releases it from its binding so speaking the same rune again before he’s resealed it will not recast the spell - the spell’s power is gone.

He may cast a spell multiple times per day, but he’ll need to bind each instance of the spell to a different rune.

He may also unseal a rune without actually shaping it, but he is not able to immediately reseal a new rune right after.

The Runegalder's magic is 'dead' and so is less potent than other types of magic, thus allowing some to shrug off their spells. When someone Resists their spells, the Runegalder rolls a d12! instead of a d20!.

Arcane Components The Runegalder gains 3 additional random Rudiments and gains an additional 2 random Rudiments every level, not including the first.

Grimoire This is the Runegalder’s spell book and keeps the spells that he binds to runes. Unlike a normal spell book, however, the spells are scribed in meteorite ink and blood that seals their magic power in the text itself. This means that the Runegalder’s Grimoire does the channeling latently for him.

At first level, he constructs 3 spells using his known Rudiments and an additional 1 every total level after that. These spells can’t have a Drain greater than 7 + their total level (so at 1st level, his spells can only have a Drain of 8) when it is scribed into the Grimoire. A spell’s Rudiments cannot be redistributed and changed: spells in the Grimoire are immutable.

So, a 2nd level Runegalder scribes a new spell. He can max out at 7 Drain. He chooses to make it a Wall Shape, Near Origin (5 Drain) and for its Effect, he chooses Disorient (2 Drain), for a total of 7. He could have also made it Chain Shape instead for 1 Drain, and Stacked the Disorient Effect, if he wanted.

Note that spells cast by the Runegalder only last their Interval unless their Effect is stacked, in which case, it either increases that Interval by a like amount or gains the Stacking bonus but not both. This is decided when the spell is cast.

Spells inscribed at different levels count as completely different spells and must be sealed to different runes. So, if the Runegalder has a 8 SP Flash Grenade and a 11 SP Flash Grenade, he would need two runes to cast both. He couldn’t simply bind “Flash Grenade” to one rune and then choose which he wanted to use in the moment.

*Skill Focus (Weirdcraft, 1) Through the course of her career, a Runegalder seeks to further their knowledge of the occult. They receive 1 free purchase of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite at every odd level, including the first.

Primary Drawback

The Runegalder uses his body as a prison for latent magical energies which wears on a person over time. He ages at twice the normal rate.

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double specialize in their Primary.

Runegalder Double Down

Vancian Casting

You can seal a new spell every other total level.

Arcane Components

You start with 1 additional random Rudiment and gain 3 each level.

Grimoire

New spells have 8 + ( total level x 2 ) Drain.

Skill Focus

Skill Focus is increased to every level.

Sourcerer

Choose this Archetype if you want to extremely power and flexibility but don't mind waiting around a bit for it.

An ethereal being in a physical world, the Sourcerer draws his magic from an internal well within them. As such, they don’t cast spells so much as manifest them into existence. Unlike most other weird-adepts, the Sourcerer doesn’t rely on luck or Astral Winds, but instead generates power from within. This is a slower process making Sourcerers less helpful in the moment but more powerful given a bit of time.

Vitality Die

d8

Skills

Main Skill Suite According to your Secondary Archetype

Archetype Abilities

Manifest Sourcery Whether born under a certain constellation or through a long-lost bloodline, the Sourcerer has a special connection to the Painted World. They’re a font of magic, making them very powerful and very dangerous.

Drawing from within is consistent but takes time. Every 10 seconds, you add the 10s digit of the number of SP’s in your pool into your SP pool, minimum 1. So, after 50 seconds of manifesting, you would have 15 SPs ( 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 = 15 ).

Sourcerers can continue to Manifest for as long as they want, however, this power comes with a price. Being a conduit of the unworldly saps their life and every time they add SPs to their pool, they take damage equal to that pool. This is all on one Wound but different periods of Manifest are different Wounds.

Manifesting requires light concentration so they can do other things while shaping spells but if it’s something particularly difficult (like combat or doing mathematics), the Manifesting time is doubled. You can also stop Manifesting at any time but your SP pool will atrophy at the rate of 1 SP per 6 seconds.

Rechard is a 1st level Sourcerer/Expert who is looking to shape Eiderdown before making his ascent of Deadman’s Cliff. After 10 seconds of manifesting, he receives 1 SP, after another 10 seconds, he receives another, giving him a total of 2. After a total of 100 seconds, he has 20 SP in his pool so, at 110 seconds, instead of receiving 1 SP, he now receives 2 SP, so now he has 22 SP. After 150 seconds, he’s up to 30 SP and so now, every 10 seconds, he gets 3 SP instead.

However, he stops there because he only has 31 Vitality and so, while he gets 30 SP, he takes 30 damage, no doubt traumatizing him, but, at least, if he falls, he’ll do so slowly.

Power Overwhelming As the Sourcerer grows, they also grow in power and can stay between two worlds longer. They reduce the amount of damage taken from manifesting by 9 + their total level, though they always take at least 1 damage.

Tradition Attuned A Sourcerer is always attuned to a certain Weird Tradition and, at 1st level, knows all Effects from that Tradition and 1 random Rudiment of each other type besides that (Shape & Origin). Starting at 2nd, you can choose a second Tradition. At these level and at every other level you obtain, you may select an Effect from that secondary Tradition or roll for another random Rudiment. At 11th level you gain access to a 3rd Tradition's Effects.

*Dragon Skin A Sourcerer is a well of Weird, therefore, to some exact, can absorb Weird that is thrown at them but it comes at a cost. When affected by a spell, the Sourcerer can increase the Drain of that spell by their level.

Primary Drawback

Because of Sourcerer is basically a native of another world, their bodies do all they can to shlof off the mortal coil. Every Wound takes 1 day longer to heal

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double specialize in their Primary.

Sourcerer Double Down

Power Overwhelming

This is increased to 12 + twice your total level.

Tradition Attuned

At 1st level you are attuned to 2 Traditions, knowing all the Effects from both. Starting at 2nd level and another time at 8th level and another time at 15th, you can choose another Tradition. At this level and at every level you obtain, you may select an Effect from any available Tradition.

Speaker

Choose this Archetype if you want to shape spells quickly and consistently.

There is the surface level of things and then there’s how things truly are. By striking the threads of magic, a Speaker is able to touch reality and bend it to her will, changing it as she pleases. The Speaker has a variable amount of Spell Points available to her, giving her some breathing room as well as more flexibility when it comes to shaping times.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suite Lore

Archetype Abilities

Adamic Command To know the First Language is to know the words of the Divines, heard as whispers on the mortal plane. Speakers spend decades learning to correctly pronounce each syllable and its meaning; learning the subtleties that each inflection brings. As they grow in power, the words they speak take on more power.

Once the Speaker decides what their spell will look like (Shape, Origin, and Effect(s), and how many Intervals it'll be) and what its Drain will be, they roll 3d3 (note that these dice don’t explode). If the result is equal to or higher than the Drain cost, the spell comes into being, otherwise, the spell fails if the Speaker doesn't take weirdburn: nothing happens although the attempt doesn't add to their Stress gain for later attempts. The Speaker is free to roll less dice and/or smaller dice, if they so desire.

If the Speakers have "left over" SP, they can take weirdburn to gain an extra Interval as per normal, but they most decide to do so when they initially speak the Words of Power.

Speaking words of power takes actually time, specifically 1 seconds per dice rolled.

When you roll your Dice Pool, if you roll 3 or more 1s, the Speaker has made a major mispronunciation and the GM rolls for a random Effect from a random Tradition but with otherwise identical dimensions to the spell the Speaker wished to cast.

Bending reality and shaping primordial force is not an easy thing to do and nature doesn’t like it so Speakers gain Stress when they first speak a word of power equal to 1 Stress for every 10 Drain (rounded up) the spell has - their total level + number of spells cast in the last 24 hours down to a minimum of 1.

Ciline Wordwise is a 1st level Speaker/Socialite and finds herself being forcibly escorted to a meeting with Blind Kalamen, the local mob boss. Thinking quickly, she decides to shape a Circle, Burst, Flatten Spell which will cost her 8 Drain. Decides that she has to do it quickly, before the thugs can react, so she decides to say the spell in one word, rolling 1d3 for SP.

She rolls a 3 but still Weirdburns for the remaining 5, giving her a total of 6 Stress, since it was the first spell she spoke that day, she would have only gained 1 Stress if she had succeeded (1 for the Drain - 1 for her level + 0 for the number of spells she’s spoken + 5 for the Weirdburn).

With that, she Flattens both thugs holding her and books it for the nearest safehouse.

Diction Training As a Speaker gains experience, she becomes more able to get around the trickier parts of the Divine syntax and so can add more force and power to her spells. For every total level, not including the first, she may either add another d3 to her Adamic dice pool or increase the size of one of those dice by 1 dice size (up to a d12).

Lexicon A Speaker starts with 2 additional random power words or Rudiments to start off. They gain an additional random Rudiment every odd level, not including the first.

*Skill Focus (Special) Through the course of her career, a Speaker seeks to further their knowledge of the occult. They receive 1 free purchase of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite at every level, including the first.

*Skill Focus (Language, 2) Through the course of her career, a Speaker seeks to further their knowledge of the languages. They receive 2 free purchases of the Language Advanced Skill at every level, including the first.

Polyglot Speakers naturally pick up languages in ways that others can only dream of. They start with 2 additional Languages with Ranks equal to half their Int stat.

Also, the cost for purchasing languages is halved.

Primary Drawback

Obviously, Speakers can’t have the Stutterer or Mute Flaws. Gaining either of those two Flaws prevents them from shaping.

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double specialize in their Primary.

Speaker Double Down

Adamic Command

Your starting Adamic dice pool starts at a 4d4s

Diction Training

You add d4s instead. You can also go up to d20.

Lexicon

You gain a new Power Word every level instead of every other level but only gain the normal number of Power Words for specializing (2).

Skill Focus (Language, 1)

This is increased to 4 free purchases every level.

Warlock

Choose this Archetype if you don't mind your power coming from the blood of both friend and foe alike.

The Warlock has gone down a dark path and has begun to unlock the innate magic in all living creatures. As such, they tend to be social pariahs because the process of extracting that magic is random and painful. Still all power has a price and Warlocks happily pay it.

Vitality Die

d6

Skills

Main Skill Suite Weirdcraft Twice

Archetype Abilities

The Blood Pact The Warlock has performed a secret ritual and has joined the Blood Pact, allowing a Warlock to instantly pull Weird from the living creatures around him.

This gives him 1 SP per second per person within 10 ft but deals that amount of damage to those he’s pulling from. This includes himself but he also takes an additional damage per second.

This blood pull is unaffected by armor but is blocked by other living beings and total cover, if they’re closer. Essentially, if a person would give you cover from a ranged attack, they also protect you from the blood pull.

Otherwise these SPs act exactly like normal and can be instantly used to shape a spell.

This amount is increased by 1 SP and damage per second every 6 total levels.

This pull is not stealthy at all as the blood is torn from skin and flies to the Warlock. Additionally, it is reflexive so the Warlock can do other things but it is not fully controlled and goes on for a minimum of d4! Seconds. A warlock may shape and keep up a spell even when pulling.

After a number of seconds of not gaining anymore SP (even if the pull is active) equal to the Warlock's total level, they begin to lose their power. Every second, they lose half their current SPs, rounded up.

Raphail is a 1st level Warlock/Fighter who has just engaged in an honor duel with his rival, Endrie. As they size each other up, Raphael begins to Pull, dealing 1 damage to Endrie and himself but gaining 3 SP (1 Sp from Endrie’s damage and 2 from his own since his blood is worth more). At that point, Endrie launches forward and slashes Raphail across the chest (giving the warlock another 2 SP), which Raphail returns, cutting his face (and giving the warlock another 1 SP for a total of 6). This same second, Raphail continues to pull, dishing out another 1 damage each and gaining 3 more SP for a total of 9.

At this point, Raphail uses the SP to instantly Shape a Burst, Circle, Weaken spell, weakening Endrie’s blade and allowing him to parry it easily the next second.

*Waste Not Even when not actively pulling, blood has an innate attraction to the Warlock.

Anytime anyone within 25 ft of him takes damage, part of the spilled blood is drawn to the Warlock, giving him 1 SP. They gain an additional 1 SP every 5 total levels after the first. This is regardless of how much damage was dealt.

They may use this SP to shape a spell on the same second they get get the SP: it requires no effort or concentration.

Otherwise, this behaves (and stacks with) the blood pull (including being blocked by others).

Drain The Vessel A Warlock’s own blood is seething in the Weird of the Pact: each damage he takes from the blood pull is worth double the SPs.

Font Of Power A Warlock’s spells doesn’t come from an outside force but is, instead, projected from him. This means that they get the Aura and Burst Rudiments for free but can't take any other Origin Rudiments.

Forbidden Knowledge A Warlock gains 2 additional random Rudiment at 1st level and an additional Rudiment every odd level after.

*Skill Focus (Weirdcraft, 1) Through the course of her career, a Warlock seeks to further their knowledge of the occult. They receive 1 free purchase of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite at every odd level up, including the first.

Primary Drawback

People don’t like Blood Magic. By most people’s standards, even at its best, it’s dangerous and random and so Warlocks are not well liked. Warlocks are considered 1 level lower on the Starting Bias (default Dislike) for everyone that knows they’re a Warlock.

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double specialize in their Primary.

Warlock Double Down

The Blood Pact

You now pull blood (and SP) from every person within 20 ft and increases by 1 Damage and SP for every 5 total levels.

Forbidden Knowledge

Gain a new Rudiment every level but only gain the normal number of Rudiments for specializing (2).

Wizard

Choose this Archetype if you power and flexibility but don't mind sacrificing a bit of power for a bit more stability.

Wizards, make no mistake, are still Wild Magic weird-adepts and are no wimps when it comes to raw power, but unlike the Mage that completely gives himself over to the whims of magic, the Wizard uses his study and training to lower the hills and increase the troughs, giving more consistency.

Vitality Die

d4

Skills

Main Skill Suites Weirdcraft and Lore

Archetype Abilities

Wild Magic Shaping The Wizard is able to channel the power of the stars, harnessing it and creating magical energy. While doing so the weird-adept must stand still (forcing any Defense Checks to be on 2 dice sizes lower - usually 1d10!) and he glows with light, being illuminated by a column that reaches above them. This light is equivalent to a candle’s brightness (10 ft radius of Bright Illumination, 5 ft of Dim beyond).

After 10 seconds, the Wizard gains d10! Spell Points (SP), which is a single pool that can be spent to shape the Weird on the fly out of any Rudiments he knows. The spell’s Drain is then subtracted from the Wizard’s Spell Point pool when he casts it and at the Interval. As long as he has more Spell Points than Drain, he can keep the spell cast.

Let’s say that you have a spell that is Shaped like a Cone, an Origin of Aura (Drain 3), and has a Base Drain of 6 from its Effect. That means the Drain of that spell is 9 ( 3 + 6 ).

It is recommended that even though you don’t technically get those points until after that 10 second duration, that you roll your SP ahead of time and figure out what you’re going to cast ahead of time. The GM is not obliged to stop the count for you if you haven’t been spending those 10 seconds wisely.

This channeling dice increased by 1 size every odd total level, not including the first.

You can stop shaping at any time; however, you take Stress equal to the amount of SP you have left - Weird is a powerful primal force and once unleashed, it is not stopped without cost. You also cannot cast or keep up a spell and Channel. This doesn’t remove those SP but the Wizard does lose 1 SP every 6 seconds.

Wild Magic comes with some additional dangers, however. Should the Wizard roll more SPs than 8 + his total level, he suffers a Wild Surge but untrained in it, he is unable to use it to the best of his ability.

The spell is recast, however, its Circularly Shaped, with an Aura Origin and its Range is doubled. They also take Stress equal to how much they were over.

Bending reality and shaping primordial force is not an easy thing to do and nature doesn’t like it. When they first shape a spell, they take 1 Stress for every 10 Drain (rounded up) the spell has +5 for every Category above Never that their Fatigue Threshold is at (5 for Critical, 10 for Wounded, 15 for Bloodied, etc.). This is a one-time cost so continuing to shape the same spell doesn't further Stress them out (as long as they don't suffer weirdburn, of course).

Jodit is a 1st level Wizard/Expert who is looking to learn a little bit more about an item she’s come across so she goes to Shape the Personal, Touch, Lore Mysterium spell, which is a 5-Drain spell. After 10 seconds of mild glowing and a little bit of concentration, she rolls a d10 and the roll explodes for a total of 14. This causes a Wild Surge that reshapes the spell, affecting a huge area.

This works out for her though because it still catches the item she wants in the area of effect and she gets to renew the spell twice - thrice if she wants the extra Stress but she’s already getting 5 Stress from the Wild Surge (14 - 9, her threshold) and an additional 6 from just the normal fallout.

Weird Medium The Wizard is a bit more impersonal with his relationship with the Weird, preferring to use Weird Mediums as the fulcrum of the Weird around him. At first level, he may choose one from the following list.

Should he find himself without his Weird Medium, he’s in trouble. His threshold for Wild Surges drops to 5 regardless of level. The wizard can replace their Weird Medium but it takes 5 CrP (which doesn't count towards their next level) and 2 weeks. They may not change what their Weird Medium type is.

Weird Mediums List

Ancestor Bones

This magic user was gifted the bones of his ancestors, powerful wizards from ages past that are able to give their descendants some of their prowess.

At 1st level, a Wizard with Ancestor Bones on their person lowers his channeling time by 1 second. He also lowers it by an additional second for every 5 levels he’s obtained, down to a minimum of 2.

Invested Item

This Medium comes in many shapes and sizes. By binding her soul to an item, a Wizard can make a metal object an extension of her power.

While holding this item, she may cast any spell as if the hand was free. For armor, the Invested Item offsets the penalty to shaping by 1 Drain for every 5 levels the Wizard has obtained. This can only offset the penalty, and never lower it below the base speed. For weapons and other items, they may also cast spells with a Touch Origin on a successful hit, storing one spell indefinitely until it’s used. If it is a ranged weapon, Touch spells are cast from the ammunition. Needless to say, this a much favored Medium of battle mages.

Orb

These are often called a Seer’s Orb, as this is favored by Wizards of the Occultism Tradition. Orbs are often glass, but those of other materials are not uncommon, though they tend to be precious metals or stones. The only requirement is that they’re larger than your fist. When held, Orbs bend reality, gaining an automatic increase to any spell’s Range by half of its Base Range for every 3 levels of the Wizard.

Spell Book

A large tome, traditionally, the spell book is the favored Medium of the more scholarly magic user.

The Spell Book is not simply incantations jotted down or notes about rituals - it’s an extension of the Wizard’s brain. As long as he’s touching it, he automatically gains the ability to shape using any Rudiment in the book.

Wizards who select this Weird Medium gain 2 extra starting Rudiments, however, these are only stored in their Book. They also gain a new Rudiment every 3 levels, which is also stored there, meaning that if they lose the book, they lose those Rudiments.

Spell Tattoos

Painted Men are common in the frozen tundraof Askemark. The metal heavy ink serves to store channeled magic and allows the Wizard to keep invested power for longer.

With Spell Tattoos, the time it takes to lose a SP when not channeling is doubled for every 4 levels the Wizard has obtained. This also lowers the Stress taken from stopping a spell with SP left by 1 per every 3 levels.

Stave

Traditionally made of holly wood harvested with a silver sickle at midnight on the night of the new moon, Staves serve as extensions of the Wizard’s soul, much like an Invested Item, but because it’s not made of metal, it holds different properties.
