While welding a Stave in one hand, the Wizard offsets the Fallout from shaping a spell by 1 every 3 levels the Wizard has obtained. This can't lower it below 0, however, but does extend to the people within 50 ft of them as well.

Familiar

Favored by the traveling Wizard, a familiar is a small animal or homunculus that is bonded to the Wizard’s soul. Because of this connection, a wizard can see and hear through their Familiar’s eyes and ears with they within 100 ft and channel SP through it as long as it is standing still and also within 100 ft of the wizard, allowing the Wizard full movement even when channeling. Whomsever is channeling (the wizard or the familiar) is the one that glows as well.

Wizards can also telepathically relate commands to their familiar, regardless of the distance, however, this is a one-way line of communication and the familiar cannot communicate anything back.

Familiars are small sized creatures. The player selects three candidates, but the GM makes the final decision on which creature came when she called, unless the Wizard opts to have built herself a homunculus.

A Wizard who would get 2 Weird Mediums but chooses familiar twice may select a medium or large sized creature, using the normal method, or any small sized creature of her choice.

Wand

The Wand is an exact tool, a tool of precision. It is favored by more aggressive spell weird-adepts because it makes their spells hard to resist.

While shaping with a Wand in hand, the Wizard gains a free Stack of one of the spell’s Effect Rudiments for every 3 levels they’ve obtained.

Syllabus A Wizard gains 3 random Rudiments at 1st level and an additional Rudiment every odd level after.

*Skill Focus (Weirdcraft, 1) Through the course of her career, a Wizard seeks to further their knowledge of the occult. They receive 1 free purchase of the Weirdcraft Skill Suite at every odd level, including the first.

Skill Adept This character has a knack for skills. All non-Combat Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all non-Combat Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

Primary Drawback

The Wizard’s study can sometimes leave her with a divorced relationship to reality that can make them somewhat obtuse. When using Convictions and Devotions, they roll a d12! on their Check.

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Weird-Adept Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double specialize in their Primary.

Wizard Double Down

Wild Magic Shaping

Channeling dice is increased to d20! and increases every total level. Wild Magic threshold becomes 9 + ( total level x 3 ).

Weird Medium

You get two and need to lose both before suffering penalties.

Syllabus

Gain a new Rudiment every level and increase the number of Rudiments gained to 4.

Skill Focus

This is increased to every level

Chapter 3Archetypes

Flaws

Every person has flaws; markers of an eventful life, good or bad. Oftentimes they’re artifacts of a hard life, like a soldier who is missing an arm.

Flaw Severity

Flaws have a Severity that denotes how serious they are.

What this specifically means will be unique to the Flaw as some are worse than others just as a base line (hence the variable CrP bonuses).

All Flaws start at Severity 1 but you can choose to increase them as much as you want, up to the Severity Cap, at the time of rolling or picking.

Note that some Flaws have a Severity cap (you can only get so blind, afterall), which is noted.

Unsure of the Severity?

If you're not sure what your Flaw's Severity should be, you can just roll a d3 and use that for your Severity. That will work for most Flaws, except for Missing Eye.

Flaw CrP Bonus

All Flaws give you CrP that you can turn around and use to make your character stronger in other ways. The total bonus is Base Crp + (Severity * Per Severity). If you increase a Flaw's Severity later, you gain the difference. So, taking the Fated Flaw at Severity 3 gives you 43 CrP ( 13 + (10 * 3) ). Increasing it up to 5 later gives you an additional 20 CrP.

Flaw Rank

Flaws can sometimes be applied to a Check, sometimes as a bonus and sometimes as a penatly. Either way, you'll need to know what its Rank is.

So, if you have the Ageusia Flaw at Severity 4, its Rank would be 2 since you round up ( .67 + ( 4 * .33 ) ).

Recording Flaws

When recording Flaws on your character sheet, you'll typically want to do it like so:

Deaf (3) 4

The number in parentheses is the Severity and the number to the side is the Rank, in case it comes up in a Confrontation.

Roleplaying Out Flaws

Flaws never give you permission to cross lines or make people uncomfortable, whatever side of the screen you're on.

On the flip side, don't take Flaws that you would be, on some level, uncomfortable roleplaying out. If you have any doubt, discuss with your GM and other players before the game starts and, if you're still unsure, spend the CrP to reroll.

Conflicting Flaws

It is perfectly fine to have conflicting Flaws because people are like that sometimes.

Starting Flaws

There are two ways to select Flaws: Rolling and Cherry Picking. Rolling gives you more CrP per Flaw but Cherry Picking gives you more control. You must commit to one: you cannot start by rolling and then Cherry Pick. You cannot choose to do both and choose the one you like more, either - once you start down the path, you're on it.

Rolling Flaws

Flaw Table
Roll (d6) Table
{{table.weight > 1 ? (table.currentTotal + 1) + ' - ' + (table.currentTotal + table.weight) : table.currentTotal}} {{table.tableName}}

Roll on the following Flaw Table and then on the corresponding table.

You can spend 1 CrP to reroll at any time for either table but once you’ve committed to rolling for a Flaw, you have to roll.

Each Flaw after the first loses 5 CrP of its value per previous Flaw to a minimum of 0 CrP received. So, the 3rd Flaw you roll will be at a -10 CrP.

If you roll the same Flaws twice, you have to increase its Severity by at least 1. You may choose to further increase its Severity at this time as normal. If you’ve already reached the cap of that Flaw, you reroll for free.

Background Flaws
Roll (d100) Name CrP Base Per Severity Severity Cap
{{flaw.weight > 1 ? (flaw.currentTotal + 1) + ' - ' + (flaw.currentTotal + flaw.weight) : flaw.currentTotal}} {{flaw.flaw}} {{flaw.bonus}} {{flaw.severity}} {{flaw.cap}}
Mental Flaws
Roll (d100) Name CrP Base Per Severity Severity Cap
{{flaw.weight > 1 ? (flaw.currentTotal + 1) + ' - ' + (flaw.currentTotal + flaw.weight) : flaw.currentTotal}} {{flaw.flaw}} {{flaw.bonus}} {{flaw.severity}} {{flaw.cap}}
Physical Flaws
Roll (d100) Name CrP Base Per Severity Severity Cap
{{flaw.weight > 1 ? (flaw.currentTotal + 1) + ' - ' + (flaw.currentTotal + flaw.weight) : flaw.currentTotal + 1}} {{flaw.flaw}} {{flaw.bonus}} {{flaw.severity}} {{flaw.cap}}

Random Flaw Roller

If you don't have dice at the ready, you can always get a random flaw by pushing the button below:

Parent Table:

{{flaw.parentTable.tableName}}

Flaw:

{{flaw.flaw.flaw}}

Reroll Count: {{rerollCount}}

Cherry Picking Flaws

For the roleplayers among us with a specific character idea in mind, you may Cherry Pick your Flaws.

Each Flaw after the first loses 10 CrP of its value per Flaw to a minimum of 0 CrP received. So, the 3rd Flaw you pick will be at a -20 CrP.

Flaw Descriptions

Addict

Addiction Table
Roll (d6) Addiction
1 Gambling
2 Shopping
3 Drinking
4 Narcotics
5 Sex
6 Adrenaline

CrP Base 19

Per Severity 2

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 per Severity

This character is unable to control themselves around a particular substance or finds it hard to keep themselves from performing a particular action. This is most commonly true when they're Stress and then find it's the only way to truly relax.

This character gains half the Relaxation from things not related to their addiction until they satisfy it in some way.

Should they come across an opportunity to indulge, they'll need to succeed at a Confrontation Check against this Flaw to resist. Indulging in this way doesn't heal Stress or give Relaxation and might come with other problems (such as a loss of cash, time, or brain power, or chance of disease or fatherhood).

Ageusia

CrP Base 7

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 10

Rank .67 + .33 per Severity, rounded up

This means that the character is lacking the ability to taste.

While fairly minor, it means that this character won’t heal Stress from food the same way that others will: subtract this Flaw’s Severity from the Relaxation you would get from a meal to a minimum of 0.

Allergy, Food

Food Allergen Table
Roll (d8) Allergen
1 Shellfish
2 Eggs
3 Peanut
4 Milk
5 Soy
6 Wheat
7 Tree Nut
8 Fish

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 10

Rank .67 + .33 per Severity, round up

This character’s immune system is wired a little differently and will trigger at things that are normally safe, ironically, making them actually dangerous to ingest.

When a character eats a food they’re allergic to, they’re treated as if they’ve just ingested a poison.

It’s treated as 3d3!/1 Min/Con. Add an additional 1d3! per Severity to the Lethality .

Players who don’t call out that they’re looking for their allergen when eating new or strange food have a 5% chance of eating it before they realize it’s there, thus triggering this Flaw.

This Flaw can be taken multiple times for different allergens, each counted as their own separate Flaw with its own Severity.

You can, of course, choose whatever allergy you feel fits your character, but we’ve provided a table you can use to generate one for you.

Allergy, Misc

Misc. Allergen Table
Roll (d4) Allergen
1 Pollen
2 Dust/Mold
3 Animal Dander
4 Insects

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 10

Rank .67 + .33 per Severity, round up

This character’s immune system is wired a little differently and will trigger at things that are normally safe, ironically, making them actually dangerous to smell.

When a character breathes in something they’re allergic to, they’re treated as if they just ingested a poison.

For airborne allergen , it’s 3d12!/1 Hour/1 Stress. It deals an additional Stress per Severity.

If the allergen causes a Mental Break, it starts dealing damage instead.

This Flaw can be taken multiple times for different allergens, each counted as their own separate Flaw with its own Severity.

You can, of course, choose whatever allergy you feel fits your character, but we’ve provided a table you can use to generate one for you.

Asthmatic

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 per Severity

This character has a condition that causes their lungs and breathing ways to constrict if put under too much pressure, sometimes, resulting in death.

Anytime you take damage or Stress from fatigue (for example, from an Athletics Check or from running or sprinting), you take an additional amount of damage equal to your Severity.

If you just took Stress, you still take this damage.

Atheist

CrP Base 7

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 12

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

The way of the divine is a mysterious path, and it is possible for someone to mistake it for no path at all. Some refuse to believe that intelligent higher powers exist and so forfeit some of the blessings while others find worshiping such beings laughable, like giving reverence to the biggest bully on the block.

Either way, when spending Favor Dice or having Favor Dice spent on them for a beneficial reason, they reduce each dice roll by this Flaw’s Severity.

Bastard

CrP Base 17

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 5

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

Being a bastard means you're illegitimate but not abandoned by one or more of your parents. While that may seem minor nowadays, being a bastard in a pre-industrial society was a big deal and would come with stigma that would follow the character through their life.

At the end of each session, the bastard reduces the amount of Integrity gained by 1 for every point of Severity.

Additionally, they often get less than their full siblings: when selecting kits, remove 30 sc of starting equipment and/or starting cash per point of Severity, rounded down.

Blind

CrP Base 17

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 6

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

This character has lost some or all of their sight, ranging from things being blurred colors to being completely black or white.

In melee combat or when making Checks that involve sight, they roll a dice shrunk a number of sizes equal to their Severity.

And ranged combat is right out, however, if you insist, you’ll be attacking and defending with dice shrunk a number of sizes equal to twice their Severity, so enjoy your fumbles, you stubborn bastard.

Burn Scars

Burn Location Table
Roll (d4) Location
1 Head
2 Body
3 Arms & Hands
4 Legs

CrP Base *

Per Severity *

Severity Cap *

This character’s body is covered with burn scars from some horrible accident in the past.

The exact location, penalty, and therefore, CrP Base, is dependent on the location.

This Flaw can be taken multiple times with each location counting as a new Flaw. If you already have a burn in a location, you may increase its Severity as per usual or spend a CrP to reroll.

Burn Scar Locations

Head

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 5

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This location makes the person hard to look at but can also create issues with communication. When needing to make a Language Check, this character receives a penalty equal to this Flaw’s Severity.

When used in a Confrontation, this Flaw adds its full Severity either as a bonus or as a penalty.

Body

CrP Base 17

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

Burns on the body might seem minor but actually, depending on the Severity, they can inhibit sweat production which means that the character is unable to regulate their body temperature effectively.

When Running or Sprinting, lower the time between taking damage by 1 for each point of Severity to a minimum of 1.

The character is also considered 5 degrees warmer or colder for each point of Severity in harsh weather.

Arms & Hands

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 per Severity

The arms and hands can create issues for maneuverability and fine dexterity.

The character increases their Recovery with all weapons by 1 for every 3 points of Severity.

On top of that, when trying to perform Checks that require manual dexterity, they gain a penalty equal to their Severity.

Legs

CrP Base 17

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 5

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

This location, like the arms, can create issues with mobility.

This character takes 1 extra second per point of Severity to move up or down a Movement Category.

Craven

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 4

Rank 1.5 per Severity, round up

This character has problems keeping their panic under control when the going gets tough.

For every point of Severity, lower the character’s starting Panic Threshold by 1 step. Nothing can be done to reverse this except buying this Flaw down.

Deaf

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 6

Rank 1 per Severity

This character has lost some or all of their ability to hear, either having sounds come in jumbled or quiet or simply not being able to hear at all.

This means that, for Checks involving sound, they shrink their dice 1 size for every point of Severity.

Additionally, they’re much slower to react: if they can’t see a threat, they increase their Initiative Dice by 1 for every point of Severity.

Debtor

CrP Base 7

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 5

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character has gotten into trouble financially.

They start with 100 sc of debt for every point of Severity. He can sell off as much of their initial equipment as they’d like to help pay this off but they're also no longer allowed to cash CrP in for sc at Step 10.

If they don’t make payments on it, they may find themselves on the bad end of the law or the loan shark they borrowed from but, at the very least, it’s a black mark against them and so they lose Integrity equal to their Severity at the end of every session unless they paid off some of the debt.

Deranged

CrP Base 33

Per Severity 8

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1.5 + 1.5 per Severity, rounded up

There are holes in this character’s brain and he’s starting to slip into madness. The nature of this neurosis is up to the character.

The character doesn’t suffer the effects of Stress until it matches his Willpower score, at that point, he has an episode: he doubles his total Stress.

Once he’s recovered (dropped his Stress back down below his Willpower), he suffers a permanent reduction to his Willpower equal to this Flaw’s Severity.

Epileptic

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

Something is not wired up just right in this character’s brain and that causes them to have little short-outs.

When something triggers a Trauma check for the character, or their Stress reaches above their Int score, roll a d20 + this Flaw’s Severity; if the result is above your character’s Con stat, they have a seizure, during which they’re completely helpless for the next 1d3 minutes.

Excommunicated

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 12

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character has invoked the wrath of an angry god, calling down divine judgment on his head. This is more commonly a member of the faithful who's fallen away or lost his way or willfully defies the cult’s teachings, but less commonly, it’s an outsider who's been declared an enemy of the faith.

When spending Favor Dice or having Favor Dice spent on them for a beneficial reason relating to a single Covenant, they reduce each dice roll by this Flaw’s Severity.

If Favor is being spent on them in a baleful way, the result is instead increased by this Flaw’s Severity.

Fated

CrP Base 23

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 8

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

Certain character’s bear a strange sign on them that marks them for doom. The cruel strings of fate weave together to form a noose for them.

At creation, the GM rolls 1d8! - the Flaw’s Severity. This is the number of sessions the character has before Fate begins to sharpen her shears.

After that point, whenever the character takes damage and/or Stress, they gain an additional damage and/or Stress equal to how many sessions have passed since the deadline.

If the result of the roll was negative, that represents the number of ‘sessions’ that have already passed for that character.

Feral

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 5

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

The wild and untamed lands are home to frontier men and families. Occasionally, children escape and are raised only by the wild, occasionally wolves.

Feral characters still receive any free skills from their Archetype but increase the cost of all non-Athletics, Survival, and Combat Skill Suites by this Flaw’s Severity * 10 and all non-Athletics, Survival, Combat Advanced Skills by this Flaw’s Severity.

Glutton

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character needs food more than normal or, at least, they feel like they do.

Rationing and Going Without food deals double the Stress and damage + 1 damage and Stress per Severity.

Having the normal amount of food deals 1d6! / 2 damage and 1d6! / 2 Stress + 1 damage and Stress per 2 points of Severity (rounded up).

Only by doubling the normal amount of food do they avoid any damage and Stress.

Half-life

CrP Base 50

Per Severity 6

Severity Cap 4

Rank 3.5 + 1.5 per Severity, rounded up

This character has died and been forced back to life, maybe against his will.

This character is affected by the Force Bind Spirit spell, though the Duration is set to 1d4! - Severity (minimum 1) years and a day, with all the benefits and drawbacks.

Why he came back is up to you. Perhaps he had some unfinished business or perhaps he was targeted accidently. In any case, now he lives a half-life.

Haunted

CrP Base 20

Per Severity 6

Severity Cap 5

Rank .5 + 1.5 per Severity, rounded up

Most commonly, this character has done something to dishonor his clan and has since been haunted by one of their ancestors, displeased by their actions.

The spirit takes the corporeal form of a rotting corpse wearing its death mask, bothering the possessed at all hours to restore his family’s honor and stop being such a failure. The ancestor will do nothing to protect their descendant and often make life harder for them when they can.

Unfortunately, decades, if not centuries, in the grave have made the ancestor more than a bit senile. Even if the character is able to obtain Full of Integrity, the ancestor doesn’t care; what it really wants is for the character to sacrifice themselves in a heroic way or perform suicide.

This character reduces the amount of Stress healed Taking a Breather by this Flaw’s Severity and reduces the Relaxation that others would by its Severity, both to a minimum of 0.

Finally, they lose 1 Integrity at the end of every session.

This Flaw may be paid off for half cost if the character has lasted 2 sessions with Full Integrity, however it goes back up to full price if they slip out of Full Integrity later.

Playing The Honored Dead

The Honored Dead may have been a person once but they're no longer their full personalities but merely shards of what they once were: their strongest characteristics shine through but the subtlety of the once living person is often lost.

So, Honored Dead will often only have 2 Characteristics. Often this is just their 2 Strongest Convictions but it can also be their Devotions, Flaws, Temperament, or even Goals, or some combination, that are used to inform how they interact with their kin.

Players should be encouraged to fill this out and know at least something about the person that's currently haunting them, although the GM gets the final approval.

Hemophilic

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 5

Rank 1 per Severity

These guys love to bleed. Well, they may not love it but they certainly do it a lot more than the rest of us.

They take additional damage equal to their Severity every time they’re wounded although this doesn’t count towards Trauma or Knock-Backs.

Hyperopia

CrP Base 17

Per Severity 6

Severity Cap 6

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity, rounded up

This is the fancy term for “Far-Sighted”: the character can see things that are far away clearly but has trouble with things up close.

In melee combat or when making Checks that involve seeing things close to the character, they roll a dice shrunk a number of sizes equal to their Severity.

Hypochondriac

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character lets the idea of disease and dying really go to their head.

When poisoned or sick, they also gain Stress equal to the Flaw’s Severity at the same Speed as the poison or disease.

Additionally, the threat of disease or poison can be frightening for them and they take Stress equal to half this Flaw’s Severity whenever a disease or poison’s symptoms are mentioned to them as they start to feel like they’re already suffering from it.

Idiot Savant

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 5

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character was born gifted. Or in other words, they were born with the ability to understand something but nothing else.

This character picks a Skill Suite; all other Skill Suites have their cost increased by the Flaw’s Severity * 10 and all Advanced Skills’ costs increased by the Flaw’s Severity.

Additionally, if they would receive a Skill Suite or Advanced Skill for free, they must spend 2 free purchases on it.

The chosen Skill Suite has its cost reduced by the Flaw’s Severity * 5 and all of its Advanced Skills’ costs reduced by the Flaw’s Severity.

You get no bonus for Skill Suites and Advanced Skills received for free.

Impatient

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

Time is the most precious resource of all and this character is the only one who seems to get that.

If a Confrontation lasts longer than 5 - (this Flaw’s Severity) Argument-based Checks, the character starts receiving increasing amounts of Stress. An 'Argument-based' is any Check that is specifically made to make or counter an Argument. It doesn't include auxiliary Checks, such as an Intuition Check to confirm suspicions about what's going on.

This starts at a d4! but increases by 1 dice size for each time another Argument-based Check is made.

If the Severity is greater than 5, it increases that starting d4! for every point of Severity above that.

Impotent

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 19

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

If this character was a tree, he’d have particularly softwood, if you know what I mean. His lack of confidence in his abilities in the bedroom tends to affect the other parts of his life, often snowballing;

Reduce the Integrity cap of this character by 1 for every point of Severity. They also don’t receive the free Grit Die for hitting their max Integrity.

At max Severity, the character is unable to perform because the tree has been pruned: they’re a eunuch.

Inbred

CrP Base 7

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 10

Rank .67 + .33 per Severity, rounded up

Often a curse of the nobility that gets too close to their cousins, inbreeding can stunt the mental capacity of their offspring.

Typically, this is pretty mild for the most part, but it means that, when rolling to increase this character’s Intellect, Presence, or Willpower, you’re going to subtract this Flaw’s Severity from the roll.

Infirm

CrP Base 7

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character’s immune system isn’t up to snuff and so can be easily ravaged by plague or poison.

When making a Check vs either, reduce your roll by the Flaw’s Severity.

Insomniac

CrP Base 20

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

This character is unable to sleep or just needs more than most.

A person requires an additional number of hours of sleep each day equal to this Flaw’s Severity.

If they don’t reach this number, they’re considered to be Rationing their sleep.

Irritable Bowels

CrP Base 7

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 5

Rank .33 per Severity, rounded up

Something about this character’s guts are off and that can make processing food hard on them.

When you eat any food, you take damage equal to this Flaw’s Severity but you can reduce this by 1 for each additional sc you spend on the meal. This doesn't increase the Relaxation of the meal.

Labyrinthitis

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 10

Rank .67 + .33 per Severity, rounded up

There’s something wrong with this character’s sense of balance, probably as a result of something wrong with their inner ear.

When making any Checks that involve balancing, they receive a penalty equal to their Severity.

Additionally, should they be forced to make the Check while unable to see for any reason, they also reduce the Check’s dice by 1 size.

Lemming

CrP Base 5

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 per Severity, rounded up

If all their friends were jumping off a bridge, this character would leap without looking. When in a Confrontation, if this character is on the side with the fewest people, they receive this Flaw's Severity as a penalty to all their Checks.

Limp

Limp
Movement Reduction (ft)
Walking Severity
Jogging Severity * 2
Running Severity * 3
Sprinting Severity * 4
Limp Size Mod
Size Multiplier
Small 0.5
Medium 1
Large 1.5

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 6

Severity Cap 4

Rank 1.5 per Severity, rounded up

Something isn’t working just right, whether from a birth defect or a war wound, causing this character to hobble along at a slower pace.

Characters with a limp remove the following from their movement.

This penalty is then multiplied by the character’s size.

Missing Arm

CrP Base 26

Per Severity 18

Severity Cap 2

Rank 1 + 3 per Severity

Most likely this is the result of some terrible accident or horrific war wound, though some people are born with an arm missing. Either way, this Flaw represents the arm being gone above the elbow.

The first level of Severity means that the character is unable to wield two-handed weapons, employ bows or crossbows, or anything else that needs two hands so they can only use the 1-Handed Weapon with Free Hand or 2 Hands Free Weapon Styles.

The next level of Severity prevents the character from using any weapons, and makes them unable to cast spells with Somatic components

Missing Digit

CrP Base 7

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

Each Severity of this Flaw represents another finger missing from one or both hands of the character (roll randomly to determine which fingers).

When performing Checks that require fine manual dexterity (sowing, tying rope, lock picking), the Check takes a penalty equal to this Flaw’s Severity.

If all the fingers are missing from one hand, the character is unable to wield two-handed weapons except crossbows and firearms, although they reduce their attack dice by 1 size unless steading them (on top of the normal penalties).

Additionally, Checks requiring fine manual dexterity also have this penalty.

If all the fingers on both hands are missing, they’re unable to use any weapons or perform any Check that requires fingers.

Missing Ear

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

While it won’t limit your ability to hear entirely, the shape of the ear does make it easier to hear things.

This means that, for Checks involving sound, they take a penalty equal to this Flaw’s Severity.

Additionally, they’re much slower to react: if they can’t see a threat, they increase their Initiative by 1 for every point of Severity.

Missing Eye

CrP Base 33

Per Severity 16

Severity Cap 2

Rank 3 per Severity

You can imagine that a character with one eye gone would have an issue with his depth perception. You’d be correct.

The first Severity means that the character automatically attacks second when engaging in melee, even if his weapon has the greater reach and everything is counted as two range categories further for ranged weaponry.

Additionally, they roll a d0 base for Checks involving estimating distances.

The second Severity means that the character has lost both eyes.

In melee combat or when making Checks that involve sight, they roll a d0 base.

And ranged combat is right out, however, if you insist, you’ll be attacking and defending with a -d20! base.

Missing Hand

CrP Base 33

Per Severity 16

Severity Cap 2

Rank 3 per Severity

This Flaw means that the character has lost part of one or both of their arms below the elbow and so they have some level of articulation.

The first Severity means that the character is unable to wield two-handed weapons except crossbows and firearms, although they reduce their attack dice by 1 size unless steading them (on top of the normal penalties).

Additionally, Checks requiring fine manual dexterity also have this penalty.

At the second Severity, they’re unable to use any weapons or perform any Check that requires fingers.

Missing Leg

CrP Base 33

Per Severity 16

Severity Cap 2

Rank 3 per Severity, rounded up

Missing a leg is not a great place to be.

At the first Severity, without some kind of peg leg, you're limited to Crawling or Walking but you take damage as if you're Sprinting.

With a peg leg, you’re able to Crawl, Walk, and Jog as normal but are unable to Run and Sprint.

At the second Severity, even with some sort of rolling platform to seat yourself on, you're only able to move up to a Jog but you take damage when doing so as if you're Running.

Some terrain can further limit that.

Missing Teeth

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 4

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

A few teeth missing ain’t so bad but the more you lose, the harder things can get.

At the very least, you have to be careful to eat softer foods, resulting in meals being more expensive; increase the price of food per day by 1 sc for each point of Severity. This includes rations.

If they’re Scavenging, they have to spend extra time searching for soft food: they need an additional Boon on each Check to specifically find food they can chew.

If they’re unable to find suitable food, for any reason, they take 1 damage per meal.

Missing teeth can also make some words harder to say. When needing to make a Language Check, this character receives a penalty equal to this Flaw’s Severity.

Monotheist

CrP Base 5

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 12

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity

For this character, there is only one true god, and all other divines are false deities or the work of devils.

When spending Favor Dice or having Favor Dice spent on them for a beneficial reason, if it is not a miracle from their Divine, they reduce each dice roll by this Flaw’s Severity.

Mule

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 24

Rank 1 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

While they may not show it, this character is the result of mixed ancestry and something about their unnatural genesis makes them sterile, unable to promulgate.

Reduce the Integrity cap of this character by 1 for every point of Severity and they also don’t receive the free Grit Die for hitting their max Integrity.

But they may take a second Racial Temperament relating to their other ancestry.

Mute

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 6

Rank 1 per Severity

This could be a natural birth defect or the result of someone cutting out the character’s tongue: either way, at lower Severity, the character has trouble articulating sounds and, at higher Severity, making vocal sounds at all.

When making Checks that involve making verbal sound, reduce that Check dice by 1 for every point of Severity.

At max Severity, the character is unable to make any sound at all.

Characters with this Flaw cannot be Weird-Adept Archetypes that require speech of any kind.

Myopia

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 6

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

This is the fancy term for “Near-Sighted”: the character can see things that are nearby clearly but has trouble with things far away.

In ranged combat or when making Checks that involve seeing things far away from the character, they roll a dice shrunk a number of sizes equal to their Severity.

Neurotic

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 2

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character has issues dealing with stress.

They take an additional Stress equal to their Severity every time they’re inflicted with Stress.

No Depth Perception

CrP Base 16

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 6

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

This character has a hard, if not impossible, time judging distances of all kinds.

This character’s Measure is treated as 1 ft shorter for every point of Severity and everything is counted as 1 range category further for ranged weaponry for every point of Severity.

Additionally, they shrink their dice size by 1 for every point of Severity for Checks involving estimating distances.

Orphan

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 20

Rank 1 per Severity

Orphans are those whose parents have abandoned them and have had to learn to survive on their own in a society that doesn’t know what to do with them.

Reduce the Integrity cap of this character by 1 for every point of Severity but gain a discount to either the Streetwise or Trades Skill Suites.

The Skill Suite of your choice’s cost is reduced by 5 and all of its Advanced Skills’ costs are reduced by 1.

Additionally, orphans often don’t have the resources of others and, when selecting their starting equipment, they remove 1 item per 3 points of Severity, rounded up. If selecting the “Blank Slate Kit” they lose 30 sc per Severity instead.

Pacifist

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 20

Rank 1 per Severity

This character foreswears hurting others for any reason and finds the idea of violence repulsive. Whenever they roll an attack that could inflict damage, they gain Stress equal to Severity. If they're intent is to non-lethally subdue someone, via unarmed attacks, for example, they take half stress (rounded down) per attack as it's still a form of violence.

Phobia

Phobias Table
Roll (d20) Phobia
1 Animals
2 Tight Spaces
3 Combat
4 Commitment
5 Confrontations
6 The Weird
7 Religion
8 Plague
9 The Dead
10 The Opposite Gender
11 Heights
12 The Dark
13 A Monster or Monster Type
14 Spiders
15 Snakes
16 Open Spaces
17 Crowded Spaces
18 Failure
19 Authority Figures
20 Pain

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character is unnaturally afraid of something, beyond all reason and ration.

When faced with their phobia, they gain Stress equal to their phobia’s Severity for each time they have to interact with it (which is normally represented by some kind of Check).

This Flaw can be taken multiple times for different Phobias, each counted as their own separate Flaw with its own Severity.

You can, of course, choose whatever fear you feel fits your character, but we’ve provided a table you can use to generate one for you.

Poor

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

Some characters don’t have the financial leg up that others have.

When selecting equipment, remove 45 sc worth of equipment and/or starting cash per Severity instead.

Refugee

CrP Base 20

Per Severity 0

Severity Cap 1

Rank 2

Fleeing from their homeland for either economic, religious, or conflict reasons, this character finds themselves in a foreign land.

Their flight has forced them to leave much of their belongings behind, halving their starting cash and removing any items that go over their carry.

Their native language is not the main one for this area and the Language and Law of the country they’re fleeing to costs double as they had to learn it under stressful circumstances.

Self-Conscious

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 2

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

Characters with this Flaw have a hard time being in the limelight due to thinking they have some obvious flaw. Which they do - their self consciousness. Whenever they make a Check where people are watching them (whether that's a Confrontation Check where they're the main talker or if they're making a Skill Check while their companions look on), they receive Stress equal to this Flaw's Severity.

Sensitive

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + 1 per Severity, rounded up

Things just get to this character more than others.

When they gain Stress during a Confrontation, they take an additional amount of Stress equal to their Severity.

Shaky Hands

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character has a tremor in their hands that can be a huge pain to deal with.

When firing ranged weapons, they increase their Recovery by the Severity of this Flaw.

Additionally, when doing anything that requires fine movement with their hands and fingers they can either increase the time equal to their Severity or take a penalty equal to their Severity.

The specifics of the time increase are determined by how long the task usually takes and are left up to the GM.

Slow-witted

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

This character takes a little longer than others to think through things. This Flaw doesn’t dictate how smart a person is, simply how fast they think.

When making an Int- or Pre-base Check, they can either increase the time equal to their Severity or take a penalty equal to their Severity.

The specifics of the time increase are determined by how long the task usually takes and are left up to the GM.

Stutter

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 6

Rank 1 per Severity

This character has trouble communicating, either finding the right words or pronouncing them and that can make talking a bit of a challenge.

Communicating an idea will take longer than it normally would: as an Asset, you double their Organization.

Additionally, anytime you need to make a Language Check to be understood while speaking, reduce the Check die by 1 size per point of Severity.

Characters with this Flaw cannot be Weird-Adept Archetypes that require speech of any kind.

Survivor's Guilt

CrP Base 15

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1 + 1 per Severity

This character has suffered some past trauma where they were one of a few to survivor a horrible tragedy and so carry around survivor's guilt because of it. Now, when they go through similar experiences, they relive that trauma.

When a companion of this character dies, suffers a mental break, or goes unconscious, they take Stress equal to this Flaw's Severity.

Thrall

CrP Base 17

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 10

Rank 1.25 + .75 per Severity, rounded up

Thralls are those taken in raids or the children of slaves. Technically, they’re ‘free’ but they have a social stigma that follows them.

When selecting equipment, thralls remove 10 sc per point of Severity of the character’s choice and start with no extra starting cash. If selecting the “Blank Slate Kit” they lose 30 sc per Severity instead.

Additionally, they have to overcome their cultivated respect/fear for those of a higher social caste: they gain the Devotion “Afraid of/Respects/Is Subservient to (pick one at first level) those in a High Social Caste” equal to their Severity.

Trick Knee

CrP Base 10

Per Severity 3

Severity Cap 10

Rank .5 per Severity, rounded up

Something about the character’s knee isn’t aligned right.

When Running or Sprinting, if the character gets above a 4 on their unmodified damage roll their knee gives out, forcing them to limp at Crawling speed for a number of seconds equal to this Flaw’s Severity before they can resume normal movement.

Vexable

CrP Base 23

Per Severity 10

Severity Cap 2

Rank 2 per Severity

This character finds it hard to keep their stress under control and things can quickly escalate for them.

This character’s Stress explodes on 1 value lower for each point of Severity they have in this Flaw.

So, if they have Severity 1 and they roll a d4! for their Stress, that dice explodes on a 4 and 3.

Vow Of Poverty

CrP Base 23

Per Severity 4

Severity Cap 19

Rank 1.5 + .5 per Severity, rounded up

The Middle Realm corrupts and those that wish to come closer to the Gods’ Realm sometimes eschew worldly possessions.

At any time, they can only keep a max of 200 sc - 10 sc per Severity worth of cash, goods, or equipment on them for their use.

All other wealth is donated to any local cults or the needy (which doesn’t include fellow adventurers).

This vow is rewarded though: their Max Favor is increased by 1, regardless of Severity.

Weak

CrP Base 13

Per Severity 5

Severity Cap 4

Rank .75 per Severity, rounded up

This character runs out of steam faster than others, even if their capacity for work is just the same as others.

For every point of Severity, lower the character’s starting Fatigue Threshold by 1 step. Nothing can be done to reverse this except buying this Flaw down.

Weird Resistant

CrP Base 3

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 15

Rank .75 per Severity, rounded up

For whatever reason, the Weird seems to bonus off this character. When resisting a spell, this character gains this Flaw's Severity to their Check, however must always resist, even if the spell would be beneficial to them.

You cannot take this Flaw if you're a Weird-Adept of any kind or if you already have the Weird Vulnerable Flaw.

Weird Vulnerable

CrP Base 3

Per Severity 1

Severity Cap 15

Rank .75 per Severity, rounded up

For whatever reason, the Weird seems to stick to this character. When resisting a spell, this character gains this Flaw's Severity as a penalty to their Check.

You cannot take this Flaw if you already have the Weird Resistant Flaw.

Chapter 4Flaws

Skill Suites Vs Advanced Skills

You’ll notice that there are two types of Skills in Bonfire: Skill Suites and Advanced Skills.

So, what’s the difference?

Skill Suites

These skills represent broad swathes of knowledge that cover a variety of subjects. Suites are hard to increase because there’s so much ground to cover but can be used if you don’t have the specific Advanced Skill.

An example would of this would be using the Survival Suite if you didn’t have the Signaling Advanced Skill.

Advanced Skills

These skills are more tightly focused, covering one intellectual discipline. They’re easier to master but may not be applicable in every case.

An example of this would be First Aid, Fire Building, and Scavenging are all Skills in the Survival Skill Suite, while Law, History, and Medicine are all Skills in the Lore Skill Suite.

Acquiring Skills

Throughout your character’s career, she’ll acquire and improve her skills. Both types of skills are purchased with CrP, that is spent either at Character Creation or when leveling up.

All skills have a unique cost that represents how easy or difficult they are to master. You pay the price as noted in the section below, you improve/purchase the skill.

Rank

If you haven't already calculated your starting Rank for your Skill Suites, you need to go back to Step 8 of Chapter 1: Step-by-Step Overview and do that before purchasing any additional Ranks in your Suites or Advanced Skills.

If you haven’t purchased an Advanced Skill before, its current Rank is equal to the Rank of the mother Skill Suite and increased by 1 from there.

When you buy a Skill Suite that you're already trained in, if you've already bought Ranks in its children Advanced Skill, you increase those Ranks by 1 as well. This includes Skills you can buy multiple times with different subsets, like the Craft Advanced Skill.

Cost

Check Modifiers
Stat Check Mod
1 -4
2 -3
3 -3
4 -2
5 -2
6 -1
7 -1
8 0
9 0
10 0
11 0
12 0
13 1
14 1
15 1
16 2
17 2
18 2
19 2
20 3
21 3
22 3
23 4

Skill Suites cost their Base Cost - your full Int stat + (Current Rank * 10).

If you’re Untrained in that Skill Suite, “Current Rank”, the cost is just Base Cost - your full Int stat and gives you a Rank 0.

Advanced Skills cost their Base Cost + (Current Rank * 3).

You’re still able to purchase Ranks in Advanced Skills in that Skill Suite, with the initial purchase just being the Base Cost and putting that Skill at Rank 0, but it does mean you can roll the Check on a d20!.

If you have any discounts from your Archetypes (through Skill or Martial Focuses, for example), those discounts apply after all above calculations. Skill Costs have a minimum cost of 1 CrP.

Non-Combat Check Mods

For non-Combat Skills, each one is related to one or more applicable Stats, these are the stats who’s Check Mod you’re going to add to the roll when you make a Check.

If there is more than more than 1 Stat listed, use the highest.

Combat Check Mods

Combat Skills behave identically to normal Skills except that their Check Mods are calculated a bit differently.

Instead of taking the highest stat, you’re going to refer to the following formulas and table below.

An (A), (S), or (W) means that these abilities will be affected by your Armor, Shield, and/or Weapon if you're wearing them.

Attack (Atk): Dex Mod + Int Mod

Defense (Def): Dex Mod + Will Mod + A + S

Initiative (Init): Dex Mod + Will Mod + A

Damage (Dam): W + Str Mod

Recovery (Rec) (Melee & Bows): W + Str Mod * weapon size (1 for S, 2 for M, 3 for L, 4 for H), rounded down + A

Recovery (Rec) (Everything else): W + A

You'll also have Parry, which are both based on the weapon you used but Parry may be replaced by your shield's Parry.

Combat Skills Check Mods
Stat Dex Atk Dex Def Dex Init Int Atk Will Def Will Init Str Dam Str Rec
1 -3 -3 3 -6 -5 5 -5 1.5
2 -3 -2 2 -5 -4 5 -4 1
3 -3 -2 2 -4 -4 4 -3 1
4 -2 -1 1 -3 -3 3 -2 1
5 -2 -1 1 -2 -2 2 -2 .5
6 -1 -1 1 -2 -2 2 -2 .5
7 -1 -1 1 -2 -1 2 -2 .5
8 0 0 0 -1 -1 1 -1 0
9 0 0 0 -1 -1 1 -1 0
10 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
11 0 0 0 1 1 -1 1 0
12 0 0 0 1 1 -1 1 -.5
13 1 1 -1 2 1 -2 2 -.5
14 1 1 -1 2 2 -2 2 -.5
15 1 1 -1 2 2 -2 2 -.5
16 2 1 -1 3 3 -3 3 -1
17 2 1 -1 3 3 -3 3 -1
18 2 1 -1 4 4 -4 3 -1
19 2 2 -2 4 4 -4 4 -1
20 2 2 -2 4 5 -4 4 -1.5
21 3 2 -2 5 5 -5 4 -1.5
22 3 2 -2 5 5 -5 4 -1.5
23 3 2 -2 6 5 -5 5 -2

Rank Descriptive Terminology

Rank Terminology
Rank Term
+0 Beginner
+1 - +4 Novice
+5 - +9 Journeyman
+10 - +14 Expert
+15 - +19 Master
≥+20 Grandmaster

What does it mean to have a Rank 5 in something and how would your character communicate their expertice if asked, in game?

The following descriptive terminology is presented here to give you those guidelines. While presented as just Rank, rememeber that your Check Mod changes your "effective" term.

If you have an Archetype with a Skill Focus or Martial Focus, expect that, by level 20, you'll be a Grandmaster in those Skills. Otherwise, anything you have to spent CrP on should end around Expert, although you can reach Master with sacrifices.

Skill Descriptions

Skill Name Base Cost Stats
Athletics 30 Str/Con
Acrobatics 7 Dex
Climbing 7 Str
Endurance 4 Con
Escape Artist 7 Dex
Jumping 5 Str
