Athletics Skill Suite

Base Cost 30

Stats Str/Con

This suite covers all things that require physical prowess and, to a lesser extent, pure manual dexterity.

Acrobatics

Check to Not Slow Down
Speed Difficulty
Walking +d4!
Jog +d8!
Run +d12!
Sprint +d20!+d4!

Base Cost 7

Stats Dex

This covers your character's ability to stretch their body, do flips, and turn cartwheels. This allows the character to vault fences without slowing down or roll to avoid falling damage.

Reference the Check to Not Slow Down table to calculate the base Difficulty to, well, not slow down when you encounter an obstacle.

To reduce falling damage, remove 10 ft from the effective fall distance for every Boon you get.

Climbing

Base Cost 7

Stats Str

This Skill covers climbing and repelling up and down walls of various heights and textures.

Difficulty should be based on height, with about every 40 ft increasing the Difficulty by 1 dice size.

Textures should also play a major factor in not just how tough the Check is but also how many Checks need to be made for a given wall.

So, if there’s a wall, where the base is stone at a 45% slant for 20 ft, then it moves to close knit stones for another 40 ft, and then finally to a wood overhang for just 5 ft, and then to a wooden wall for 10 ft, there would be 4 Climbing Checks in this order: +d4!, +d10! (d8! for base but because it’s 40 ft, it gets bumped up 1), d10!, and +0.

Endurance

Base Cost 4

Stats Con

Through training, a character can push his body past the limits of his base physical ability. The Rank of this Skill serves as DR against the damage you take while Running or Sprinting, although specifics are given in the Actions section of Chapter 3:Combat.

Escape Artist

Base Cost 7

Stats Dex

This allows the character to escape bonds and restrictions and is always rolled opposed, either against the Rope Use Skill of the person who tied them or against the quality of the manacles or binds the person was put in.

The character can make a straight +0 Check, not to break the bounds or get free, but to instead move his body to an advantageous position.

Jumping

Base Cost 5

Stats Str

When you need to cover a distance without touching the ground, jump.

Typically, a character can jump 16 inches vertically or 5 ft horizontally without a Check, however, if they want to go further, they’ll need to roll.

Each Boon adds 2 inches to the vertical jump and 6 inches to the horizontally. Starting at a run doubles this.

Small creatures half these numbers while Large creatures double them.

Move Silently

Base Cost 9

Stats Dex/Will

Move Silently Speed
Speed Dice to Roll On
Crawling d20!
Walking d12!
Jog d8!
Run d4!
Sprint 0

When you want to move silently, you’ll want to use this Skill. This involves being able to feel your way along and compensate for creaks.

This is always an opposed Check vs any potential listener’s Listening, with a failure indicating that the listener has heard something suspicious, though the person attempting Move Silently may not be aware that they were detected.

Moving at speeds greater than a Crawl speed is considered Multitasking. Refer to the following table for what to roll.

Resistance (Poison/Disease)

Base Cost 1/5

Stats Con

Poisons, diseases, and toxins in general are a constant threat for adventures and some have found that they can build up a resistance to these troubles over time. When you take this Skill, you need to determine what specific poison, disease, or toxin you’re taking it for. When you’re exposed to that substance, for any reason, you gain this Skill’s Rank when making Checks against it.

You can take this Skill multiple times, each for different poisons, diseases, and toxins.

At character creation, this Skill has a base cost of 1 CrP instead of 5. If you want to take this Skill for a poison, disease, or toxin you’ve been exposed to during play, it drops down to 1 CrP again and the cost only increases by the Rank (instead of twice the Rank). You only get this discount once per exposure.

If you’ve bought a poison, you can expose yourself to small amounts to build up an immunity but, because you’re not at as much of a risk, the immunity builds up slower: there is no discount to the base cost but the price increases by the Rank (instead of twice).

Sport (specific)

Base Cost 4

Stats Str/Con

This covers the actual playing of a specific sport as well as an in-depth knowledge of the game’s rules as well as famous players and techniques.

If it becomes a plot point, the GM should feel free to make this Skill apply to only certain positions, like pitching or shortstop but this a fantasy roleplaying game so I doubt that’ll happen.

Swimming

Base Cost 5

Stats Str/Con

This Skill allows a character to not drown in water.

The Difficulty of the Check is determined by the water (or other liquid, I don’t judge) you’re attempting to swim in, though simply trying to float on your back and letting the current take you gives you a +d8! to your roll, though it is risky because you could get pulled into an aquifer or get pulled over a waterfall but that’s the chance you take.

Vandalism

Base Cost 3

Stats Str

Vandalism is the art of destroying inanimate objects using non-weapon methods.

This could mean breaking down a door, bending bars, lifting gates, destroying pieces of art or a lock, or something more iconoclastic. It involves sussing out the weak points and targeting them for maximum damage.

A successful Check results in 1 Wear being applied to the object, with an additional Wear for each Boon.

Lore Skill Suite

Base Cost 30

Stats Int

This suite covers general knowledge, which is mostly academic in nature. Most of it is pretty heavy stuff but the basics are second nature or stuff that’s been picked up here and there.

Administration

Base Cost 7

Stats Int

While they’ll never inspire the awe or respect that other leaders do, people who oversee the day to day functions of an organization keep the lights on so that others can make the speeches.

Administrators can make a Check at +0 to gain a clue about an item the party might need on their adventure, or one to retroactively remember that they did buy an item back at the market for just such an occasion.

Each of these Checks they make increases the Difficulty of the next one by 1 step.

History

Base Cost 6

Stats Int

Everyone knows certain large events, but few can tie those events into an overarching narrative and understand their effects on later events.

The History Skill allows a character to not just recall events but also to link them to the present day, to certain traditions and rituals of a culture, or the behavior of certain members of a culture, giving insight on how to proceed.

Language (specific)

Base Cost 5

Stats Int/Will

A character receives this Skill for free in their native tongue with a Rank equal to their Int and it allows them to speak and be understood by others with Skill in that language. Like all Languages, this isn't increased with the Lore Skill.

Purchasing other languages can be done, however, if it a language completely unrelated to a language you already known, the Language's Rank starts at 0: otherwise use of that that Language's Rank as a starting Rank.

Checks are only made when timing is critical, such as communication in a battle, or when understanding is key, such as when debating foreign policy.

Additionally, when two speakers are in a Confrontation, the one with the higher Language Rank gains a +d4! to their roll (see Applicable Skills in Chapter 2: Confrontations). In case of tie, nothing happens.

The Lore Skill Suite can’t be used in place of a Language Check for tongues you don’t know unless you have the Language Skill in a related Language. Using a real-world example, someone with the Language (Swedish) Advanced Skill couldn’t use the Lore Skill Suite to understand a person with Language (French) but could use it when talking to someone with Language (Norwegian) or Language (Danish).

Law (culture)

Base Cost 5

Stats Int

This Skill covers the intricacies of the legal system, including landmark rulings and common punishments for common crimes. A character can make their case or find loopholes to exploit the legal system.

A character’s Lore Skill can only be used to substitute for their native culture but not others’. If the character does want to branch out, his mastery of Law for that new culture starts at 0, as he must learn everything from the ground up. Diving more into his own culture’s laws (buying this Advanced Skill for his culture) uses the Lore Skill as base, as per usual.

Literacy (alphabet)

Base Cost 7

Stats Int

This Skill allows a character to read and write in a language’s alphabet, giving them the power to pen books and poems, or passive aggressive notes. A character who's Trained in the Lore Skill Suite is considered to be literate in their native language's alphabet.

This Skill can be taken multiple times, each instance representing mastery of a new writing system. The scribe can then use that alphabet to pen any language they know, in the same way that we could use the Latin Alphabet to pen Arabic or the Korean Alphabet to write English.

To decipher a text, the person needs to know both the alphabet it's written in and the language it's using, which most of the time won't matter but can be used as a cheap way to do a cypher in a pinch.

Checks are only made when timing is critical, such as quickly scanning a letter, or when understanding is key, such as reading an extremely techinical work, or where basic competency is unsure, such as reading an early version of the language.

Mathematics

Base Cost 9

Stats Int/Will

While this may seem like just a Skill that allows you to be able to juggle figures and add totals and calculate the area of a circle like a huge nerd, mathematics has a more practical use: correctly guessing distances.

While you can try to eyeball how far away something is, a Mathematics Check vs +0 allows you to do rough calculations, giving you the ability to know exactly what penalty you’re going to get for using a ranged weapon or who's going to be affected by the Shape of a spell you’re going to cast.

Medicine

Base Cost 8

Stats Int

With proper treatment and nursing, a wound that would lay you out for weeks, may only keep you down for a couple of days. This Skill involves the knowledge of long-term care, when bandages should be changed, which poultices will have the greatest effect, and what minor surgeries need to be performed.

A character with this Skill can make a Check for a wounded person, adding the Severity of his largest Wound to the opposing roll.

So, if a person has a 5, 3, and 8 Severity Wound, he can make a Medicine Check vs d20+8.

Success means that the person can take 1 day off the healing time for every Wound every time it drops a Severity.

So, a success against a 5 Severity Wound means that it was treated properly and takes 10 days to completely heal ( 4 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 0 ) instead of the normal 15.

Every Boon you get reduces the number of days healed by an additional day.

Additionally, when resisting Poison, Toxin, or Diseases, you can add your Medicine Rank, rounded up, to each round of the Confrontation.

Monster Craft

Base Cost 8

Stats Int

This Advanced Skill is under both the Lore and Survival Skill Suite but still counts as 1 Skill, so you don’t have to buy it twice - they share their Rank. It simply represents the different ways that each Skill Suite approaches the craft.

When you first purchase this Skill, you need to choose which Skill Suite to base if off of: only purchases of that Skill Suite increase it. You cannot switch it.

Monster Craft gives you insight into the creatures that roam the Middle Realm. Simply put, each Boon gives you a (truthful) answer to a question.

Difficulty is based on how common the monster is. Common is +0, uncommon +d6!, rare is d12!, and legendary is +d20!.

Religion (cult)

Base Cost 4

Stats Int

This Skill acquaints the character with a knowledge of cults, their common Covenants and Miracles, as well as their hierarchies, means of advancement, and important members.

It also allows a character to gain a knowledge of their rituals and sacrifices, as well as the taboos of their clergy and how to appease their heavenly messengers and avenging angels.

The Religion Skill is taken for a single Covenant, but can be purchased independently for different Covenants.

A character adds the Rank of this Skill to their chance of gaining Favor when making certain sacrifices to the god of that cult.

World Craft

Base Cost 6

Stats Int

This area of study covers the topography of the Middle Realm. It’s forests and rock formations and biomes. It helps predict whether or not it’s going to rain or whether the next summer is going to be a hot one.

Predicting what’s coming in the next hour is a Check vs +0, with the Difficulty increasing by 1 dice size for each time you double the prediction window. So, detecting the weather in the next 2 hours is vs +d4!, while doing so in the next 16 hours is vs +d10!.

Streetwise Skill Suite

Base Cost 30

Stats Will/Pre

This suite covers knowledge that a character might pick on the street or in the school of hard knocks. While Lore is book smart, Streetwise is street smart.

Current Affairs

Base Cost 5

Stats Int

A character with this Skill is well informed about the day to day affairs of regional powers and men and women of importance, their dealings and alliances, as well as their hatreds. He can pick out celebrities and know how and why someone got rich and famous.

They can also use this Skill to guess the Integrity category of someone by watching how people react to them and letting them know about certain NPCs' Reputations.

Deception

Deception Check
Difficulty Level of Lie
+0 White Lie
+d4! Lie of Omission
+d6! Mostly True Lie
+d8! Half Lie
+d10! Mostly False Lie
+d12! Absolute Lie
+d20! Absolute Lie with Easy Evidence Against It

Base Cost 8

Stats Int/Pre

This covers all sorts of deception, where you want the person to believe the opposite of the truth, or, to put it simply, when you want to lie to them.

The level of Difficulty to pull off a lie is based on how much of what you’re saying isn’t the truth, strictly speaking. This is always opposed by either the other character’s Deception or Intuition but only if the character has reason to suspect that you’re lying to them.

Even if you succeed, this isn’t a permanent way of changing their mind. New evidence presented to that person may cause them to rethink their opinion on what you tried to sell them so be careful about what falsehoods you spin.

Forgery

Base Cost 11

Stats Dex/Will

Mostly commonly used for creating fake currency, forgery is a Skill that allows a character to reproduce something effectively and fool others. This Skill acquaints the character with common forging techniques and knowledge with what possible agents will be looking for.

The forger must also have the appropriate corresponding Craft or Trade Skill, so he can’t forge coins if he doesn’t have the Metalworking Skill, though that’s within reason: a character forging an official passport with one at hand doesn’t need to have Literacy as he can just copy the letters, though he may also need to have Artistry (wood cutting) to create the heraldry on it, but someone trying to forge an official declaration from scratch does need to have the Literacy Skill in that language plus Artistry (wood cutting).

Forgery is opposed by the applicable Skill, or Forgery but only if the character looking has reason to suspect there’s something else. A lazy guard probably won’t Check your passport too closely right before lunch, but a particularly astute one who's on the lookout for a promotion will.

Gambling/Gaming

Base Cost 5

Stats Int

This Skill doesn’t give the character a gift for winning games, just that he knows the rules and knows the odds, which could in turn lead to him winning the game.

Intuition

Base Cost 5

Stats Will

The ability to understand people and get where they're coming from can help you figure out what will and won't work with them better.

It has 3 uses: to get a feel on how likely a Confrontation is, to confirm an NPC's Characteristic, and to discover an NPC's Characteristics.

To get a feel about the likelihood of a Confrontation, a Check is required with the Difficulty based on how well the person knows their target.

Boons can be used to determine what additional things might be dealbreakers or insights into why this tactic might work while Complications can result in a misread of the situation.

They can also use it to confirm their theories about what Characteristics a character has. The player needs to make a reasonable guess about the Characteristic first - so players who’re simply throwing out guesses automatically fail.

The Check is based on how much the person and the target have interacted with each other but typically start at Impossible and are lowered by 2 for each previous interaction, although the GM can further lower the Difficulty if the interaction was particularly meaningful or telling.

Finally, the GM will subtract double that Characteristic's Rank from their roll so that more powerful it is, the easier it'll be to confirm, although they may add their Deception Rank for free as well.

Boons can be spent for additional insight into that Characteristic (like learning it's general Rank) while Complications might result in the Characteristic being slightly off or leaving out a key detail.

Players don't need to exactly correct in their guesses, as long as they get the spirit. If they succeed, it's a good opportunity to just tell them what the Characteristic is directly.

A character can also use their Intuition Skill to 'read' someone: learn a Characteristic without making a guess at it.

The Check is based on how much the person and the target have interacted with each other but typically start at Impossible and are lowered by 1 for each previous interaction, although the GM can further lower the Difficulty if the interaction was particularly meaningful or telling.

Finally, the GM will subtract that Characteristic's Rank from their roll so that more powerful it is, the easier it'll be to guess, although they may add their Deception Rank for free as well.

Boons can be spent for additional insight into that Characteristic (like learning it's general Rank) while Complications might result in the Characteristic being slightly off or leaving out a key detail or being completely wrong.

Listening

Base Cost 6

Stats Int

Listening has to deal with your character’s auditory senses. This goes beyond simply hearing something: listening allows the character to know when an otherwise innocuous noise is actually something to pay attention to though it might not always be apparent why at first.

Lock Picking

Lock Picking
Lock Difficulty Base Time Time Off
+0 1 Minute 5 Seconds
+d4! 5 Minutes 30 Seconds
+d6! 20 Minutes 2 Minutes
+d8! 30 Minutes 3 Minutes
+d10! 45 Minutes 5 Minutes
+d12! 1 Hour 10 Minutes
+1 Dice Size Add +15 Minutes +5 Minutes

Base Cost 11

Stats Dex/Int

It takes a lot more know-how than you might think to pick a lock.

The amount of time it takes to pick any lock is based on your Skill Rank and the quality of the lock. Subtract the Time Off * their Boons from the Base Time.

Sleight Of Hand

Base Cost 7

Stats Dex

This Skill covers all things that require you to do quick, delicate movements with your fingers. This may be slipping a card up your sleeve, picking a pocket, or doing cat’s cradle while bored.

Survival Skill Suite

Base Cost 30

Stats Con/Will

This suite covers everything that a character might need to survive in the wild; Knowledge of what plants to eat and the Skills to hunt and breed animals.

Botany

Base Cost 7

Stats Int

This gives a knowledge of what the herbs used in cooking, alchemy, and medicine look like in their natural environment and it allows you to identify their common uses. It also helps find food in the wilderness.

If halving their overland travel speed, a person with Botany can make a Check every travel period: if they succeed, they can consider themselves 1 step up on the Long-Term Exhaustion table. So, if they had nothing, they could consider themselves Rationing.

If they choose to stay put, a success nets them 2 steps up.

4 or more Boons results in doubling their output, meaning they possibly found themselves enough food for the next day.

Mostly, this is used for detecting poisonous plants, which is Check vs +d4! but is a common Skill when Helping Out for both Medicine and Cooking/Baking.

Fire Building

Base Cost 5

Stats Dex

Against the cold, lonely nights out in the wild, there is only the fertility symbols you carve for yourself and the roar of the fire. This Skill allows you to build one of those things: the fire.

Under normal conditions, it takes about 30 minutes and a Check vs +0 to set up and light a fire, assuming you don’t have to go far out of your way to find the wood.

First Aid

Base Cost 8

Stats Dex/Int

This gives the character a crude understanding of battlefield medicine: making splints and staunching wounds.

A character with this Skill can make a Check for a person wounded in that last 30 minutes, adding half of the Severity of any Wounds that he's treating to the opposing roll (rounded down).

So, if a person has a 5, 3, and 8 Severity Wound, he can make a First Aid Check vs d20+8 or he can choose not to treat the 3 Severity Wound and make a vs d20!+6. Success means that the person can take 1 level of Severity off those Wounds. So, a 5 Severity Wound drops immediately to a 4 Severity Wound. You cannot go back and do a Check for a Wound that you skipped.

You have 30 minutes to perform First Aid Checks for a person, with each Wound taking 3 minutes, if applicable.

For every 2 Boons, you may increase the damage healed by 1.

Handle Animal (specific)

Base Cost 6

Stats Pre

This Skill deals with the handling and care of a specific animal, from birth to the slaughterhouse. It also deals with training and common illnesses to make sure the stock is healthy and virile.

While most Checks are handled like normal knowledge Checks or on a case-by-case basis (such as calming down your animal during a storm), using a question-and-answer style, this Skill is also used for training, with the base number of tricks you can teach an animal equal to their Int (note that carrying things and handling a bridle are two different tricks).

The animal needs to have both the basic temperament and physical ability to learn a trick (no sheep becoming pack animals and no dogs learning to pick locks). The GM may increase or decrease this for particularly smart/dumb and obedient/obstinate animals.

After a month of training, a roll is made vs +0. If successfully, the animal learned the trick. If not, another Check can be made in a month, although every failure increases the Difficulty to learn that trick by 1 dice size.

If players want to tame animals they can use the following Obstacle to do so.

Hiding

Base Cost 9

Stats Dex/Will

This allows a character to make the most of a situation or environment to cloak themselves against prying eyes. This is opposed by the applicable Skill, with the Difficulty determined by the area. Characters can also use this to instantly get an idea of how well they can hide in the given space.

Hunting

Base Cost 7

Stats Will

Most of the time, you’re not going to down your quarry in one go, and so the hunt is on as your watch for subtle signs of their passing. While this Skill was originally used to hunt wildlife, it has been repurposed by wardens and bounty hunters trying to capture the most dangerous game.

The Hunting Skill can be used to track your prey, get a sense of their movements, and predict where they’re going. It can also give insight into common and uncommon natural creatures.

If you’re using it for food, hunting is a boom or bust strategy: at the end of each full day you spend hunting, roll a Check.

For each Boon you gain 2 days’ worth of food, but either way, you gain 1 damage from exhaustion and possibly more if you suffer a Complication.

Hunting is also used to harvest Reagents from dead animals and monsters which can be sold or used to increase your spell power.

Monster Craft

Base Cost 8

Stats Int

This Skill is the same as the Monster Craft under the Lore Skill Suite. Look there for details on it.

Navigation

Base Cost 7

Stats Int

Either using the stars or the position of the moons and sun, this character can track their way even through the most untamed wilderness without getting lost. It also allows them to tell the time.

Without proper equipment, a character can only give rough estimations of where they are, anchored on larger geographic features (like mountains or rivers but not towns or roads) to the nearest 10 miles.

Scavenging

Base Cost 4

Stats Int

There’s a gift in high-speed appraisal. This is often used by those picking over battlefields for anything they could sell, but it’s also found a niche with adventurers who use it to find food and sustenance while traveling away from civilization.

A Check vs +0 tells a character which of two things considered is worth more. This can’t be used for coinage, but can be any other type of good. It also gives the character an idea of whether broken equipment can be reasonably salvaged.

This doesn’t give even a ballpark of what anything is worth, but it only takes a few seconds of consideration.

If using this Skill to scavenge for food, use the rules presented in the Botany section, however, two or more Complications results in you eating something poisonous.

Snaring

Base Cost 8

Stats Int/Dex

This teaches the character how to properly create and place snares to trap smaller wildlife. It also gives some cursory knowledge on the best places to put them.

Snares have a chance of giving you food once a week, although you’ll only actually roll when you Check them. Every Boon you get gives you half a day’s worth of food.

Use Rope

Base Cost 4

Stats Dex

Covering all kinds of knots and bindings, the Use Rope Skill is pretty self-explanatory, though it should be noted that you can also use this Skill to get a sense of the tensile strength of a rope or how much you’re going to need for a certain job.

To keep your players on their toes, I suggest you make the Check, not when they tie the knot, but when it’s tested.

Strategy Skill Suite

Base Cost 30

Stats Will/Pre

Combat isn’t just about raw physical power, but more about how it’s directed and used. This Skill Suite deals with logistics and making the most out of what you have.

Combat Style (style)

Base Cost 9

Stats Con/Int

By studying the best tactics and how to fight in certain circumstances, a warrior can take advantage of his surroundings and combat styles emerge. Combat Styles can be anything but involved in parts: a situation and a metric.

This situation is when the Combat Style is most effective. For instance, it can be “in the forest”, “fighting on rooftops”, “being outnumbered”, “being in a duel”, “fighting while prone”, etc. Really anything (as long as your GM approves).

The second part of the Combat Style is the metric applied to. This can be anything from the following list: Fatigue, Initiative, Recovery, Attack, Damage, and Parry.

Both the situation and metric are selected at the time of purchase and cannot be changed.

If the situation is applicable, the character receives a +1 to that metric for every 2 Ranks of that Skill he’s obtained.

So, a character with the Combat Skill (forest fighting, attack) at 5 who gets into a fight in a forest gets a +2 to attack.

Having a high Rank in Strategy doesn't automatically give you Combat Style bonuses under all circumstances and buying this Skill for the first time starts it off at Rank 0, instead of the Tactic Suite's Rank.

Leadership

Base Cost 6

Stats Pre/Will

The difference between a leader and an administrator is that the latter gets stuff done and the former gets others to get stuff done but hooking into what they believe and how they view themselves.

Those with this Skill can 'distribute' their Ranks among their traveling companions, followers, and hirelings.

Each Rank 'given' to a person increases their Panic by 1 step.

These Ranks can only be 'redistributed' once a week and can't affect the person 'giving' them. In a group, only one person can 'give' out their Leadership Ranks (as you can only have 1 party captain) and they must be present, alive, and conscious for the Ranks to have an effect.

Additionally, during a Combat, Confrontation, or Challenge, whenever you could apply it, the party captain can transfer a Grit Die from one character to another up to their Leadership Rank. He can do this a number of times equal to his Leadership Rank, but he can only transfer 1 Grit Die and that Grit Die has to be used immediately. They also gain 1d4! Stress per die transferred this way.

And finally, assuming you have a willing audience, you may make a Leadership Skill Check vs +0 pointed at a Characteristic you think the person or group might have.

If you succeed the Check and they have the Characteristic you’re looking for (or close enough - you don’t have to be exact), you increase their Panic threshold by 1 step for the next d4! hours. Gaining 2 or more Boon increases it by 2 steps.

You can increase the number of Characteristics you’re aiming for by increasing the Difficulty dice size of the Check by a similar number.

Quarter Mastering

Base Cost 5

Stats Int

There’s an art to packing and making sure that everyone is well fed and prepared. A quartermaster adds 1S for each Rank he has in this Skill. This also applies to any person he packs for.

Recruiting

Recruiting Check
Difficulty Location
-d10! Capital
-d6! Large City
-d4! Medium City
+0 Small City
+d4! Large Town
+d6! Medium Town
+d10! Small Town
+d20! Wilderness

Base Cost 8

Stats Will/Pre

Knowing where to find the right person is a crucial Skill for any long-term expedition. A character with this Skill can find a random person willing to hire on with a Check vs +0 in 2d6! days.

Now, finding specialists or someone with a certain Skill is another matter. Every additional criteria increases the Difficulty by 1 dice size.

Where you’re looking also makes a difference, as well.

This doesn’t guarantee that the person found will take the job or doesn’t have some serious issues, like a crippling fear of dogs: it only guarantees that they have the Skills you’re looking for and that they’re somewhat interested in being hired on. Pay and comfort make a lot of difference to a prospective hire.

Boons can be used to reduce the time by 1 day per but they can also be spent to have the people you find be more qualified in other ways that you weren't really looking for.

On the other hand, Complications will slightly alter the parameters in unfavorable way. So, for instance, you get 12 mercs instead of 10 but you have to hire them all.

Riding

Base Cost 8

Stats Dex/Will

This Skill teaches a character how to maintain their stability while on horseback and makes them capable of feats of equine prowess.

The bonuses for this Skill are varied and many with the specifics spelled out in Chapter 3:Combat under the Mounted Combat section so they won't be listed here. Seriously, go Check it out.

Signaling

Base Cost 4

Stats Int

This is the knowledge of how to communicate over long distances, either using semaphore, smoke signals, signal lamps, or horn blowing.

When using this means of communication, each side rolls a Check based on how complicated the message is and how quickly they need to send it.

Signaling is an ad hoc language with no grammatical rules or complicated tenses and so even at the best of times, only simple messages can be sent.

Warfare

Base Cost 9

Stats Int/Will/Pre

The Warfare Skill handles conducting a war, preparing your troops and directing them in a battle.

A Check can also be made to retroactively apply an action. This has to be something that the character could have done previous to the Combat, Confrontation, or Challenge and can't retroactively affect or change other major events (i.e., no "I roll to have never come into this dungeon in the first place"). The GM will have the final say. This Check starts at +0 Difficulty but increases by 1 dice size each time they’ve been rolled. This resets when the next time they Relax.

Finally, a number of times per Confrontation, Combat, or Challenge, a person with this Skill can 'pause' what's going on and discuss, out of character, what's going on with their other party members (even if their characters aren't in the scene). This lasts up to 1 minute out of game.

Warfare also has additional benefits and uses that will be outlined in Crowns of Fire, the kingdom management and mass combat supplement for Bonfire.

From Rounds to Seconds

The Warfare Advanced Skill can help players transition from round-based combat to count-up combat as it can give them a chance to breath, which they might be used to. You might even consider giving them a starting 5 pauses + Warfare Rank and then slowly lower that number as they get adjusted.

Trades Skill Suite

Base Cost 30

Stats Dex/Int

This suite covers the crafting and creating Skills. While there are a wide array and breath of professions, this list is pared down to those areas of knowledge where the common man and the adventurer overlap in their needs.

Appraisal (specific)

Base Cost 7

Stats Int

It’s wise to know what something is worth before selling and buying it. This Skill handles that and is taken for a specific type of good, such as books & scrolls, livestock, jewelry, arms & armor, and so on.

If a character has the appropriate Skill covering the item he’s looking to sell/purchase, a Check will tell them what kind of deal they're getting on the item - how much they’re being ripped off or how much of a steal it actually is.

Additionally, the character should get a bonus if he has any Skill that’s applicable to the thing he’s purchasing.

Articulation

Base Cost 5

Stats Will/Pre

You may think that the truth is powerful enough to carry your argument, but you can be beat out by a master of deception. Articulation is the Skill of rhetoric and formulating the truth in such a way that makes it the most convincing.

The level of Difficulty to convince someone is how much evidence you can supply to back up your arguments. This is opposed by Deception or Articulation but only if someone is actively trying to deceive or convince the same person as you.

Note that the Difficulty of their Deception Check may add bonus dice to your Articulation Check.

Even if you succeed, this isn’t a permanent way of changing a person’s mind. Others may lie more effectively than you can tell the truth and that may cause them to rethink their opinion on what you tried to sell them.

Artistry (specific)

Base Cost 8

Stats Dex

While some may not find the Fine Arts a worthy way to spend time, others may disagree. Artistry covers all artistic endeavors, including painting, sculpture, embroidery and anything else that is done for art’s sake.

Cooking/Baking

Base Cost 5

Stats Int

On the road, a hot meal can count for a lot. Once a day, a character who has a hot meal gains 1 Relaxation for every Boon the cook had on their Check.

On top of this, a character can prepare otherwise unpalatable or poisonous food in such a way as to make the most of it, though it is a Check vs d12! to do so.

Unless the character is trying to prepare a feast worthy of His Imperial Majesty, basic daily cooking only requires a Check vs +0.

Craft (specific)

Base Cost 8

Stats Dex/Int

This Skill covers any Skill that makes something that isn’t noted here, such as carpentry, tailoring, basket weaving, pottery, etc. The GM may adjust the price for a particularly difficult to master study.

Leatherworking

Base Cost 7

Stats Dex/Int

From the moment it leaves the beast to the moment the final touches are finished, leatherworking handles the process of making and crafting works from the hides of animals, including skinning and tanning.

Maintenance

Base Cost 6

Stats Dex/Int

The Skill of tinkers and adventurers, this gives the person a general knowledge of easy and ad hoc fixes that can be done on the fly.

A successful Check lowers the Wear on the item by 1 but you can lower the Wear by an additional point for every 2 Boons you get on your Check. The level of Difficulty in repairing something is equal to the Wear on the item, rounded up to the nearest dice size.

So repairing a spear with 1 Wear is a d4!, while repairing one with a 5 Wear is a d6!.

Another Check can't be made until the item gains more Wear. Additional repairs will need to be done with the corresponding Craft Skill.

Metalworking

Base Cost 9

Stats Dex/Int

This covers the process of changing crude ore into a beautiful weapon, armor, or decorative piece. It also covers the construction and repair of more mundane things, like plows, but if you’re picking this Skill up, I doubt you’re doing it to corner the farmer’s market.

Musician (specific)

Base Cost 6

Stats Dex/Pre

This covers the mastery of specific instruments, including singing. At the end of the day, the dulcet tones of a neatly played mandolin can ease the ache of a long day.

A character who hears someone play an instrument gains 1 Relaxation for every Boon the player had on his Check, although they only get this benefit once per day. The player also gains this bonus (although to really gain the benefit, he should probably Not Sweat It). This doesn’t stack with others playing; however, you will take the highest roll and use that to determine Relaxation. It also does no good if you’re in a stressful situation, like being hunted.

Unless the character is trying to serenade a queen, basic daily ditties only require a Check vs +0.

Performance

Base Cost 5

Stats Will/Pre

This Skill covers everything from making your case before a court or a stirring speech before charging into battle.

On a success, anyone listening gains a temporary Devotion to what the performer wants: whether that’s themselves or an organization or a case. If the Devotion already exists, the size is temporarily increased.

The Devotions strength is equal to the number of Boons the performer had.

Weirdcraft Skill Suite

Base Cost 40

Stats Int/Will

The science of the Weird is an oft studied but little understood branch of knowledge that requires a deep knowledge of the nature of the Painted World.

With this Skill Suite, someone can identify a spell, point out needed regents and processes for ritual shapings, detect if something is touched by the Weird and what its properties are, or even detect if a spell has been cast in an area, and have a chance of finding out what it was.

This Skill Suite is also used to identify Reagents from dead animals and monsters which can be sold or used to increase your spell power.

The final thing it does is allow you to shape cantrip versions of spells from any Tradition, regardless of Archetype. The ability to shape is inherit in all living things though it takes decades of practice, a strong family bloodline, and/or a natural gift to do what Weird-Adept Archetypes do, a form of practical "folkweird" is often passed down as part of the tools of the trade.

This doesn't, and will never, allow someone to shape the full version of a spell but it can give them a boost or an edge. The specific details should be left up to the GM and player, but they should always be appropriate to the Tradition and never be more powerful than a spell that does the same thing. Most commonly this will mean it will get used as a Skill while Helping Out or a Repurposed Skill. Regardless, it always takes 60 seconds - the Skill Rank to shape these effects.

All Advanced Weirdcraft Skills

Base Cost 12

Stats Int/Will

Unlike other Advanced Skilled, the Weirdcraft Advanced Skills pretty much work the same and so don't need their own section.

The first bonus that having an Advanced Weirdcraft Skill gives you is that it gives you further insight into a particular Weird Tradition, allowing you to detect it better. For more information on what each Tradition specializes in, head over to Chapter 6:The Weird but here is a small synopsis of each:

Animism This Tradition focuses on the manipulation of the body, forcing it to endure beyond its normal limits and making it into a weapon.

Calling This Tradition focuses on the Realms beyond the Middle one we’re so fond of. It involves the summoning of demons, elementals, and spirits.

Charm This focuses on the manifestation of the Weird in its raw and primal form. This allows the Weird to interact with our world in a more physical way.

Glamour This Tradition focuses on the manipulation of the senses, tricking the brain into seeing what the weird-adept wants you to see.

Investiture This focuses on inanimate objects and either imbuing them with power or manifesting the latent potential that is already in them.

Occultism This Tradition focuses on the hidden world and opening of the third mind: the divination of knowledge and the unseen.

Sortilege This Tradition focuses on fate, chance, and probability: more specifically, it focuses on messing with it so that things go in your favor.

Armor Skill Suite

Base Cost 40

Stat *

Training in armor allows you to move and operate more freely in all types of armor and mitigate some of the drawbacks of wearing them.

All Advanced Armor Skills

Base Cost 7

Stat *

Ranks in Armor Advanced Skills gives you the same benefit, regardless of the armor you're wearing. So, a Rank 5 in Recovery gives you a bonus of 5 to your Recovery whether you're wearing leather or full plate.

Defense This helps bring down the penalty for wearing the armor in the first place, however, once that penalty has reached 0, you get a +1 to your Defense for every additional 3 Ranks in this Skill, rounded down.

The bonus to Defense applies even if you're not wearing armor.

Fatigue For Fatigue, every 2 Ranks lowers the Fatigue penalty of applicable armor by 1. Thus, if you have Rank 2 Fatigue training in Fatigue, your Fatigue Threshold when wearing chainmail, for example, would be Wounded instead of Bloodied.

Once it reaches Critical (e.g. after 6 Ranks for chainmail armor), every 3 Ranks lowers your Skill Adjustment Penalty by 1.

Recovery & Initiative These Ranks reduce the associated penalties for wearing armor, however, they don’t give you a bonus once you’ve zeroed them out.

Melee Weapons Skill Suite

Base Cost 40

Stat *

Training in melee weapons allows you to fight more effectively while using all hand-to-hand weapons except your fists. It also allows you to kill your enemy more effectively.

All Advanced Melee Weapon Skills

Base Cost 7

Stat *

When you purchase an Advanced Melee Weapon Skill, you’ll need to select the specific type of weapon that the Ranks apply to; axes, sidearms, swords, polearms, or trauma weapons.

You can select the same Advanced Skill multiple times but they need to apply to different weapons categories.

Attack This Skill allows you to hit more consistently and is added to your Attack Check.

Parry This Skill increases your Parry range with that weapon on a 1-to-1 basis but also increases the weapon’s Breakage Threshold by 2 for every Rank you have in it and the Parry's static DR by 1 for every 3 Ranks.

The rules for breakage are found in Chapter 3:Combat.

Damage This Skill allows you to kill your enemies faster and gives you a bonus to damage based on your Rank and the weapon you're using.

Crushing weapons gain a +1 per 2 Ranks (rounded up); For Slashing and piercing weapons, you start at a +d3! damage and increase it by 1 dice per 2 Ranks above that (rounded up), however slashing is capped at a +d4! and piercing is capped at a +d8!. Once you hit that cap, additional Ranks start the process over, adding another d3! and then increasing it. Note that these additional dice do add to the dice number for /D DR.

So, if you have a Rank 5 in a slashing weapon, you're going to add +d3!+2d4! to your damage with that weapon. If you have Rank 5 with a piercing weapon, you instead add a +d3!+d8! instead.

Recovery This Skill allows you to attack quicker. You subtract 1 from the weapon's Recovery for every 2 Ranks (rounded up).

Minimum Weapon Recovery

How fast a weapon can move and maneuver is ultimately limited by its size and balance and no matter how much you train, you can’t overcome that hurtle.

All Piercing Weapons

2 Seconds

Small Slashing Weapons

3 Seconds

Medium Slashing & Small Crushing Weapons

4 Seconds

Large Slashing & Medium Crushing Weapons

5 Seconds

Large Crushing Weapons

6 Seconds

Ranged Weapons

Per Weapon

Ranged Weapons Skill Suite

Base Cost 40

Stat *

Training in ranged weapons allows you to fight more effectively from afar. It also allows you to kill your enemy more effectively from a distance.

All Advanced Ranged Weapon Skills

Base Cost 7

Stat *

When you purchase an Advanced Ranged Weapon Skill, you’ll need to select the specific type of weapon that the Ranks apply to; thrown, mechanical, firearms, or Shape Rudiment (although for the Shape Rudiment Advanced Skill you can only purchase Attack).

You can select the same Advanced Skill multiple times but they need to apply to different weapons.

Attack This Skill allows you to hit more consistently and is added to your Attack Check.

Damage This Skill allows you to kill your enemies faster and gives you a bonus to damage based on your Rank and the weapon you're using.

Crushing weapons gain a +1 per 2 Ranks (rounded up); For Slashing and piercing weapons, you start at a +d3! damage and increase it by 1 dice per 2 Ranks above that (rounded up), however slashing is capped at a +d4! and piercing is capped at a +d8!. Once you hit that cap, additional Ranks start the process over, adding another d3! and then increasing it. Note that these additional dice do add to the dice number for /D DR.

So, if you have a Rank 5 in a slashing weapon, you're going to add +d3!+2d4! to your damage with that weapon. If you have Rank 5 with a piercing weapon, you instead add a +d3!+d8! instead.

Recovery This Skill allows you to attack quicker. You subtract 1 from the weapon's Recovery for every 2 Ranks (rounded up)

Shields Skill Suite

Base Cost 40

Stat *

Training in shields allows you to utilize them as a defensive item more effectively, minimizing their drawbacks while maximizing their bonuses.

When you purchase an Advanced Shield Skill, you’ll need to select the specific type of shield that the Ranks apply to; small, medium, or large.

You can select the same Advanced Skill multiple times but they need to apply to different shield types.

Breakage

Base Cost 3

Stat *

By learning how to properly deflect incoming attacks, the shield fighter can prolong the longevity of their shield. Every Rank in this Skill gives you a +3 to your breakage threshold with that style of shield.

The rules for breakage are found in Chapter 3:Combat.

Fatigue

Base Cost 7

Stat *

For Fatigue, every 2 Ranks lowers the Fatigue penalty of applicable shields by 1. Thus, if you have Rank 2 Fatigue training in Fatigue (Medium), your Fatigue Threshold when wielding that shield would be Wounded instead of Bloodied.

Parry

Base Cost 7

Stat *

This Skill increases your Parry range with that shield on a 1-to-1 basis.

Unarmed Skill Suite

Base Cost 40

Stat *

Being trained in the Unarmed Skill Suite allows you to more effectively grapple, throw, and otherwise disable your opponent using your body: no weapons required.

However, no matter how many Ranks you have in the Skill Suite or its Advanced Skills, you’re never treated as if you have a weapon while unarmed.

All Advanced Unarmed Skills

Base Cost 5 for Effectiveness, 7 for everything else

Stat *

Attack This Skill allows you to hit more consistently and is added to your Attack Check.

Parry This Skill allows you to parry blows with your hand more effectively, increasing your Parry range on a 1-to-1 basis and the Parry's static DR by 1 for every 3 Ranks.

Effectiveness Effectiveness is applied to the difference between the Attack and Defense for additional benefits when using that unarmed move but ONLY if the attack hits. Every Rank adds a +3. So, Rank 3 in Effectiveness gives you a +9 to your total.

Effectiveness (Holds) applies to all holds: both maintaining a grab but also breaking free of one.

Chapter 5Skills

Carry

Instead of each item having a weight in pounds or ounces, each item is assigned a size that represents, not only how much it weighs, but also its general bulky and awkwardness. These sizes correspond to the naming conventions set up in Chapter 7:Misc. Rules, however, just because something is Medium sized here, doesn’t mean it’s the size of a human - again, item sizes are based on their weights, bulkiness, and awkwardness to carry.

Your Carry matches up with that, so if you have 2M as your Carry, you can carry 2 Medium items - or 2M items and is based on your strength

Base Carry
Strength Carry
1 1S
2 2S
3 1M
4 1M 1S
5 1M 2S
6 2M
7 2M 1S
8 2M 2S
9 1L
10 1L
11 1L
12 1L 2S
13 1L 1M 1S
14 1L 2M
15 1L 2M 2S
16 2L 1S
17 3L
18 3L 1M
19 3L 2M
20 4L
21 4L 1M
22 4L 2M
23 5L

You can also swap out 1 for 3 of the size lower. So instead of carrying 2M items, you could carry 1M item and 3S items.

Each individual instance of an item counts towards this: carrying two daggers, both S items, would count as 2S for Carry.

Wearing Items

Normally what is written under the Carry column for each item is its Size. The only exception is clothes, armor, and personal containers. If worn on your person, not carried or stuffed in a backpack, these become less encumbering since their weight is distributed across basically the entire body.

In this case, shrink them 1 size for Carry purposes. Small items become negligible. Wearing boots, a Small item, then makes them effectively weightless, while any Heavy Armor makes them only M.

Personal Containers

Personal Containers, such as backpacks or sacks, go one step further. Since it is assumed that your Carry weight is how much you can hold effectively, it does take into account that some things are too awkward to effectively carry despite being fairly light.

These containers increase your Carry by the noted amount.

The exceptions, sort of, to this are coin purses, which make coins negligible (otherwise they’re 10 = 1S), quivers which do the same thing but with arrows, and scabbards (for Large and Medium weapons) and sheaths (for Small weapons) allow you to wear weapons - shrinking them 1 size.

Going Over Carry

You can go over your Carry, of course, but it will slow you down. Going over your Carry prevents you from Sprinting.

Beyond that, each M of weight over your limit removes the next quickest Movement Category (so, removing Running, Jogging, Walking, and then Crawling) until your character is unable to move. It also lowers your Fatigue Threshold by 1 as well.

Unless proven otherwise, the GM should assume the characters are carrying their max Carry if they pick up something new while out adventuring.

Drag

Instead of trying to carry something, a character can always drag it behind them, which is much easier.

In this case, a person can drag 3 times what they can Carry, but this is a straight multiplication.

So, a person who can carry 1L can drag 3L; a person who can carry 2M can drag 6M.

However, regardless of how much they're dragging, they cannot move above a Walk and going over their drag limit once, dropped them to a max of Crawl. Going over twice prevents them from moving at all.

Currency

The denomination of coinage is fairly simple and is done in divisions of 10.

10 cc = 1 silver coin (sc)

10 sc = 1 gold coin (gc)

10 gc = 1 platinum coin (pc)

So, 100 cc is equal to 1 gc.

The silver coin is the base of the economy and is what most day-to-day interactions use. If a denomination isn’t noted, it’s assumed to be sc.

Note that 100 coins is 1S

Superior Equipment

Not all equipment is built the same and, if you have some extra coin, it might benefit you to invest in some good quality gear.

Superior gear is always unique and even two +1 longswords can be different. This is done through Descriptions and they're like the Descriptions that your character has: they're just used to describe gear instead.

During a Confrontation, Combat, or Challenge, if that Description applies, you can gain an extra bonus equal to its Rank to what is going on. The exact details are noted in the particular chapter.

You can have additional Descriptions on a single item, increase the Rank of Descriptions you already have and/or add new ones (as long as they make sense and start at Rank 1).

Every time you do so adds an extra 25% to the cost of the item. This is compounded and is calculated using the total Ranks of all Descriptions, so getting a +2 costs the same as 2 +1s.

So getting a Finely Tuned (+2) Mandolin would cost 93.7 sc ( ( 60 * 1.25 ) * 1.25) while getting one that is Finely Tuned (+1) and Inlaid (+1) would cost the same.

Wear

Wear represents how close your weapon is to breaking.

Simply put: if, on a Skill Check, Attack roll (for weapons), or Defense roll (for shields and armor), you roll equal to or below the Wear of that item on the unmodified main die of the Check (usually a d20), that item breaks and becomes functionality unusable until it’s repaired.

There are some specific cases that should be noted:

  1. You still maintain any penalties (Fatigue, Defense Modifiers from armor and shields, for example) that item gives you unless you discard it.
  2. In the case of weapons, you can still use the broken weapon - you just half all the damage it does.
  3. And finally, instead of having the item break, if it’s a Superior quality item, you can instead reduce one of its Descriptions by 1 as long as you have at least a Rank 1 in that Description. The Wear remains but the weapon isn't broken.

Repairing

Since the Maintenance Skill will only get you so far, you might need to remove Wear from your gear through blacksmithing. This is done through personally having the applicable Skill (Leather- or Metalworking, for example) or through contract work.

Hiring It Out

If you just hand off your gear to a blacksmith, the price for repairs is 10% of the price you would normally buy the item (not factoring in the price increase for it being Superior if that's the case) per point of Wear and takes 1 day for every 40 sc the repairs cost.

Doing It Yourself

If personally done through the appropriate Skill, the cost for raw materials is 10% of the base Source price for the item per point of Wear with the base time being 1 day for every 80 sc, however, two things to note:

The first is that you need to roll a Check vs d20! + the amount of Wear rounded to the next largest dice size (so, 4 Wear becomes a d6!) as the end of that time. Each Complication results in that amount of leftover Wear that will require twice the time and raw materials to fix (even if you then go to blacksmith) at which point you'll need to make another Check.

So, if you're repairing a glaive (base cost 49 sc) with 8 Wear on it. The cost per Wear is 2sc 4cc so the total for all 8 would be 19sc 2cc, which will take just about 5 days.

At the end of those 5 days you'd roll a Check vs d20!+d10!.

If you fail by 10 (2 Complications), that means that you were only able to repair 6 Wear, leaving 2 left over. To fix that it would be an additional 9sc 6cc (since it's 4sc 8cc this time per Wear) and take another 4 days or so.

Note that your total comes to 28sc 8cc where going to a blacksmith would have cost you 39sc 2cc.

The last thing to consider is that if you don't have a forge for metalworking, you'll have to rent one, which can range from 1cc to 1sc per day depending on how busy the forge (good luck trying to rent one at a military camp).

Selling Equipment

Players can, of course, sell equipment but the price is going to be reduced: this is normally a quarter the price of buying the item but the cost to repair the item if it has Wear should also be factored in.

If the piece of equipment was used/created by a monster who wouldn’t have taken very good care of it (such as a goblin), it is only worth 10% of the price instead.

Table Header Explanations

The following is a breakdown of how to read the following tables. Note that the prices here are not absolute and are actually the lowest price you’ll find for a give item based on the area. War, tariffs, what relationship the buyer has with the seller, and even the political climate can cause these numbers to fluctuate wildly.

Name

This is the common name for the item.

Size

This is the size of the object.

Source

This is the wholesale sc cost of producing the item.

Local Market

This is the sc price of purchasing this item within a day’s travel of the place where it was manufactured.

Nearby City

This is the sc price of picking up this item within about a week’s travel from where the thing was crafted.

Distance City

This is the sc price of the item in faraway markets, either across a political border or beyond a month’s travel away. This price increases the further away the city is, obviously.

Equipment Prices

Animals, Livestock & Pets
Name Source Local Market Nearby Market Distant City
{{content.name}} {{content.size}} {{content.price}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'local', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'nearby', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'distant', content.size)}}
Animals, Mounts
Name Source Local Market Nearby Market Distant City
{{content.name}} {{content.size}} {{content.price}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'local', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'nearby', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'distant', content.size)}}

Mount Stats

Each mount is different though they do have ranges based on the breed and this is represented by their unique set of stats that are rolled for each mount you look at while shopping. These can usually be discerned by a Handle Animal Check that's, of course, appropriate to the type. So, nice try, but Handle Animal (horse) won't help you figure out which riding lizard is best.

These stats are then used to determine the specifics of each mount: how fast can they get up and go? How long can they run for? Each of the main stats has a positive effect on some of these derived stats and a negative effect on others so figuring out the right balance for what you want out of a mount can be tricky. Averages for each breed are found under that breed's profile in the Bonfire Bestiary.

You’ll note the min roll for each stat at the very top of the table for easy reference.

Mount Stats
Turning Deceleration Acceleration Carry Vitality Endurance Bravery
Min 2 2 2 0 none none none
Camel, Bachrian 3+d4! 5+d4! 5+2d4! 40+3d6! (1d8 * 4) + 125 1+2d4! -d6!
Camel, Dromedary d4! 5+d4! 5+2d4! 20+2d6! (1d8 * 7) + 125 2d4! -d4!
Goat, Riding 5+d4! 2+d4! 5+2d4! 50+3d6! (1d10 * 4) + 20 3d4!+1 d4!
Horse, Courser 5-d4! 5+2d4! 5-2d4! 50+3d6! (1d8 * 5) + 100 d4!-2 d4!-2
Horse, Destrier 5+2d4! 5+2d6! 5-2d6! 20+3d6! (1d8 * 3) + 100 d4! 2d4!-6
Horse, Palfrey 4+d4! 5+2d6! 5+2d4! 20+3d6! (1d8 * 9) + 100 5+d4! 2-d4!
Horse, Rounsey 4+d4! 4+d4! 4+d4! 45+3d8! (1d8 * 7) + 100 d4!+1 d4!-2
Horse, Sumpter 1+d4! 3+d4! 5+2d6! 50+3d6! (1d8 * 7) + 100 2d4!+1 -d4!
Lizard, Pack 5+2d4! 3+d4! 2+d4! 85+3d10! (1d8 * 7) + 75 d4! d4!-2
Lizard, Riding 8+3d6! 5+d4! 2+d4! 85+3d10! (1d8 * 11) + 75 3d4! d4!
Mule 5+2d4! d4! 5+2d4! 85+3d10! (1d8 * 7) + 100 8+d4! -2d4!

The details of what these stats mean are expanded on in the Mounted Combat section of Chapter 3:Combat but a lower Turning, Deceleration and Acceleration is good, a high Bravery is good, Carry is how many Large items they can carry (note that Small Creatures are considered a 1 Large Item, Medium are 3 Large Items, and Large are 9), and Endurance and Vitality work the same as they do in humans.

Armor
Name Size Source Local Market Nearby Market Distant City
{{content.name}} {{content.size}} {{content.price}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'local', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'nearby', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'distant', content.size)}}

Small & Large Sized Creatures

Obviously, a smaller creature requires less material to make a suite of armor while a larger one requires more, so armor built for Small-sized creatures cost half the price while armor for Large-sized creatures double it.

Note that this only applies after character creation.

Armor Table Header Explanation

DR

This number is subtracted from the damage dealt by a weapon.

Def

All armor weighs you down and makes it harder to dodge incoming attacks. This number is added to your Defense roll.

Init Mod

Armor is restricting, even at the best of times. This is added to your Initiative roll at the start of combat.

Rec Mod

Again, armor is restricting. This is added to your weapon’s Recovery.

Type

This denotes how many Vitality Categories you need to decrease your Fatigue Threshold by. You should note that should you purchase Medium or Heavy armor, this comes with a Gambeson that’s worn underneath for comfort. This is already factored into the other stats of the armor.

Weight

This is how heavy your armor is for Carry when your armor is carried on your person.

Fatigue Threshold

This denotes how many Vitality Categories you need to decrease your Fatigue Threshold by.

Skill Adj

Armor, regardless of how fitted, is restricting and heavy, making it harder to perform certain skills in certain gear. This is the number applied to physical Skill Checks.

Armor Stats
Name DR Defense Mod Init Mod Rec Mod Fatigue Skill Adj
{{content.name}} {{content.dr}} {{content.def}} {{content.init}} {{content.rec}} {{content.fatigue}} {{content.skill}}
Beverages
Name Strength Size Source Local Market Nearby Market Distant City
{{content.name}} {{content.strength}} {{content.size}} {{content.price}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'local', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'nearby', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'distant', content.size)}}

Effects of Drunkenness

Medieval and Renaissance alcohol was a lot weaker than the stuff we have today but it could get your drunk, which did have some perks.

There are 5 stages to drunkenness: Buzzed, Drunk, Sloshed, Browned Out, and Blacked out. Each stage gives you +2 to any Relaxation you gain and a +4 to any Morale Checks and any Checks you make to Resist Mental Spell Effects you make, however, it also lowers all other Checks by 1 dice size and increases the Ranks for any Flaws by +2 as well.

How quickly you can get drunk is based on your tolerance and your Size. For every pint dunk, roll a Resistance (Alcohol) Check vs d20 + (the alchol's strength * the number of points you've had). If you're Small for Knock-Backs, you roll this Check on a d12!. If you fail, you move up a stage. Every 2 Complications moves you up an additional stage. 3 - 4 bears for Drunk, 5 - 6 for Browned Out.

Personal Container Limits

You can't just pile on the backpacks to give you infinite Carry: you're, in fact, limited. You can wear 1 backpack, and up to 3 pouches, and 3 of any other type of containers (coin purse, quiver, canteen, scabbards, etc.). You can also be considered to be wearing up to 2 sacks or bags but only if you're carrying them with your hands.

Coin Purses

Coin purses help you carry all that loose change you have. Normally, 100 coins is 1S but, with a coin purse, 200 coins is 1S.

Hirelings

Hirelings
Cost per Day
Artisan Advanced Skill Base Cost
Mercenary 10
Unskilled Laborer 1

Artisans starts with 3 points. These points can be spent on skills or equipment. The point cost to increase a Skill is (base cost + (Rank * 3)) / 10, minimum 1, except equipment which is a number of points = Source price / 100, rounded up.

You get to distribute a number of points equal to your Recruiting Rank - the GM gets to spend the rest.

When you hire a mercenary, you'll need to determine their role or specialty. These are found in the Mercenary entry in the Bestiary. This determines their starting stats and equipment which you can then improve.

Basic Food & Lodgings

This is not normally included. +1 sc/day.

Hazard Pay

Artisans and Unskilled Laborers will demand a share of the loot or double pay for anything dangerous. Mercenaries normally don't unless the job is more dangerous than you let on when you hired them. Note that this doesn't suddenly make them soldiers: they will defend themselves but they won't go on the attack and they certainly won't put their lives in any more danger than they absolutely have to.

More Skilled Artisan And Mercenaries

1 extra point per +1 sc/day they demand.

Improved Morale

Doubling the pay per day gives a +d4! to morale checks. Each doubling after increases it by 1 dice size.

Presence

Subtract Presence in cc from price/day, down to half of the total cost.

Musical Instruments

Poison (per Dose) Effect Delivery
Blacknessel 1d12!/40 Sec/Int Ingestion
Blue Glory 4d4!/10 Sec/Str Ingestion
Bondweed 3d8!/2 Min/10 Stress Contact
Griffin Hair 4d8!/6 Min/-1 Fatigue Ingestion
Lylullin 2d10!/30 Sec/Will Ingestion
Maidenscap 5d3!/1 Hour/Con Ingestion
Palm of St Germain 2d6!/10 Sec/Pre Ingestion
Tears Of Sicyon 2d6!/20 Sec/Dex Contact

Crafting Poisons & Toxins

Seeing the prices is natural (and right) for players to want to craft their own poisons but poisons are expensive not only because they're largely illegal but because it takes a lot of effort to make them - at least, good ones.

You can find a lot of things in natura that are toxic to humans but they come with two problems: they're too weak, only making someone sick temporarily and they're often detectable. Think of spoiled food: when it's hard to detect, it often results in mild food poisoning that only knocks someone out for a day or two. When it's powerful enough to kill, the food smells and tastes horrible, often causing people to throw up before they've even ingested a meaningful quantity.

The poisons listed above are extremely concentrated and with the right chemical breakdown that they're basically undetectable but that comes from lots of rare plants and a lot of manufactoring so, if players want to make their own poisons, it's more than simply gathering a handful of toxic flowers.

At the very least, they'll need an alchemical lab, time, materials, and know-how. A lot of this is already covered in the crafting rules. Typically, the equipment will cost 10 times the Source Price of the poison (modified by the distance the equipment will need to travel as per normal) and, once assembled, isn't portable, but, after researching and crafting, characters can produce the poison at Source price so characters who make it a make it main part of their playstyle will quickly have it pay off.

Services
Name Source Local Market
Cartage, /barrel, /day, Overland 2 3
Chantry Prayer, 1 Monk, /day 4 5
Fortune Telling, /Half Hour 2 3
Handsome Cab, /Half Hour 1 1.5

Lodging, Double, Cheap Inn (Each) 2.5 3.33
Lodging, Quadruple, Ave. Inn (Each) 3 3.99
Lodging, Quadruple, Cheap Inn (Each) 2 2.66
Lodging, Single, Boarding House (Monthly) 100 133
Lodging, Single, Religious Hostel 2 3
Scribe, Writing or Copying, /Hour 2 3
Shipping, /barrel, /day, Sea 1.5 2.25

Stabling Horse, /day, w/ hay, No Grain 0.7 1
Travel, Coach, /day 10 15
Travel, Ship, /day 12 18

Services

These are common services the players might employ while in a settlement.

Chantry Prayers

In settlements with chantries, the players can pay for a monk to pray for them, bestowing 1 temporary Favor per day per monk.

This Favor cannot be banked from day to day: simply disappearing if going unused.

Fortune Telling

Fortune Tellers are able to gaze into the miasma of the future to discern the fates of those that come to them.

After getting a reading, once per Grit Die they've earned through other ways, they can roll a Pres Check vs d20. Should they succeed, they gain 1 Grit Die.

Should they fail, they lose a Grit Die.

Getting a reading with no Grit Die results in no Check, no bonus, but no penalty.

Shields
Name Size Source Local Market Nearby Market Distant City
{{content.name}} {{content.size}} {{content.price}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'local', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'nearby', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'distant', content.size)}}

Shield Table Header Explanation

Size

This indicates the general size of a shield. It also determines how tough your shield is.

Shields 2 sizes larger must be wielded with 2 hands and those 3 sizes greater must be wielded with 2 hands and the wielder gains a -2 to their Fatigue (meaning that if you would normally become Fatigued at Critical, you'd instead become Fatigued at Bloodied).

However, using a shield as a Small creature does have its benefits: increase the Cover by +3 (+6).

DR

This number is subtracted from the damage dealt by a weapon on a successful parry with a shield.

Def

This is the number that you subtract from your character’s defense. Lugging a huge piece of material on the end of your arm makes dodging a bit difficult. Additionally, you’re often moving a shield into harm’s way, meaning, overall, you get hit more while wielding one.

Parry

Some shields are balanced better than others and that allows you to deflect blows more effectively. This number is the shield’s Parry Threshold. This overrides your weapon’s Parry regardless of which is higher. Parrying with a shield subjects it to the Shield Breakage rules.

Cover

The first number is the bonus that you add to your Defense Check against ranged weapons. If you’re actively crouching behind it, you're limited to Crawling but you add the number in parentheses instead. * denotes that crouching behind that shield gives total cover so ranged attacks automatically miss.

Flanks

This is the number of additional attackers from the side that the shield can defend against. More on that is found in Chapter 3:Combat.

Fatigue

This numbers adjusts the Wound Category at which you become Fatigued. So a shield with Fatigue -1 means that you become Fatigued at Wounded, instead of Critical (assuming you're not wearing armor as this penalty stacks with armor's).

Bonus

Some shields have additional unique bonuses. If there is a ‘yes’ in this column, look up the shield in the following section to find out more details.

Shield Stats
Name Size DR Def Parry Cover Flanks Fatigue Bonus
{{content.name}} {{content.size}} {{content.dr}} {{content.def}} {{content.parry}} {{content.cover}} {{content.flanks}} {{content.fatigue}} {{content.bonus ? 'Yes' : ''}}

Shield Bonuses

Buckler

The buckler is a lightweight shield which relies more on parrying blows than outright stopping them. The buckler also has the added benefit of being rather small with almost no weight, allowing it to be held but not used while wielding two handed weapons. You receive no bonuses when doing this, but it means that if you do switch over to a one-handed weapon, you instantly get the buckler’s bonus.

This shield is gripped instead of being strapped in: it only takes 1 second to ready.

Clothe

Clothe shields aren't official shields: they're improvised by wrapping a clothe (a tunic works or any M-sized piece of clothing or fabric works) around the wrist.

Figure Eight

This shield is designed specifically for phalanx or shield-wall tactics. This gives a +2 Parry and a Cover of +2 (+4) to anyone fighting on either side of you. This stacks with any Parry or Cover that they have from either their weapon or shields.

This shield is gripped instead of being strapped in: it only takes 2 seconds to ready.

Pavise

This shield is less a shield and more portable cover employed by gunners and crossbowman, rather than fighters.

However, the Pavise can be set up using a kick stand in the back, giving anyone crouching behind it basically complete cover and allowing that person the ability to steady their weapon on it.

Round

With the Round Shield, on a natural roll of 20 on Defense or an Unarmed Strike, you delay your opponent’s next attack by 5 seconds.

They also delay the enemy an additional 5 seconds if used to perform a strike in unarmed combat.

This shield is gripped instead of being strapped in: it only takes 2 seconds to ready.

Substances, Ropes & Fabrics
Name Size Source Local Market Nearby Market Distant City
{{content.name}} {{content.size}} {{content.price}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'local', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'nearby', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'distant', content.size)}}

Rope Poundage & Snapping

All ropes have a max poundage they can hold, noted like this: (250#). Should a rope have that much weight on it at one time, it comes under strain, gaining 1 Wear every second. Should it reach 20 Wear, it automatically snaps.

Torches & Lanterns

All torches and Lanterns last for 1 hour.

Ammunition
Name Size Source Local Market Nearby Market Distant City
{{content.name}} {{content.size}} {{content.price}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'local', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'nearby', content.size)}} {{calculatePrice(content.price, 'distant', content.size)}}

Weapon Table Header Explanation

Size

A weapon’s size indicates the smallest size the wielder can be to use it 1 handed.

Weapons 1 size larger must be wielded with 2 hands and those greater than that can still be used but they lower the wielder's Fatigue Threshold by 3 for each size of difference beyond that first step (so a human holding a a size Huge weapon lowers their Fatigue Threshold by 3, meaning that if they would normally become Fatigued at Critical, they'd instead become Fatigued at Hurt).

Damage

This is the damage inflicted when a successful hit is scored.

Recovery

This is the number of seconds a character locked in melee must wait before attacking again with this weapon.

Dam Type

This tells you whether the weapon is Slashing (S), Piercing (P), or Crushing (C).

Parry

Some weapons are balanced better than others and that allows you to deflect some blows.

This is the weapon’s Parry Threshold. This overrides by your shield’s Parry if you’re using one, regardless of which is higher.

A successful parry with a weapon has a DR of 2/D. Parrying with a weapon subjects it to the Shield Breakage rules.

Measure

This is a measure in feet of how long a weapon is.

Bonus

Some weapons have additional unique bonuses. If there is a ‘yes’ in this column, look up the weapon in the following section to find out more details.

Melee Weapon Stats
